Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

I desire to refer to your memorandum of June 10 enclosing copy of a report submitted by the Chief Architect, Mr. Buck, dealing particularly with the waterproofing of the walls of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

Under the direction of Mr. Warren of Mr. Webb's staff part of the exterior brickwork at this school was treated with a product prepared by the Minwax Co., Inc. of New York. The reports received from the Principal indicate that there has been no leakage of water through the walls treated with this product.

Present indications are that we will have some funds available for further expenditure at the Alert Bay School during the current fiscal year and it would be appreciated if you would ascertain and advise me as soon as possible the amount and cost of the material that would be required to complete the waterproofing of the exterior walls in the same manner as the section which has already been treated under Mr. Warren's direction.

When we receive this information from you it will be decided if the amount required can be provided and, in that event, it is our intention to arrange for its purchase and storage at the Alert Bay School so that it may be applied to the exterior walls when weather conditions are suitable during the spring of 1941.

Director.
Ottawa,
November 4, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo with reference to the completion of the waterproofing of the outside face of the walls of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

It is noted from your letter that it is too late to do the work during the current fiscal year but as present indications are that we will have some funds available I am taking up the matter with the Surveys & Engineering Branch with a view to determining the quantity and cost of the material that would be required to complete the waterproofing of the exterior walls. When we have this information it will be decided if the funds can be provided and, in that event, the material will be purchased and shipped to the school for storage until next year when the work can be done.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your letter of September 25th, your file 156-0-5, regarding the completion of the waterproofing of the outside face of the walls of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

On receipt of your letter I wrote to Mr. Todd for a report on the work done last year under the direction of Mr. W.C. Warren, but owing to the Agent's absence from his office considerable delay occurred in supplying the information requested.

It would appear from the reports received that the last waterproofing has proved satisfactory and that the Department would be justified in making the necessary arrangements to continue the work.

It is too late to do any of this work this fiscal year as in order to obtain satisfactory results the waterproofing material should be applied in the warm dry weather of summer.

As the work already done, including the purchase of materials, was carried out by the local Branch of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau, on instructions from the Surveys and Engineering Branch, Ottawa, I should like to suggest that the question of the purchase of the materials required be referred to that Branch who could make the necessary arrangements with their Vancouver Office to place the orders for the materials and the storage of same.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of October 2nd last, file 15/6/8131, I regret the delay in answering same owing to my absence from the office.

Enclosed you will please find copy of a letter received from Principal Anfield, which will be self-explanatory.

My observations from time to time concur with Mr. Anfield's findings, and I would recommend that the balance of the walls be water-proofed next spring as soon as weather conditions permit, using the same material as heretofore.

Your obedient servant,

"M. S. Todd"
Indian Agent.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Vancouver, B.C.
October 25th, 1940.

The Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.

Dear Sir,

With reference to our conversation of today's date, I have made a further careful examination of the inside walls on the south-east face of the building. It can be said with reasonable certainty that the water-proofing carried out by the Department under the supervision of Mr. W. O. Warren, has proved satisfactory to date.

In conversation with those who have been constantly working on this side of the building, and from my own observations since this work was completed, it can be said that no water has seeped through from the water-proofed surfaces to the inside of the building. It is noticeable that the heavy furring which took place on these walls previously has now ceased, but continues in increasing amounts on the front wall of the school which, as you are aware, was not water-proofed.

In giving weight to the relative values of the new roof put on the school at the same time as this water-proofing was done and the water-proofing itself, it must be reported that there has been but little diminution of water in the basements coming through the front walls. This would seem to add to the value of the water-proofing work done as such seepage has stopped entirely on that face of the building.

The residence, which was water-proofed at the same time as the south east wall, has also stood up well and there are no signs of seepage through any of the walls.

In view of these facts, it would appear most likely that the completion of this water-proofing work would solve the problem of leakage into the school entirely, and it is a pleasure to hear that the Department has funds available to undertake this work. I am glad, however, that only the purchase of materials will be made at this time as it would be absolutely impossible to do such work during the weather we shall have from now on until spring.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Principal.

March 6, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Consideration has recently been given to the necessity for waterproofing the south and east walls of the Alert Bay School and Principal's residence. Part of the east wall was done two or three years ago but I understand that an additional coat of liquid waterproofing is advisable.

In preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1941-42 it was only found possible to include an amount of $1075.00 for repairs and improvements at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. Our funds next year will be so limited that it will be impossible to expend a larger amount than the sum mentioned.

I have recently received an estimate showing that the cost of the material required for waterproofing the walls would be approximately $750.00. If the Department bought the necessary material for this work could the school management assist us by supplying labour without any cost to us? Such action on their part would be greatly appreciated as, due to present conditions, it is not possible to provide funds for the purpose.

Please discuss this matter at once with Mr. Anfield and let me have an early reply.

Yours truly,

Mr. M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Alert Bay School.

With further reference to your memorandum of November 4th, 1940, relative to the proposed purchase, during the present fiscal year, of materials for the further waterproofing of the walls of the above school, I am enclosing for your information copy of a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, Engineering and Construction Service, dated February 27th, to which is attached a Bill of Materials.

It will be noted that Mr. Mills asks to be advised as soon as possible whether this work is to be undertaken during the coming summer so that he can arrange accordingly.

General Executive Assistant.
February 27, 1941.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Alert Bay Residential School

With reference to your memoranda of November 25th and December 12th last, regarding waterproofing for exterior walls on the above, I may say that an inspection of the school was carried out on the 1st and 2nd instant by Mr. Warren of Mr. Webb's staff.

We are now in receipt of Mr. Warren's report dated the sixth instant in which he states that moisture is entering the building through the south and east walls only, and that he was unable to find any evidence of dampness on those portions of the east wall of both the school and principal's residence which were waterproofed with Minwax in 1938. The untreated portion of the east wall and most of the south wall appear so saturated that seepage is evident in a number of basement rooms. In some spots the plaster has fallen off and in many instances in the upper floors of the school evidence of moisture penetration is present where the plaster has become soft and porous.

From Mr. Warren's report it is noted that paint has deteriorated on the window frames, and in many cases has weathered off entirely. The absence of paint on the brickmoulds has allowed them to absorb water, which has resulted in loosening and cracking the caulking.

The need for pointing of brick joints does not appear to be great; but it is understood from the report that some work of this nature will be necessary.

From observation and discussions with the school principal, Mr. Warren appears satisfied that no trouble from dampness has been, or is likely to be, encountered in the north and west walls.

The work involved in remedying the conditions at the school, including the principal's residence, and as reported by Mr. Warren may be summarized as follows:

(a) Thoroughly clean all brick surfaces including back of parapet walls from all scale, dirt and dust. Remove efflorescence by the use of a diluted solution of hydrochloric acid.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
(b) Rake out and point all loosened and cracked mortar joints in brickwork and stone coping; and caulk all cracks and flaws in brickwork with Minwax or equal caulking compound.

(c) Remove all loosened caulking from window brickmoulds, and recaulk where necessary.

(d) On the south wall of both the school and principal's residence apply two coats of Minwax or equal liquid waterproofing, coloured at the job to match previous waterproofing treatment. On the areas of the east wall of both the school and principal's residence, not previously treated, apply two coats of liquid waterproofing, coloured as for south wall. On the east wall of both the school and principal's residence, previously treated, apply one additional coat of liquid waterproofing, coloured as for south wall. Waterproofing should be coloured by the addition of dry colour, and should be applied with a spray gun.

(e) Due to the obliteration of the brick jointing by the coloured waterproofing, the treated surfaces will present areas of one solid colour. In order to obtain a uniform colour over the whole building, the north and west walls not being waterproofed should be coloured with two coats of oil stain, which could be prepared at the job.

(f) Repaint window brickmoulds with two coats of approved paint.

A spray painting machine should be provided for the application of the waterproofing material, and the oil stain. It is felt, however, that since only the purchase of materials is contemplated during the current fiscal year, arrangements might be made for the rental of such labour saving equipment, when operations are begun.

I am forwarding herewith, in duplicate, a bill of materials in connection with the work, which materials are estimated to cost approximately $1,229.00, delivered at Alert Bay. This estimate may be subdivided as follows:

**Waterproofing materials**

- Liquid waterproofing, caulking compound and pointing materials ........................................... $750.00

**Painting Materials**

- Painting Materials .................................................. 200.00

**Scaffolding Materials and accessories**

- Scaffolding Materials and accessories ......................... 179.00

**Expendable Sundries**

- Brushes, paint pails, trowels, chisels cleaning materials, etc. ........................................... 100.00

**Estimated Total**

- Estimated Total .................................................... $1229.00

If a spray painting unit is not available for rental when required, add ........................................... $250.00
Owing to Minwax having been used already on parts of the buildings at Alert Bay and the satisfactory results obtained to date, it is recommended that Minwax should be utilized for the proposed work.

The waterproofing work should be started not later than June 1st, and should be completed by the end of July, while painting could be carried on until September 15th.

With regard to labour it is probable that all labour, including a foreman for the work, may have to be obtained in Vancouver, due to the absence of local labour during the fishing season.

In this connection I may say that labour and other costs on the work, which it is understood will be carried out during the 1941-42 fiscal year, are estimated to be approximately as follows:

Labour for waterproofing ............. $1,550.00
Labour for painting .................... 650.00
Contingencies, engineering, etc. ..... 300.00

Estimated total 1941-42 .............. $2,500.00

You will observe that the materials to be provided from funds available during the current fiscal year, together with expenditures for carrying out the work next fiscal year, are estimated to cost approximately $2,980.00.

It would be appreciated if we were advised as soon as possible whether the above work will be undertaken this summer so we can arrange accordingly.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find Voucher No.263 in the amount of $42.05 in favour of Evans, Coleman & Evans, Limited of Vancouver, for materials for repairs to Left Hand Boiler No.44262 at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

In this connection, Principal Anfield reported difficulty with this boiler in April last, which was taken up with the Department, and at that time we were advised the Boiler Inspector would look into the matter upon his annual inspection. On November 2nd Mr.T.J. Arnall was here, and recommended "pit walls and floor are to be bricked up to protect metal sides".

Owing to the necessity of having the work done immediately, Principal Anfield went ahead on his own and purchased the material without obtaining authority from the Department, but the work has now been done and as I feel it is an account which the Department should pay, I am passing the voucher and would kindly ask that it be approved and paid by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Dear Mr Todd,

Further to our conversation of today's date in consideration of Mr Hoey's letter to you, file 156-0-5, of March 6th, last; and of the Commissioners letter to you, file 15-6-524 of Feb. 22nd last, with enclosed report and recommendation of Mr W.G. Warren of the Survey and Engineering Branch and your reply thereto under date of March 5th, I have given this matter very careful thought and have made a thorough study of the report submitted by Mr Warren.

To accept Mr Hoey's suggestion would involve a tacit responsibility for any work done and this I am unable to do. The problem of waterproofing this building is an extremely difficult one and I have not enough technical knowledge to see that the recommendations made by Mr Warren are properly carried out. If however, the point of responsibility is not raised at all and the matter approached from a strictly financial angle I would estimate the cost of labour as far beyond the absorbable possibilities of the School per capita grants and I could not conscientiously recommend such an expenditure to the I.R.S. Commission, M.S.C., as much as they and the writer would like to be of assistance to the Department. Most expenditures at this school are in the nature of fixed charges. The children have to be fed, clothed, kept warm and healthy. With increased costs and diminishing returns due to the cut, an almost irreducible minimum of maintenance cost has been reached. The only fluid budget head is that of salaries and the per capita cuts forced a reduction in these to a point where staff members are receiving $27.50 per month with maintenance, and doing up to fourteen or more hours a day.

Mr Warren's labour cost on the proposed work totalled $1500.00 approx: for the brick work only. To do the painting required, a further item for labour totalling $630.00 approx: was noted; a sum total of $2130.00 to be expended on labour. Mr Warren's report showed a total material cost of $1398.00 approx: which Mr Hoey's letter has reduced to $750.00 of available funds. Reduced proportionately the $2130.00 labour cost would amount to $1225.00 to be put up by the school authority, presumably from per capita grants. Should our I.R.S. Commission have such a surplus available, I would feel compelled to make a very strong appeal that it be utilized to increase the reduced salaries of the staff and to restore or implement courses that the cuts in per capita grants have necessitated.

Under the circumstances, I cannot support Mr Hoey's suggestion.

Sincerely yours,

Principal.
Mr. F. EARL ANFIELD  
Principal

The Indian Agent,  
Alert Bay, B.C.

Dear Mr Todd:

Further to correspondence from Mr Hoey, in which it was suggested that the School authority might assist in the cost of waterproofing the School; and stating that the sum of $1075.00 only would be available for all the Departmental needs of the School; it would seem imperative that the Department should be informed without delay that the following items will have to be taken care of this summer without fail, if valuable property is to be maintained in efficient order.

(1) Main boilers will require new smoke boxes, hoods and all new metal stacking. Present equipment is paper thin and can be punched through anywhere. Furnace gases are leaking badly into boiler room. Estimated cost $200.00, though exact cost is now being secured from the makers of the boilers.

(2) Pomona deep well pump has been in operation II years without a cent of expense to the Department. Increasing loss of water and wobbling in head are proof that this pump must be pulled this summer, without fail, and new impellers, bearing and bronze seats installed. Estimate to hand for parts $148.00 f.o.b. Vancouver. The School would do the work.

(3) Lighting plant engines must have new cylinder heads and perhaps new pistons. These engines have operated II years without a stop of any kind. Estimated needs for parts $350.00 at least.

There are other urgent needs, but the three jobs mentioned herewith are imperative if the plant is to continue operating. We must have heat, water and light if the school is to function at all. I mention this with the very definite hope that the funds available will be apportioned to take care of the above.

Sincerely yours,

Principal.
Ottawa,
April 7, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith application of Mr. Indian Agent Todd, dated March 29, 1941, to expend $100.00 for labour and, in addition, purchase material for repair of the intake pipe of the fire protection pump at Alert Bay Indian Residential School, the cost of material being estimated by the Dominion Water and Power Bureau to cost $32.00 as per attached requisition, a total of $132.00, assuming that labour costs will amount to that estimated, which I presume is a maximum estimate.

These repairs have become necessary owing to the fact that some seagoing craft or log boom has become entangled with that part of the pipe line on or below the foreshore, dragging the pipe out of line and thereby breaking the leaded joints, consequently it will be necessary to realign the pipe and recaulk the joints, which Mr. Todd considers can be done by local labour without the necessity of supervision by the engineers of the Water and Power Bureau, the latter concurring with this proposal.

As the school is meanwhile without fire protection from this pump, I would recommend approval of the application, and request that if at all possible authority be granted to proceed with the work as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

For D. M. MacKay,

Dear Mr. Todd,

Further to our conversation of today's date re the work needed to put the fire pump intake back into proper condition, I would confirm the following requirements:

a/ Labour.— approx. $100.00. This would be contingent entirely on tidal conditions permitting the work of leading points to be completed.

b/ A joint leading outfit with sufficient lead to take care of two or three joints should others be strained. This could be obtained, I presume, through the Water Power Branch in Vancouver.

c/ New holding cables to replace those broken. The specifications and cost of these should be on file in the W.P. Branch in Vancouver and this new cable could likely be purchased from their office and shipped direct. Cable clamps should be included.

It should be borne in mind very distinctly that skilled local labour is a very limited matter and if in pulling these pipes into place, weakened joints should break, the whole intake will have to be floated out. Such a job should be in charge of an engineer in my opinion.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

Sir,

Replying to Departmental letter of March 6th last, No.186-95, in which you request information in connection with repairs and improvements to the Alert Bay Residential School, I beg to advise I have gone into this matter very carefully with Principal Anfield, and I enclose herewith copy of his reply which will be self-explanatory.

I also enclose a further letter from Principal Anfield in which he points out some items which are necessary to be attended to this year which amount to approximately Seven Hundred Dollars.

It would therefore appear impossible for the Department to undertake the necessary work as well as purchase the waterproofing material for the school even if it were possible for the School to provide funds to take care of the labour. Under the circumstances, it is difficult for me to recommend to the Department what action should be taken in respect to the waterproofing of the school.

I agree with Principal Anfield that the work to be done on the school should be done by an expert, as this has always been considered such by our engineers. In my opinion we should not spend any further money for experimenting on the walls of this school, but rather realise we have got to face a situation that exists and definitely provide sufficient funds to have the work done which would be of a permanent nature.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your letter of May 6th enclosing requisition for two sets of smoke boxes and hoods complete, together with all pipes and connections for main and H.P. boilers at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, and copies of correspondence relating thereto.

No provision whatever was made in the Estimates of recent years for this expenditure. In 1938-39 an item of $72 for new hoods and stove pipes for the main boilers was included in a list of requirements forwarded by Mr. Anfield. The Estimates for your Agency, however, were late in arriving here on that occasion. Consequently, the requirements of your Agency had to be made up in this office based on the former year's submission and no provision could be made for the item of $72 referred to.

In Mr. Arnall's report of November 12, 1940, reference is made to the smoke pipe and breaching being thin, but no recommendation for replacement was made.

There is no doubt that the appropriation for such services has been severely cut and if replacement of these hoods is not an urgent necessity it might be well to provide for same in your forthcoming estimates. Otherwise, the expenditure, if approved, will undoubtedly be made from the reduced amount set aside for St. Michael's for this fiscal year.

Please consult Mr. Anfield and let me have your reply at the earliest possible date, when, if necessary, the matter will be referred to the Department for consideration.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Todd:

Attached please find bids from two firms on a portable bake oven for this School. An item to cover this was included in last year's estimates.

As you are aware, our bake oven installed when the School was built, collapsed completely over a year ago, and since then it has been quite a struggle to get by with the large amount of baking required in a school of this size. It was agreed that we should not ask for this bake oven last year as the Department installed a new kitchen range at that time, but there is a very real need for this equipment this year.

The #2 Economy quoted f.o.b. Alert Bay by Marshall Wells @ $192.94 would be ample for our needs and with the range put in last year, would complete our kitchen requirements for many years to come.

Thanking you,

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Todd:

Further to our conversation re the hot-water heating boiler at this School, attached please find copies of letters received from Patterson Boiler Works, makers of this boiler. It is noted that they recommend the boiler should be sent down for retubing and that the cost would be from $35.00 to $40.00. To this would be added freight charges both ways and cartage in Vancouver.

This boiler has never given satisfaction at this School and were it not for the coils in the main heating boilers, we would be hard pressed to get adequate hot water for our requirements.

However, in view of the urgent need of a hot water heater, I would recommend that this equipment be sent down for prompt retubing, testing and return.

Your assistance and recommendation will be greatly appreciated.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 17th inst. The cost of a new set of tubes for your hot water heater would be about $10.00.

However we believe it would be advisable for you to send the boiler here and have it retubed, as in all probability it will require retubing throughout. The cost of retubing same complete and testing would be about $35.00 to $40.00.

We hardly think your local machinist could make a satisfactory job, as tubes have to be expanded in and not welded.

Yours very truly,

Patterson Boiler Works Ltd.

Per C.D.P.
Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith a copy of a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Todd requesting that certain repairs be made to the hot water heater at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, together with copies of letters from Mr. Anfield and the Patterson Boiler Works Ltd., relating to the matter. This boiler was supplied by the Department to the school in 1938 at a cost of $328.00 - refer your P.O. 8392 and E.R. 1770.

Although Mr. Anfield states in his letter of April 22nd, addressed to Mr. Todd that "this boiler has never given satisfaction at the school", no previous complaint regarding the boiler was made to this office. The Patterson Boiler Works supplied the unit and it is just possible that the Principal may have had some correspondence with this Company on the subject.

As immediate repairs are necessary I would recommend that the Department approve of having the boiler sent to the Patterson Boiler Works and that the cost involved be paid either from school funds or charged to the allotment to this school for maintenance of equipment for the current fiscal year.

A reply by air mail would be appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

The enclosed copy of letter received from Principal Anfield, will be self-explanatory.

For your information, this boiler was purchased by the Department three years ago, and in my opinion should have given longer service than it has; however as it is an emergency repair job, I would recommend that authority be granted at once for the boiler to be shipped to Vancouver and the necessary repairs made as the school are finding it difficult to carry on without a sufficient hot water supply.

Would you kindly advise me by return mail whether Principal Anfield may ship the boiler to Vancouver for the repairs required, the accounts to be forwarded to this office for payment.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of August 11th last, file 156-0-5, I beg to advise you Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., is apparently confused in the correspondence received from Principal Anfield of St. Michael's School.

Apparently Dr. Westgate is referring to Principal Anfield's letter of July 1st last dealing with his Estimates for 1943-44, which were included with ours and which are now at the Indian Commissioner's office for his attention. This letter of Mr. Anfield's gives a list of requirements for the school for that period, but which are not required at the present time.

In Departmental letter No.156-0-5 of June 17th last, you pointed out there were certain funds available for the school for the current year, and advising out of the $1,750 approved, an expenditure of approximately $120.00 had been made. In this connection, our records only show that one voucher, amounting to $84.68, has been spent, and I would appreciate if you would kindly advise me what the $120.00 represents.

In the appropriations approved for the current year, it is the desire of Principal Anfield and myself to keep these to a minimum. We have gone over the various items requested, and have decided it is necessary to ask for the one item of $894.00 for a hot water tank, but this cannot be done until such time as the Boiler Inspector arrives and makes his recommendations, giving the necessary information to meet the requirements. Just when Mr. Arnall will be able to let us have this we are not sure, as he has informed us he cannot make his annual inspection for a short time yet. I might add the cost of equipment has increased, and no doubt the amount of $894.00 asked for will have in all probability, to be increased to $1,000.00.

In addition to this there will be only one other small item of expenditure requested, particulars regarding which will be forwarded shortly.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

Dear Sir:

I have received an application from Mr. Indian Agent Todd for authority to expend the sum of $38.15 for cement, lime, brick and galvanized thimbles, to construct a chimney in the classroom block of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

This construction is now required due to the difficulty in securing fuel oil for the oil heaters at present in use in the building, and the necessity of installing wood-burning heaters in replacement. The alternative would be the installation of a large wood-burning furnace which is out of the question at the present time.

I would recommend that this expenditure be approved and would appreciate the Department's decision by airmail.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,

Dear Major MacKay:

On today's mail I received notification as Chairman, Civilian Protection Committee, Alert Bay, that effective February 1st, 1943 "Dim-out" regulations for District "B", in which Alert Bay is situated, go into effect. Put briefly this compels us to blackout all lighting that faces the sea, and this is going to be a problem as far as material is concerned. This dim-out will be for the duration, and it means that we will have to put in permanent shields with ventilating facilities for all our dormitories, and class rooms, as these will have to be put in at sunset and removed each morning day after day by Indian children. For such permanent blackout, only Veneer is suitable, though it need not be of #1 Grade. We have already installed three thousand feet for blackout purposes, but in our class rooms, and dormitories we had tar paper shields on wooden frames, figuring that at the worst we would only have occasional need to use them. These must now be changed, and for these 84 windows we will require 1700 square feet of 5 ply Veneer or suitable equivalent, in sheets 10' x 4'.

For your information, the school paid from grants the cost of all blackout material purchased up to this time. Now that almost as much again will be required, I am compelled to ask the Department for help in supplying this material. Mr. Indian Agent Todd is away at Campbell River, and I understand will not be back for at least a week or so, otherwise this matter would have gone through his office in the regular way. We have very little time until February 1st, as we have to construct ventilating shields in every second window to be covered.

Your favourable consideration to the purchase and supply of this material at an early date will be greatly appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Todd:

Answering yours of April 29th, in connection with certain items in Inspector Manning's report on this School. It is necessary to report as follows:

1. The dormitory doors are locked at night for the protection of the children from outside marauders, and from the danger of the children getting in the stair-wells in the event of fire. All the dormitories are equipped with electric buzzers, and are in charge of responsible senior pupils, who can call staff members in the event of sickness and other needs during the night. We have had more than one instance of outside Indians getting into this building and into the girls' dormitories at night. I would recommend that panic-bolts approved by the Fire Underwriters Association be placed on the fire escape doors in all these dormitories.

2. The question of continuing the services of the present senior class room teacher, Mr. Hannlow, in the coming Fall Term, is a matter that must be referred to the Commission in Winnipeg, from whose Offices all Staff appointments are made. I shall place this file before them, with a report, and they will in due course advise me of any decision made. The writer is aware of the unsatisfactory condition of this particular class room, and the necessity for a change in the teaching personnel thereof.

3. Regarding the frame building in which the senior classes are carried on. Re: Indian Residential School - Alert Bay, B.C.

On looking over the voluminous stack of correspondence regarding the Fresh Water Pumps and Diesel Engines at the Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C., I cannot see that Mr. Anfield could do anything other than ask for prices for the repair of this Engine.

In my report, dated November 2nd, 1940, I recommended that the cylinder be re bored and new piston fitted and that the pump be drawn from the well and overhauled.

On my next visit to the school, September 10th, 1941, I was informed that the pump and engine had been overhauled and were in good condition.

On my visit to the School, October 22nd and 23rd, 1942, the engine was started up in my presence with no trouble and the exhaust was practically clear. There was a slight pin-knock, but not enough to cause any serious trouble. There is a possibility that after six months' operation, this knock has developed further.

I can quite understand Mr. Anfield's position in this matter, which he has discussed with me on several occasions. The whole school depends on this deep well for its whole domestic water supply and should the engine or pump give out, a very serious situation will develop.

This pump and engine should at all times be kept in the best of condition, or, better, a duplicate unit be purchased and installed.

The price quoted by the Reliance Motor Works appears quite reasonable. Of course, there might be some other minor repairs needed, but from what I saw of the engine last fall, I do not think any will be required. However, what might have developed during the last six months I am not in a position to say, but for reasons given will emphasize that both pump and engine be kept in first-class condition.

Dear Mr. Todd:

Further to our conversation of today's date, it is noted that an item for $1250.00 approximately has been included in the estimates sanctioned for the purchase of a furnace for the Classroom block, formerly the Girls Home.

Following the condemnation of the steam heating plant formerly in use in this building, oil stoves were purchased by the Department, and installed in the classrooms. No heat was provided for the hallways or store rooms used in this building. A year ago there was a distinct possibility that no further oil supplies would be available and two small wood stoves were purchased by the Department should oil fuel be cut off. At present only two classrooms are used in this building, but some 8 or 10 other rooms are used as store rooms of various kinds.

At the recent inspection of this School, this building was condemned as a fire trap, and should oil supplies be cut off, the fire risk in this building would be even more enhanced by the use of small box stoves, and I would be most unwilling to sanction their use at all.

It is presumed that the $1250.00 sanctioned is for a hot-air furnace on which a bid was received from the Nimkish Sheet Metal Co. some two years ago. This bid included equipment to heat three classrooms, and the main hallways. Apart from the actual furnace the job would be a sheet metal project, and the hot and cold air vents would have to be constructed and fitted into the building as it is at present.

From the point of view of fire risk such a hot-air furnace would be a good safety measure, though it should be remembered that the building is condemned and that it will be likely torn down as soon as wartime conditions permit.

Dear Mr. Todd:—

With reference our conversation about fire protection at the classroom block of this School, it is necessary to advise as follows:

1. We recognize that this building is a fire trap, but consider that unless it is immediately demolished it is safer to keep it in use.

2. The building is kept under constant supervision by day and by night, and is kept locked when classrooms are not in session.

3. Regular drills are carried out from the building, which can be emptied during school hours in a couple of minutes.

4. There are two hydrant houses within 50 yards of this block; the hoses are kept coupled at all times to the hydrant, and there is a constant supply of water in the lines.

It is recognized that we could hardly save the building should it catch fire, but with the protection mentioned herewith I think we could manage to keep it from spreading to other parts of the plant, including the main school.

Dear Mr. Todd:

As you are aware, our unloading wharf was destroyed last winter in a heavy south-east gale. No request was made for replacement as the labour situation in Alert Bay was becoming more hopeless each year and it was almost impossible to get men to unload the scows of slabs on the wharf. The Telegraph Cove people, from whom we purchase our fuel supply (600 cords of slabs per year) were of the opinion that they could put in an unloading derrick at Sharpe's boat shop and they spent considerable money trying to work this out. We brought in two test scow loads and we find that the cost of unloading and hauling is exactly double the previous system and as the handling of the derrick will require at least four men I have abandoned the idea entirely.

The only solution is a grid at the site of the previous School dock on which the scow can be placed and a truck run right onto same and slabs loaded thereon by the driver, requiring only one man.

I have been trying to get the pile driver man for over two months, but unsuccessfully until this week, when he arrived with the driver to do some work at the Cannery. As we were down to less than a month's supply of slabs, I have instructed him to proceed at once to put in this grid and have secured the necessary material from Telegraph Cove. The driving will cost approx. $100.00 less materials, 22 piles, 6 heavy cross timbers, drift bolts etc.

Would it be asking too much for the Department to make a grant of $100.00 towards this job and we will absorb the balance through School grants. I realise this is not the regular way to do this, but had to get action on this problem at once, as the driver may not be back for months and we must get 500 cords of slabs piled this summer without fail in order to have reasonably dry fuel for the winter.
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.

Your help in this will be appreciated. In the meantime we shall have to pay the cost and hope that the grant requested can be used as a refund.

Thanking you,

Sincerely yours,

Principal.

I enclose you, herewith, correspondence which has taken place over the erection of a Grid built on the foreshore in front of St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, B. C.

I regret very much to have to place this whole matter before the department, particularly since Principal Anfield has been appointed Indian Agent of Bella Coola, but in view of the circumstances under which this Grid was built, I have no alternative since Principal Anfield has forwarded me his letter of October 1st, 1943 enclosing an account apparently assumed on behalf of the Residential School, and asked that I place the matter before the department. As this whole matter was irregular from its inception, it is necessary for me to go into detail so that the department will know exactly what has taken place from the beginning.

In the month of October, 1941, Principal Anfield informed me it was too costly to handle their slab wood by unloading it on the school dock which the department had rebuilt at a cost of Two Hundred Twenty-Five Dollars ($225.00) a short time previous to this at the request of Principal Anfield, for this purpose, and asked if I thought the department would object to a Grid being built on the foreshore alongside the dock by the Telegraph Cove Mills for this purpose.

At that time Principal Anfield stated the Grid would be completed by the Telegraph Cove Mills and the School at no cost to the department, as it was to their interests to find a cheaper way of handling their fuel. It seemed it would benefit both the Telegraph Cove Mills and the School as Mr. Anfield was purchasing the slabs from them, and it was for this reason that they planned discarding the wharf provided by the department for this use and building a Grid in its place.

I informed Mr. Anfield at the time that as it was only a matter of providing a very few piles and the placing of a few timbers to rest the scow on, that I did not think the department would have any objections; but as Mr. Anfield made no application for permission to be forwarded to the department in order to obtain their approval for the building of this Grid, no action was taken in the matter.

During the month of December 1941 while I was in hospital in Vancouver, a very severe storm struck Alert Bay with the result that the wharf which we had only recently rebuilt was taken out entirely and allowed to drift away. After I returned to duty and was able to get around I noticed the wharf was missing and asked Mr. Anfield what
had happened. He informed me of the circumstances and at the same time told me he and Fred Wastell of the Telegraph Cove Mills arranged with Mr. Goodrow to put in a Grid, but made no mention of the department paying for same.

On June 13th, 1942 I received the enclosed letter from Principal Anfield, in which you will please note he asked at that time for the department to make a grant towards the work of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00), and further stated "In the meantime we shall have to pay the cost and hope that the grant requested can be used as a refund".

Knowing the circumstances from the beginning that it was the intention of the Telegraph Cove Mills and Principal Anfield to build this Grid and arrange for the wood in order that their costs could be recouped, I informed Principal Anfield that as the department had not been consulted and their permission and authority obtained, I could not consider placing it before Ottawa with the recommendation that this be paid.

On June 24, 1943, Mr. Goodrow came to my office and told me Fred Wastell had informed him the Government was paying for the building of the Grid. I asked Mr. Goodrow who had employed him and what arrangements he had, and was informed as follows. He stated Fred Wastell of the Telegraph Cove Mills employed him to build this Grid for them and that they would pay for same as it was being used for their benefit in getting the scows unloaded quicker and less costly. Mr. Goodrow also informed me that Principal Anfield at the Residential School had nothing to do with it in any way and that it was entirely Telegraph Cove Mills' responsibility, and that he was looking to the Telegraph Cove Mills for payment.

Since the Grid was built the R.C.A.F. have taken over the Telegraph Cove Mills and they are now supplying wood to the Residential School and through this new arrangement the Telegraph Cove Mills have no further use for the Grid.

The department can draw their own conclusions from the above information and why the Government is now being asked to pay for this Grid. You will also please note in the statement submitted by Principal Anfield the price has now gone up from One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) to One Hundred Fifty Dollars ($150.00).

As stated above the whole procedure has been irregular and it appears to me the parties responsible for the building of this Grid are now trying to get the department to pay for something which they have no right to do so. I regret very much that Principal Anfield has associated himself with a deal of this kind, but as stated above I have no alternative but to submit same to the Department and recommend against any payment being made or the account being honoured in any respect. In my opinion it is the responsibility of the Telegraph Cove Mills who Mr. Goodrow states employed him to do this work and stated they would pay him for same.

(M.S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

Under date of December 29th last Rev. S. J. Wickens, Principal of St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, came to me reporting the vertical high pressure steam boiler in the school, used by the laundry and kitchen, had blown several more tubes out, and upon further examination found it necessary to re-tube the boiler.

As the school was in session it was necessary that immediate action be taken to get this equipment operating at the earliest possible moment, and I instructed Mr. Wickens to purchase, if possible, the necessary tubes at once. This action was taken by myself rather than wait to refer the matter to Ottawa as I felt this was what the department would expect me to do in an emergency of this nature. I also felt that with the shortage of materials it might be possible that we could not obtain them immediately, and the sooner the order was placed the sooner the equipment would be back in operation.

We were fortunate in obtaining these tubes immediately, which were supplied by the firm who sold us the boiler originally. I enclose you, herewith, voucher #300, covering the cost of same, and would recommend that it be paid as submitted.

(Ms. S. Todd)

Dear Mr. Todd:

I regret to report that our vertical high pressure steam boiler is out of commission.

We have had two or three individual tubes plugged in the past because of leakage, but yesterday a group of tubes blew out. The expert examination by a master mechanic revealed that all the tubes, numbering 67, are due for renewal. This boiler was installed in 1935; the first burst occurred in 1942 and an overhaul was to be expected.

As a result of the closing down of its operation, the dryer in our laundry is affected, as well as the steamer in our kitchen.

It would be appreciated if you would authorize the renewal of all of the tubes and provide for such work to be done at the earliest opportunity.

I am, yours very truly,

S. J. Wickers,
Principal.

March 31st, 1944.

Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B. C.

Recently I requested you to purchase a Circulator Heater for the Alert Bay Indian Day School and was informed that there were none available in Vancouver.

Today I am informed by the Manager of the B. C. Packers Ltd., Alert Bay, that they have a Circulator Heater of the type we require for the School, and are willing to sell same to the Department for Fifty Dollars ($50.00) cash. The Company has agreed to hold this stove for a week until I can obtain word from you as to whether the department will purchase this Circulator Wood Heater.

As we need this stove very badly I would appreciate if you would authorize the purchase of same; as I do not like the present fire hazard to continue any longer than necessary.

Kindly advise me by return mail if we may obtain this stove from the B. C. Packers Ltd.

"M. S. Todd"

I am forwarding herewith Voucher No.60A, for 55¢ in favor of McLennan, McFeely and Prior, Ltd., Vancouver, with reference to prepaid freight charges on a carton of Corbin Exit Bolts (Panic Bolts) for the doors leading from the dormitories to the fire escapes at Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

Kwawkewlth Agency Voucher No.349, covering the cost of the bolts, at $92.00, and freight at 55¢, was received here from Mr. Indian Agent Todd. We asked the company for the receipted freight bill on March 17th and received it only today. In the meantime, in order to expedite payment of the larger amount, we forwarded Voucher No.349 to the Department with the amount of the freight struck off.

It is noted that the invoice is dated February 15th while the Union Steamships Ltd., have stamped the Bill of Lading that they received the 55¢ on April 8th. It is recommend that this amount be paid from last year's appropriation although the receipt is dated April 8th. It has been explained by merchants previously, at Vancouver, that they have charge accounts with the transportation companies and frequently pay the prepaid freight charges on several shipments at the end of the month in a lump sum. When they ask for separate receipts on an individual shipment, the company stamps on the date on which the receipt is secured.

Voucher No.60-A was prepared in this office, because of the time that would elapse, if we sent the receipt to Mr. Todd and waited until the voucher was prepared in his office and returned to Vancouver.

I desire to refer you to Mr. Hoey's letter of May 4, 1942, in connection with the impossibility of securing a temperature regulating valve for the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

I now enclose, for your information, a letter dated January 22, received from the Canadian Powers Regulator Company, Limited, together with their catalogues Nos. 229 and 258. Philip Phelan,

January 29, 1945.

Memorandum

Mr. R.A.Hoey

On January 22nd, 1943, we placed an order with Crane Limited, Victoria, B.C., for a hot water storage tank and accessories recommended by Commissioner Mackay for the Indian Residential School at Alert Bay, B.C. Due to priority restrictions in effect at the time, Crane Limited, could not supply the fifth item on the order calling for one Powers temperature regulating valve at $130.00. Inquiries regarding possibility of securing this item were subsequently made, but without success in locating a source of supply.

We recently received from the Canadian Powers Regulator Co. Ltd., Toronto, Ontario, the enclosed letter and bulletins numbers 229 and 258, describing their #11 regulator and # C40 thermostatic water controller which they offer at $123.12 and $187.25 respectively, f.o.b. Toronto. It is noted that they recommend the higher priced equipment as more satisfactory.

Will you kindly advise what action, if any, you wish taken in this matter, returning vendor's letter and bulletins with your reply.

Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B.C.

Enclosed please find requisition covering emergency purchase of fire hose, couplings, etc., for use at St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C.

Recently at a fire drill, it was discovered that considerable hose had deteriorated to the extent that when under water pressure the hose was bursting. I, therefore, instructed Principal Wickens to obtain tenders for same, as I consider in the interests of protection for the school, that this should be replaced at once.

In checking up my estimates I find that no provision was made by the School for this replacement, therefore, the funds may have to be supplied from some other request which has not been used up.

It would be appreciated if you would give this your early attention as I am somewhat worried over this situation existing longer than necessary.

The Powers No. 11 Regulator

Type and Use
This is a self-operating regulator for the control of liquid temperatures in either heating or cooling operations. It is of rugged construction and has been designed to give years of service with a minimum of expense.

It may be used on steam heated hot water tanks, vats, kettles, dye machines, bleach tubs, pickling vats, acid baths, plating tanks, fuel oil preheaters, milk can and bottle coolers, sugar juice heaters, feed water heaters, Diesel oil preheating vats, sewage treaters, digesters, etc. It may also be used to control liquids used as cooling mediums in drinking water systems, jet condensers, etc. See page 11 for typical applications.

Construction and Operation
The No. 11 Regulator is of all metal construction, simple in design, and easy to install. Its thermostatic bulb contains a sensitive fluid, hermetically sealed, which generates a pressure in proportion to the temperature of the liquid in contact with the bulb. This pressure is conducted through the flexible connecting tubing to the all metal bellows diaphragm in the operating head, which responds by gradually closing or opening the valve to maintain the desired temperature.

Temperature Range and Adjustment
The No. 11 Regulator is furnished standard for any specified operating temperature between the limits of 60° and 250° F. It can be furnished in sizes ¼-inch to 3½-inch, inclusive, where frequent and accurate resetting is necessary, a dial adjustment regulator (page 5) is recommended. Regulators for operation between 40° and 60° F are furnished with spring and collar adjustment only. A lock for the spring and collar adjustment feature can be provided at extra cost.

Types of Valves
The No. 11 Regulator is furnished standard with a direct acting (spring opened) valve for the control of heating mediums. For the control of cooling mediums it is furnished with a reverse acting (spring closed) valve. It may also be furnished with a three-way valve for mixing hot and cold water or for diverting the flow of a heating or cooling medium (see page 6).

Valve Construction (See figure 8)
The ¼-inch and ½-inch valves are made of steam bronze and are of the low pressure single seat composition globe pattern with double unions. Sizes ¾-inch to 1½-inch, inclusive, are made of steam bronze and are of the double-seated balanced type with double unions. Where steam pressures permit, they can also be furnished in the double union single seat composition disc type.

High Steam Pressures
When the pressure of the steam to be controlled is above 75 pounds, stainless steel trimmed valves are recommended. For steam pressures above 200 pounds or for total steam temperatures above 500° F., steel valves with stainless steel seats and poppets must be used.

When so ordered the Powers No. 11 regulator can be safeguarded for a specified over-run in temperature.

Extension Bonnet
When the regulator is to be fitted at a temperature below 200° F. or if the valve is to be insulated where moisture may accumulate and freeze on the packing gland and valve stem, an extension bonnet is recommended. The use of this extension bonnet also permits a neater job of pipe covering.

Thermostatic Bulb
The standard bulb is made of copper and is for use in water and other non-corrosive liquids. For corrosive solutions or gases, a bulb of special material can be supplied (at extra cost) when full information is given regarding the corrosive agent, its concentration, and the temperature at which the solution is to be maintained.

The standard bulb has a pipe thread tank bushing and retainer nut and a straight flexible tubing connection (see figures 1 and 2); a flange connection will be substituted when required. Bulbs of special design can be furnished if required; a sketch and complete details should accompany requests for prices. Figures 4 and 5 on page 4 show two special bulbs.

Separable Well
To permit removal of the bulb without draining the tank, vat or pipe line, a separable well or socket can be supplied at extra cost but its use retards the action of the regulator to some extent. Where temperature changes are quite slow the interference offered by a well is negligible, but where accurate indication is required and temperature changes are fairly rapid a well should not be used.
Wet Bulb Control

By covering the bulb of the No. 11 Regulator with a wick kept saturated in an overhead or automatic water pan, the No. 11 Regulator may be used as a wet bulb instrument. A chromium plated style W bulb will be furnished for this service. If the dry bulb is to be mounted on the water pan it should be of the same type of construction. This has an insulating bushing which decreases heat transfer.

Flexible Tubing

Standard flexible tubing is made of copper with bronze protective sheathing. Standard lengths are shown in the price list on page 10 and in the tables of dimensions on page 9; additional lengths may be had at extra cost. Tubing is available to resist the corrosion action of various chemicals can also be specified. Another tubing with nickel finish will resist mild acid fumes. Smooth bendable monel or stainless steel tubing can also be furnished, but the best protection for tubing is lead sheathing (see Item 26 and 30 in the price list).

The No. 11 Regulator can be furnished without flexible tubing. It is then identified as the Powers No. 11 Regulator and is described in Bulletin No. 241.

Cautions

To prevent results the steam pressure should be kept constant and as low as possible.

To prolong the life of the regulator and prevent temperature variations due to dirt or sediment lodging between the valve disc and seat, a self-cleaning strainer should be installed in the supply line to the valve. If the steam contains a large amount of moisture or condensate, a steam trap should be installed just ahead of the regulator. See page 7 for strainers and Bulletin No. 253 for traps.

The Powers Dial Adjustment No. 11 Regulator

Type and Use

This regulator is of the same design and construction as the Powers standard No. 11 Regulator (pages 2 to 4), except that it is provided with dial adjustment to facilitate changing the temperature setting over close limits. The use of different style thermostatic bulbs (see figures 9 to 12 below) also makes the regulator suitable for the control of atmospheric, liquid, wet bulb and dew point temperatures.

This regulator may also be furnished with an indicating thermometer mounted on the operating head.

Valve Construction (See page 4)

The regulator is made in valve sizes ¼-inch, ½-inch, ¾-inch and 1½-inch only. It is furnished standard with a valve seat of double and single seat pattern, and can be had in the direct acting (spring opened), reverse acting (spring closed), or three-way type. In the three-way pattern the bottom port is screwed.

Temperature Range and Adjustment

The regulator is furnished standard for a specified operating temperature between the limits of 60° and 250°F, and has a range of adjustment of approximately 20°. To obtain this range and to permit ease of adjustment and accurate resetting, a fine pitch scale is used. As six complete turns of the adjustment knob are required to cover the entire temperature band, two scales are provided: a vernier scale marked numerically, A to G, inclusive; and a circular dial (marked off in five divisions). After the regulator is installed, it may be calibrated and dial readings recorded with these separate temperature scales. This makes it possible to easily reset the regulator for any predetermined temperature.

The Powers No. 11 Regulator with Three-Way Valve

Type and Use
The regulator is designed to mix hot and cold water and deliver the mixture at a constant temperature. It is used for supplying tempered water to wash sinks and basins, for mixing brine in evaporators, industrial processes, etc. It is also used for mixing or diverting the flow of brine in cooling operations. It is not intended for shower use.

Valve Construction (See page 8)
Sizes 1/2-inch to 2-inch, inclusive, have bronze bodies with screwed connections. Sizes 3/4-inch to 1 1/2-inch, inclusive, can also be furnished with union connection and flanged ends. Sizes 1-inch to 2 1/2-inch and 3-inch have iron bodies with screwed connection on all three ports, but can be furnished with flanged side and screwed end connections, at an extra cost. Valves are flanged on all three ports and tempered at extra cost in sizes 2 1/2-inch to 4-inch. Sizes 3/4-inch and up have vanes fitted with special skirted design to prevent "hunting."

Extension Bonnet
When the regulator is to control at a temperature below 20° F, or if the valve is to be installed where moisture may accumulate and freeze on the packing gland and valve stem, an extension bonnet is recommended. The use of this extension bonnet also permits a neater job of pipe covering.

Temperature Range and Adjustment
The standard regulator is furnished for an operating temperature of 140° F, and has an adjustment range of approximately 20° above and below this point. Any other 40° range between 60° and 200° F can be further specified, at no additional cost. It can be furnished in sizes 1/2-inch to 2 1/2-inch, inclusive, for operation between 40° and 200° F, at extra cost.

Water Pressure
For best results the hot and cold water pressures must be approximately equal. If one pressure is considerably higher than the other, a suitable reducing valve must be used (see Bulletin No. 256).

Cautions
Check valves should always be installed in both supply lines to prolong the life of the regulator and prevent temperature variations due to dirt or sediment lodging between the valve disc and seat. Self-cleaning strainers should be installed in both supply lines to the regulator (see Bulletin No. 256). Whenever possible regulator should be installed in a mixing position in preference to diverting.

Powers Safety Shower Mixers

(Pressure Equalizing Valve Type)

With the simple turn of only one handle, this Powers mixer automatically delivers a shower unsurpassed in comfort.

Because of its simplicity, rugged construction, safety and economy, it is used widely in residences, hotels, hospitals, and especially on showers subjected to moderate or heavy use, as in clubs, colleges and universities, schools, public baths, institutions and industrial plants. It is unequalled for heavy duty.

Comfort and Safety Features

Pressure Equalizing Valve (Figure 3-140). Without this important feature a Powers mixer would be simply another shower mixer. This valve is a floating piston which controls and equalizes the mixture of hot and cold water before they enter the mixing chamber.

It safeguards the bather from scalding and annoying temperature changes caused by pressure variations in supply lines due to use of nearby showers, faucets and flush valves. It substantially shuts off hot water if cold water supply fails.

Safety Stop Screw (Figure 2-140). This screw can be used to limit the delivery temperature of the shower, thereby preventing the possibility of scalding caused by a "dead end" in the hot water supply.

Check Valves (Figure 5-140) are built into both inlets to prevent backsiphonage or interchanging of hot and cold water.

Economies—While the first cost of Powers Mixers is higher than that of hand valves and most mechanical mixers, their many advantages make them a much more profitable investment.

By providing safety features, they prevent damaging public liability and expensive lawsuits caused by accidents to bathers injured in ordinary showers.

No time or water is wasted while bathers wait for showers to become hot or cool off to the right temperature.

Extra large supply pipes, often used to minimize dangerous pressure changes, are unnecessary when Powers Mixers are used.

Construction—Powers Mixers are ruggedly built of heavy castings with all internal working parts chromium plated to resist corrosion and wear. They have no thermostatic coils, no diaphragms, and no composition valve seat washers on hot water inlet to prevent leak and need frequent replacement.

Their sturdy all metal construction insures a durability not equaled by any other mixer.

How the Pressure Equalizing Valve Works

Simplified Diagrams Showing Cross-Section of Shower Mixer

WARM WATER 105° F.

| Hot water pressure 40 lbs. | Cold water pressure 40 lbs. |
|---------------------------|---------------------------|
| Pressure                  | Pressure                  |
| 10 lbs.                   | 10 lbs.                   |

Figure 6-140. Supply pressures equal.

Pressure Equalizing Valve A is a floating piston carrying on each end valves BB, which control the admission of the hot and cold water to mixing chamber C.

To illustrate the operation of this valve let us assume that the pressure of hot and cold water supply is 40 lbs., and that the handle of the mixer has been turned to the position where the temperature of mixed water delivered to shower is 105° F.

As long as the pressures of both hot and cold water supply are equal, the piston will occupy the neutral position illustrated above.

If pressure of cold water suddenly drops to 10 lbs., as shown in Figure 5-140, due to use of nearby showers or flush valves, the preponderance of hot water pressure instantly moves the piston sufficiently so that valves BB, by proportionately restricting the higher and favoring the lower pressure, maintain in the mixing chamber C the perfect balance of pressures necessary to maintain the temperature at 105° F.

Complete failure of either supply substantially cuts off the other. See Figure 6-140 which illustrates position of piston with complete failure of cold water supply. Spring shown is non-corrosive and is used only as an additional safeguard to insure instant closing of hot water valve when cold water supply fails.

Figure 7-140 shows position of piston with hot water supply suddenly reduced to 10 lbs. Because pressures of hot and cold water flowing to the mixing chambers are perfectly balanced, temperature of shower remains constant at 105° F.

Powers Style D Steam and Water Mixer

The Powers Style D Steam and Water Mixer is recommended for use where it is not practical to install a steam heated water storage tank and regulator. It will deliver hot water at approximately 150°F, water at a reasonably constant temperature for showers; wash sinks and wash fountains; dishwashing machines; barrel, can and car washes; and industrial processes.

The ½-inch mixer is intended to furnish tempered water for only one shower or fixture. No shut-off valve or volume adjustment should be installed between the mixer and the shower head or outlet. When used in this manner, the steam and water pressures may be anything between 10 and 100 pounds.

The ¾-inch mixer may also be used for furnishing tempered water to washup sinks provided there is a cold water connection at the fixture. By mixing cold water with the tempered water from the mixer, which is in this manner, the handle of the mixer is set at the desired temperature, and permanently in this position. For this type of installation the steam pressure should not exceed the cold water pressure; if it does, a reducing steam and water pressure reducing valve (see Bulletin No. 256) should be installed on the steam supply line to reduce the steam pressure and maintain it at the normal water pressure.

The 1-inch and 1½-inch mixers are intended for industrial process work and should generally be operated at least at 50% of their rated capacity.

The Style D mixer will not operate satisfactorily if either the steam or water pressure is less than 10 pounds or more than 100 pounds.

Safety Features—The two safety features described on pages 2 and 3 are incorporated in the design and a safety stop is included in the construction of this mixer. The mixer will maintain whatever temperature is desired regardless of pressure changes in the supply line. Failure of cold water substantially shuts off the delivery.

Construction—The mixer is ruggedly built of bronze with all internal working parts chromium plated to resist corrosion. Dial face handles are heavily chromium plated. Handles providing safety stops. Wall flange can be supplied for mounting mixer to wall.

Connections—Inlets have standard male elbow connections with union. Outlet has female connection without union; male connection with union at outlet can be furnished when specified.

Temperature Range—Mixer can be adjusted to maintain any desired temperature between that of the incoming water and 200°F. Delivery volume decreases proportionately as temperature rises.

Check Valves—The mixer has built-in check valves to prevent steam and cold water from interchanging. However, as an extra precaution, it is recommended that check valves be installed in both steam and water supply lines.

Shut-Off Valve—The mixer has a built-in shut-off valve.

Strainers—To protect shower mixers and heads from dirt and scale, self-cleaning strainers (page 35) should be installed in steam and cold water supply lines or mains. We can also furnish chromium plated brass strainer tees (see roughing-in dimensions and price list).

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

For many years the Department have experienced difficulty in providing suitable accommodation for teachers and staff in Alert Bay, with the result that we could not keep teachers.

Three years ago a duplex building, owned by the Synod of B.C., became vacant, and I made arrangements with His Lordship, Bishop Sexton, for this old building to be set aside for the use of teachers and Agency staff. As the Department had closed their teacherage at Takush Village, Smiths Inlet, and had transferred some household equipment to Alert Bay to be placed in storage, I utilized what furnishings I could to partially furnish the part used as a teacherage. Mrs. Massey, who was then principal of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, purchased additional furnishings to supplement what we already had.

This year, Mrs. Massey resigned and moved away and was going to sell her share of the furniture locally, which meant we would be back in the same predicament as we were before with no place for a teacher to live. In order to try and keep a permanent place for our teachers, I purchased the furniture owned by Mrs. Massey and paid her $72.00 for everything.

I enclose you, herewith, voucher No. 136 in the amount of $72.00, together with a list of the furnishings purchased and the receipt from Mrs. Massey, and am recommending to the Department that they purchase these furnishings which will be used for a permanent furnished teacherage so long as we are able to have the use of the building. I might add that Mrs. Massey gave us a good price on all these furnishings and they are well worth the money.

(Sgd) M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.
Alert Bay, B.C.,

For some time I have been very much concerned over the services being rendered by the Night Watchman at St. Michael's Indian Residential School, and have brought this to the attention of the principal. The question of employing suitable labour has been difficult during recent years.

On August 8th Mr. Wickens came to me and suggested that the Department supply a time-clock for use of the Night Watchman in order to have a greater check on his movements. Mr. Wickens felt this would insure greater supervision, and in this I concur.

Dear Mr. Todd,

I regret that my absence from Alert Bay has delayed my letter of Annual Estimates for the next fiscal year.

I am not repeating the items requisitioned in past years although they are still needed. The water-proofing of the whole school and the new floor to the Auditorium were the main items in last year's requisition.

Being away from the office I have no present access to my files to ascertain the lesser items in my listed needs of former years.

The requests I am now making are listed as under:

(1) The razing of the old School Block is very necessary. The recent earthquake did some damage to the building which was already insecure. The two rooms being used as classrooms let in the rain very badly, windows and plaster needing attention. I recommend the erection of a new building large enough to provide two full sized classrooms and two storerooms - approximately 60' x 60' at a cost of $7,000.00.

(2) I recommend the building of a Farm Instructors Cottage. This will provide for better oversight of our herd and livestock and also release much needed space in the main school block for the accommodation of our staff. Cost $3,000.00.

(3) The time has come when some of the mattresses for our Dormitory beds should be renewed. I request that fifty (50) new mattresses be purchased - approximate cost $400.00.

(4) Our farm machinery needs attention and I request that a new Farm wagon be purchased at an approximate price of $200.00. Two new wheels have been purchased for the present wagon during the past year and the frame cannot be expected to last much longer.
The Indian Agent,
Alert Bay.

(5) With the increasing difficulty of buying cord wood and the high cost of purchasing coal, I request that consideration be given to the installation of an oil fuel system for the school heating plant - approximate cost $600.00 for the two boilers.

Attention Mr. R.A. Hoey, Director.

In a recent press release, your remarks re a proposed or suggested new set up for educational residential schools were noted with interest.

On his last visit to Prince Rupert en route to Babine Agency, a similar proposal was discussed with District Inspector Davey, with particular reference to the Crosby Home at Port Simpson. Whilst no longer within my jurisdiction I also placed before him a plan which I believed would work admirably at Alert Bay, at which point there is a large residential school under Anglican auspices, as well as a potential 4 room day school set-up.

At the residential school there is an old "classroom block", formerly a girls boarding school. This building is a fire trap and should be replaced.

The residential school building proper has 3 classrooms. There is a serious shortage of playrooms in this building, the children using the basements for such purposes. Most of the winter months are such as to keep the children indoors a large part of the time.

Adjacent to the residential school is a special reserve, now subdivided; the original purpose of which was to provide land for the housing of ex-pupils. There has been a serious overcrowding of the village day school for many years as Indians from outside villages (too small to support day schools) have moved in to get their children to school.

My suggestion to Inspector Davey was (a) to build a ten or twelve room consolidated school on the special reserve adjacent to the residential school, capable of handling the 200 pupils from St. Michaels, plus the 100 pupils of the day school in the village. Two of the rooms would be for high school pupils who would be drawn from (a) the Kwakweweth Agency and (b) from other agencies in which there are no available "high" high schools, e.g., the Bella Coola Agency. The residential school could become a hostel or home for (a) orphans, neglected and problem cases, (b) these high school pupils (c) preventorium children as at present. The present classroom block would be demolished and so remove the biggest fire risk to the main building.

The proposed educational centre would be built and operated entirely by the Department with a full Civil Service staff. It would include an industrial arts and domestic science division, and built in the form of a wheel with six spokes. The hub would be a teacher's residence containing apartments and single rooms; the six spokes the classrooms, manual and industrial arts and domestic science; and an auditorium gymnasium. It would be steam heated from the central building. If the teachers quarters were not to be included, the central block could be the gymnasium-auditorium, with shops and domestic science rooms above or below.
Alert Bay would be an ideal place in which to establish such an educational unit, which would of course be also used in a major adult education programme and presupposes the use of a school-village health nurse, welfare teacher in addition to the academic staff. It should be remembered that the Department is going to have to build (a) a day school of at least 4 rooms for the village in any case (b) a new classroom unit at the Residential School should the status quo remain constant. My suggestion to Mr. Davey was to combine the two needs, take care of the High School pupils of a very large part of the B.C. coast; put the academic side of education solely on the Department and I believe, if the right man can be secured to head it up, do a real piece of work for the Indians at not much greater cost than at present. Pupils of all faiths would be admitted to the proposed educational unit.

This has been much on my mind in the past few years and your statement to the Indian Committee gives me encouragement to put my idea into writing. I know that Alert Bay is no longer my territory but my roots are down deep in that spot and I do not easily forget the many years I worked there.

If this scheme has any merit and is investigated further, I would ask that my name be kept out of it as far as the Indian Agent, Alert Bay is concerned, as he may not take kindly to a scheme coming from another Agent.

I may be in Ottawa on leave in September and would like the opportunity of discussing this further and also a proposed Indian co-operative fishing scheme, details of which I am now bringing together into a definite plan.

F. Earl Anfield
Indian Agent.

In the current year's appropriation we provided an amount for water-proofing the exterior walls of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. Surveys and Engineering Branch found it impossible to proceed with this work during the past summer.

The officers of the M.S.C.C., whose head office is now located in Ottawa, approached us and pointed out the necessity for providing a cottage for the farmer at the school and asked us if we would expend the amount provided for water-proofing the walls for erecting this cottage.

We advised them to have the principal consult the Agent and submit requisitions for materials and estimates of labour.

We are now informed by the M.S.C.C. that the principal completed the work without following Departmental procedure. Evidently the labour was done by the school staff but certain expenditures were incurred for materials, etc.

We are instructing the M.S.C.C. to have the accounts incurred in connection with the construction of the farmer's cottage submitted to Indian Agent Todd and he in turn should submit them to you.
