Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C.

Re your 6-11-4 of December 2nd, 1947, dealing with Principal's quarters at Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

When the new school was built in 1929 I asked the Department to furnish the Principal's residence. Mr. W.E. Ditchburn, the Commissioner declined, but consented to furnish one bedroom only, which was done. The furniture of this room was carefully checked and left when we departed from Alert Bay, but I understand that Mr. A.W. Derrom, Vice-Principal, who took over for me until Mr. Wickens arrived, took this furniture to his suite in the main school. He had recently married one of the staff and I expect required the double bed. He has gone and I believe this furniture, bed, drawers and two chairs, is now used in the same room by a Mr. and Mrs. Wiseman farm instructor at the school.

When we left Alert Bay, the Indian Residential School Commission bought our electric refrigerator which was moved to the Preventorium, our oil burning kitchen range and some other items of furniture, which I cannot remember at this time. I know that two bedrooms were left furnished. When I went to Alert Bay in 1926 I had to pay my predecessor $200.00 cash for furniture that I think had been in the school since 1889. It disintegrated and after I married we bought almost all new furniture of our own. If I remember correctly the total expenditure by the Department in the residence did not exceed $100.00 in furnishing the one bedroom.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Alert Bay, B.C.
November 25th, 1947

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Re: St. Michael's Indian Residential School

Rev. Dixon arrived here and commenced duty at the school Nov. 24th, and apparently after having made a general inspection of the premises found that his living quarters were unfurnished. The matter had been previously taken up with his MSCC Headquarters, and he had a letter from them to the effect that it was the Department's responsibility to furnish these quarters.

It is our belief that furnishings were originally supplied, but have gradually disappeared throughout the years. At any rate, the former Principal had his own furniture, which he took away with him on his departure.

The new Principal has asked that if possible we obtain the following as soon as possible:

1 Bedroom suite complete
1 Chesterfield suite with two chairs
1 Dining room suite

If it is found that we cannot make these purchases, we would ask that you direct the request through the necessary channels in order to get immediate action. In the meantime the Principal, Rev. Dixon, is getting along on makeshift arrangements.

J. C. Letcher
Acting Indian Agent.
Air Mail

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

I am forwarding Mr. Acting Indian Agent Letcher's letter of November 25th wherein he requests that the Department provide furnishings for the principal's quarters at the Alert Bay Indian residential School. In the absence of any information on file with respect to furnishings previously supplied, if any, I contacted Mr. Anfield and secured the information as detailed in his letter attached. I have made inquiries regarding the cost of the furniture requested by the new principal in case the furnishings for his quarters are to be the Department's responsibility and find that the Bedroom suite, Chesterfield suite and Dining room suite will cost approximately $800.00.

I should appreciate being advised if the Department ordinarily assumes responsibility for furnishing the principal's quarters at residential schools and if so if funds to the above amount can be made available.

D. M. MacKay,

March 9, 1948.

AIR MAIL

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I enclose for your information a letter recently received from Archdeacon Cook with reference to the Alert Bay Residential School. It is noted from this communication that the M.B.C.C. is prepared to be responsible for the labour required for painting and repairs, provided the annual vacation period be extended for three months.

We feel that any such extension of the holiday period would be inadvisable for many reasons and consequently we would like you to give us an estimate of what labour would cost to do the work that is absolutely essential. Previous to submitting this estimate you might communicate with the Reverend principal and ascertain what assistance in the form of labour the school staff is prepared to give during the months of July and August and if you have this information it would reduce the amount that the Department would be expected to pay.

You should also forward a requisition for the paint and materials for repairs that you recommend and let us know the approximate cost of these, and if they can be purchased in British Columbia you should submit the names and addresses of the firms from whom the paint and materials can be secured.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

PP/MGD

Enc.
March 9, 1948.

Dear Archdeacon Cook:

We have your letter of the 5th instant with reference to the Alert Bay Residential School. It is noted that in connection with the painting and repair work that you consider necessary at the Alert Bay School, you offer to supply labour if the Department supplies the material. We appreciate your co-operation in this regard but it appears that this would be contingent on increasing the holiday leave from two months to three months.

For many reasons we feel that it is undesirable to increase the holidays at any one school unless the situation is more serious than at Alert Bay.

We are writing to Indian Commissioner Arneil requesting him to let us have an estimate of the cost of the labour in carrying out the repairs and painting during the months of July and August. We are instructing him to communicate with the Reverend Principal of the Alert Bay school with a view to ascertaining how much labour can be supplied by the school staff and intimating to him that we will be prepared to pay the cost of the labour over and above what is supplied free by the staff. We are also requesting him to submit a requisition for the paint and materials required.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Ven. Archdeacon H.G. Cook,
Superintendent,
Indian School Administration,
M.S.C.C., Ottawa.

It was noted by district School Inspector Davey during his visit to the Alert Bay Residential School that there were insufficient beds and mattresses to accommodate the enrolled pupilage and that many of the springs and mattresses in use were in very poor shape. Mr. Acting Indian Agent Letcher was requested to consult with the Principal and advise what items were required to bring this equipment up to standard. The Acting Agent's letter of February 5th and enclosure in this connection is attached hereto and I would recommend that the departmental purchasing be requested to secure 24 single beds complete with springs and mattresses and 24 additional mattresses. If the Department so desires prices can be secured in Vancouver but it is anticipated that the expenditure would exceed $500.00, the maximum amount which the Commissioner has authority to cover by purchase order.

Mr. W. S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Acquisition of Beds & Mattresses St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay

In reference to School Inspector Davey's letter, file 6-11-1, dated January 24th, I wish to advise that the following beds and mattresses are urgently required by the Residential School:

24 only single, cot style beds with springs
48 " Mattresses, cot size

In support of this requisition we are enclosing herewith a letter received from the Principal which is self explanatory.

It is suggested that War Assets Corporation be contacted with a view to obtaining the requirements from their surplus stores, if such items are available. Hospital cots would be the ideal solution, as these are much stronger and will stand the abuse of the male pupils. It is recommended that the equipment be supplied as soon as possible.

J/C Letcher

Dear Sir:

We have 196 beds in this School and only 190 mattresses. Several mattresses now in use are a disgrace and for health reasons should be discarded.

Would it be possible for the Indian Affairs Branch to supply twenty-four beds and forty-eight mattresses without delay so that we can increase our pupilage to the maximum?

As a guide I suggest Restmore bed #625 - page 94, Restmore Catalogue No.10

Yours truly,

I am forwarding Mr. Acting Indian Agent Letcher's letter of January 22nd and enclosure referred to therein, together with a memorandum dated January 28th from District School Inspector Davey in connection with the proposed supply of masonite for covering the tables in the dining room at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

The condition of the tables is such that some covering is necessary and in view of conditions in general at the school as revealed by a recent investigation by the School Inspector it is considered that everything possible should be done to improve the standard at this school.

Although the Principal requests white masonite, the material he has in mind is not actually masonite but a plastic composition which costs 75¢ a foot compared to 18¢ a foot for black masonite which would be equally suitable. The cost of black masonite and aluminum counter edge moulding is approximately $175.00 and I would recommend that the Department endeavour to make funds available for the purchase of this material.

Dear Col. Neary:

This is just a personal note to thank you for your kindness and help extended to me while I was in Ottawa recently. I arrived home and am on duty. My doctors informed me my recovery is almost complete but I must have proper rest and not try to overdo things.

For your information, Commissioner Arneil and Inspector Davey visited the Agency three days after my return, and we decided that the north half of Lot 23 (which has since been the subject of another report which will reach you shortly) is the proper location of the new proposed classroom block to accommodate Residential School pupils.

I have also interviewed a local contractor who is building the Agency residence this year and he is willing to accept a contract for the labour only for this building, the Department to purchase all materials. This I think we can do without any difficulty, and as soon as you are prepared to go ahead, this advance notice will help you in deciding your plans. This same contractor would, I believe take a contract to supply material as well as do all the work, providing he was sure of being able to purchase all the material.

You will be pleased to know that we have drilled a new well and struck a supply of good water close to the new school site. The engineers are installing part of the plumbing which means both teacherages should be ready for occupancy shortly. All the plumbing is being put in with the exception of the toilets. This will have to be held up evidently until the sewerage system is installed.

I am informed the Turnour Island School and Teacherage is about half completed. The Campbell River Teacherage is reported finished.

This personal note is just to say thanks for all your courtesy and assistance while I was in Ottawa, and to let you know what progress is being made in respect to our schools now under construction.

Yours faithfully,

(M.S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

Col. E. F. Neary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

FOR PROJECT No.884.

PLUMBING AND DRAINAGE

1. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying plans are intended to provide for a complete plumbing and drainage installation and fire protection service in the School Building and the Contractor shall furnish all material and labour of every description required therefor for its proper completion.

2. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor shall visit the site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

3. RULES AND REGULATIONS

All work shall be done in accordance with rules, regulations and recommendations as may be laid down by local or other authorities controlling such work. The contractor shall file all necessary plans with such authorities and pay all necessary fees for permits, etc., as may be required.

4. MATERIALS AND WORKSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds.

All work shall be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner by workmen skilled in this trade, and special attention shall be given exposed work so that it be neatly erected with pipes plumb and true.

5. EXCAVATING AND BACKFILLING

Contractor shall do all necessary excavating and backfill after same incident to the installation of his work. Backfilling will be done in shallow layers and be thoroughly puddled and tamped.

6. INSTALLING IN

Furnish and install complete lines of drains, vents, wastes, etc., of required sizes. All fixtures shall be back vented as noted on drawings or as may be required.

Install water lines and make all necessary connections to fixtures. Each plumbing fixture shall have air chambers installed on both hot and cold water lines, such air chambers being not less than 12" long. All branch lines shall be separately valved.

7. DRAINAGE UNDERFLOOR

All soil and drain pipe below the basement floor shall be extra heavy cast iron with bell and spigot ends. The inside of such pipe shall be clean and free from rust and shall be thoroughly oiled inside and out to give a protective coating.
8. EXPOSED DRAINS

All soil and drain pipe above the basement floor shall be medium weight cast iron with bell and spigot ends, and shall be clean and free from rust and shall be thoroughly oiled inside and out.

9. JOINTS

All joints in cast iron pipe shall be made with cement and molten lead and thoroughly caulked.

All joints in waste or vent piping shall be made with long sweep recessed cast iron drain fittings.

Where screwed joints are used for soil or waste pipe, they shall have a smooth continuous interior surface.

Joints to fixtures shall be made with proper gaskets and ferrules as required.

Water closets shall be connected to soil drains by means of brass or cast iron floor flange not less than 3/16 inch thick with caulked joints to cast iron soil drain and with approved packing ring.

10. GRADING OF PIPES

Waste and soil piping shall be graded in the direction of flow with a pitch of not less than 1/4 inch to the foot unless otherwise noted on plan or specified.

All horizontal branches of vent piping shall be graded with the same pitch as above toward the fixtures.

All horizontal branches of hot and cold water piping shall be so graded that they may be completely drained through drip connections installed at necessary points.

11. CLEANOUTS

Provide and set fittings in all drain and soil pipes for cleanouts at all points where obstruction might occur and at the ends of all long horizontal pipes and all points required by-laws, or as directed or shown on drawings. Also install Barrett cleanouts at foot of all stacks.

Cleanouts shall be full size for pipes up to 4" diameter and not less than 4" for larger pipes. In horizontal runs they shall be closed gas-tight with heavy brass ferrules caulked in and capped with screw cap, and where on drains underground shall finish flush with floor.

12. WATER PIPING

Cold water piping included in this contract shall begin at a point 3'-0" outside of the building, or otherwise as noted on plans.

All domestic hot and cold water piping in this building shall be galvanized steel standard weight, put together with galvanized screwed malleable iron fittings. No cold water piping shall be laid in any floor slab. Water service pipes within the basement shall be covered as hereafter described, and exposed to view on external walls and below ceilings.
13. FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE

Provide and install where indicated on plan E cold water branches from main to hose rack connections. Each of these branches shall be valved close to hose rack. Provide suitable couplings to connect hose to stand pipe.

Supply and mount on suitable brackets approved type hose racks including 50'-0" of unlined linen hose with suitable nozzle, for inside service. One rack assembly to be located in each of the following rooms, where shown on plans: Manual Training Room, Cooking and Sewing Room (in basement) and Hall on First Floor. Mount racks 7'-0" up from floor. See drawings for further details.

✓ 14. HANGERS

Standing runs of cast iron pipe shall be securely fixed in position by means of strong iron supports placed immediately below the hubs.

Horizontal runs of cast iron pipe shall be supported by means of band iron hanger rings and 3/8 inch rod supports from the ceiling.

Vertical runs of water pipe shall be supported by means of iron supports same as for cast iron pipes.

Horizontal runs of water piping shall be supported at 6'-0" intervals with rod and ring hangers. No grabber bar hangers allowed.

✓ 15. VALVES

Valves generally shall be gate valves unless otherwise mentioned 2" and under shall be all brass. Over 2" shall be iron body valves with bronze trimmings.

✓ 16. FLASHING

Where vent stacks project through the roof they shall be suitably cap flashed with 5 lb. lead to make a satisfactory and watertight job.

✓ 17. TESTING

Water Piping: Contractor will test all water piping before covering, using cold water at 100 lb. pressure.

Drains and vent system shall be tested for leakage by being filled with water to roof level.

Underfloor drains shall be tested for grade using a standard billiard ball.

On completion of the work the sanitary system shall be submitted to a smoke test.

✓ 18. SLEEVES AND ESCUTCHEONS

Where exposed pipes pass through floors, partitions or ceilings in finished rooms, they shall be provided with galvanized iron sleeves 1/2 inch larger than the pipe and cast iron or chrome plated pressed steel escutcheons either of the one piece or split ring type.
10. PLUMBING FIXTURES

The Contractor shall furnish and install all necessary fittings and connections to water supply and drainage system, plumbing fixtures in accordance with plumbing fixture specifications.

20. DOMESTIC HOT WATER STORAGE TANK AND HEATERS

The Contractor shall provide and install on suitable stand, a galvanized steel storage tank of the capacity noted on plumbing plan, built for 150 pounds working pressure. He shall make all necessary water connections generally as shown on plan, including all valves, unions, etc.

The Contractor shall also provide and install in positions approximately as shown on detail 8 immersion type electric water heaters of the capacities noted, complete with aqua-statics suitable for this service.

31. COVERING

All exposed cold water piping, unless otherwise noted, shall be covered 1" thick with anti-sweat wool felt sectional covering consisting of two 1/2 inch layers, each of which shall have been so fabricated by its manufacturer as to have a double thickness of cement paper both inside and out, stapled in place and jacketed with factory cotton pasted on. Risers in partitions will not be covered unless noted on plan.

All hot water supply and recirculating pipes, unless otherwise noted, shall be covered with 1 inch thick 4-ply asbestos air cell sectional pipe covering carefully butted and fitted around hangers, etc., and jacketed with factory cotton pasted on.

Elbows, tees, valves, etc., shall be covered with asbestos cement and covered with cotton as specified for pipes.

Hot water storage tank shall be covered with 1 inch thick 4-ply asbestos aircell blocks, wired in place, and plastered 1 inch thick with long fibre asbestos cement applied in two coats, the last coat to be tempered with 10 per cent Portland cement and trowelled to a smooth finish. Paint two coats with waterproof paint of an approved colour.

22. HOSE HIBBS

Provide and install in Boiler Room where shown on plumbing plan, one 1/2 inch angle pattern hose valve with renewable seat and tee handle.

23. FLOOR DRAINS

Provide floor drain in Boiler Room where shown. It shall be cast iron with anti-tilting flat round grate with integral receptor.
1. **GENERAL**

The Contractor shall furnish and install ready for use the following plumbing fixtures, the locations of which, as hereafter numbered, are indicated by the corresponding numbers on plans. All exposed work, brackets, etc., not plated shall be enamelled two coats with white enamel. Plated work shall be of best quality chromium plate or brass, unless otherwise noted; if chromium plating cannot be obtained nickel plating will be acceptable, but the contractor shall definitely state the plating included when submitting his tender.

2. **MANUFACTURERS' PLATE NUMBERS AND ILLUSTRATIONS**

The Contractor shall submit in triplicate to the Chief Engineer, Engineering and Construction Division, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ontario, for approval, a list of the Plumbing Fixtures and Fittings with Manufacturers' Plate Numbers and Illustrations that he proposes to supply. Fixtures and fittings shall be so specified consistent with such restrictions as may apply; for any such not obtainable the Contractor shall submit obtainable and acceptable alternatives subject to the final approval of the Department.

3. **CLOSET COMBINATION: REQUIRED**

Vitreous china reverse trap elongated rim bowl with cast iron floor flange asbestos gasket and china bolt caps.

Vitreous china low down closet tank with silent ball cock and 3/8 inch chrome plated angle supply with rough plated brass stop and wall flange.

Black Bonalite open front seat cover with plated bar hinge.

4. **LAVATORY: REQUIRED**

20" x 18" Vitreous china wall lavatory with 6" high integral back, rectangular basin, and anti-splash lip on concealed wall hanger.

Fit with heavy duty plated brass hot and cold indexed self-closing faucets, chain stop, 3/8" x 6" plated supply uprights with reducers, 3/8" rough plated brass angle stops and plated wall flanges, 1-1/4" outlet-traps adjustable "P" trap to wall with porcelain gland, screwed female outlet and plated wall flange 1-1/4" plated and polished N.O. plug with rubber stopper, and plated brass chain with spot welded ring on stopper.

5. **EXTERIOR SINK: REQUIRED**

18" x 30" x 6" deep Vitreous china flat rim sink with integral overflow and drainboard. Fit with plated swinging spout, connected to 1/2" plated hot and cold supplies with 1/2" rough plated angle stops, with wall flanges. Provide grease trap equal in manufacture to the "Fleming" no. F-2015 having a grease capacity of 10 lbs. and 75 gal. water per hour with 1-1/2" inlet and outlet as supplied by the same Co. of Canada, Ltd.

END
1. Scope of Work

This specification and the accompanying plans are intended to provide for a closed system of forced hot water heating complete in every respect, for the Day School. The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work, and be responsible for the accuracy of same. He shall provide all labour, transportation material and plant, and give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done.

2. Visit the Site

The Contractor shall visit the site and see the conditions under which the work will be done.

3. Materials and Workmanship

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

Workmanship shall be of the best, and all work shall be done in a neat manner with due attention being given to the grading of pipes and making connections. All connections shall be made so as to permit free and unobstructed flow at all times, and adequate provision shall be made for expansion. All pipes shall be carefully reamed after cutting and the Contractor will be held strictly responsible for any failures due to neglecting this phase of the work.

4. Radiators

Furnish and install where shown on plans, cast iron free standing radiators of a design equal to "Certo" as made by Dominion Radiator Co., Ltd., or the "Copley" as made by Gurney Foundry Co., Ltd. These radiators shall be suitable for hot water heating and shall be of sizes as noted on plans.

5. Radiator Valves

Furnish and install on flow end of all radiators, brass globe valves with solid wheel handles, of approved manufacture.

6. Valves Generally

All valves, except for radiators, shall be gate valves, 8" and under; all brass; over 8" iron body bronze fitted of a type and make satisfactory to the Chief Engineer, Engineering and Construction Division, or his representative.

7. Automatic Air Vents

Furnish and install where indicated on plans and where elsewhere deemed necessary, automatic air vents equal to Bell and Gossett type as made by B.A. Armstrong, Co., of Canada Ltd., Toronto, Ontario. Air Vents shall have heavy cast iron bodies seamless copper floats and needle type discharge valve.
Vents shall be of sufficient capacity to positively and quickly relieve the air from all parts of the system; vent outlets shall be carried to convenient drains or where directed.

6. PIPING

All flow and return piping shall be standard black steel pipe put together with cast iron screwed fittings and with unions, screwed or flanged, where required. All piping throughout the work must be carefully reamed before assembly, and pipe compound shall be applied to pipe threads only.

Piping shall be run substantially as shown on plans so that there will be a free and easy circulation to each radiator. All flow connections to radiators above the mains shall be taken off top of main at 45 degrees. All flow connections to radiators below the mains shall be taken off bottom of main at 45 degrees. All return connections shall be connected into side of return main. Provide and install drain-offs on all connections to radiators below the mains and at all other low points, so that the system can be completely drained, providing all necessary valves.

Where risers occur, they shall be concealed in partitions or furred in as indicated on plans.

7. GRADING OF PIPES

Flow and return mains shall be graded \( \frac{1}{2} \) inch in 10'-0" unless otherwise noted. Materials to radiators and risers shall be graded \( \frac{1}{2} \) inch per foot back to mains.

8. HANGERS

Pipe suspended from ceiling shall be supported by ring hangers with \( \frac{1}{2} \) inch diameter rods spaced not more than 8'-0" apart.

Pipe carried on wall shall be supported by bracket type hangers securely fastened to wall. Careful attention shall be given in locating these brackets, in respect to the grade of the pipe. Brackets to be spaced not more than 8'-0" apart.

No grabbler bar hangers will be accepted for any part of the work.

9. SLEEVES AND ESCUTCHEONS

Pipes passing through walls or floors shall have galvanized flanged floor sleeves \( \frac{1}{2} \) inch larger than the pipe installed during the construction of the building.

A cast iron or chrome plated pressed steel escutcheon of the one piece or split ring type shall be provided and installed where any pipe enters or emerges from a ceiling, floor or wall.

10. COVERING

All flow and return mains, except where otherwise noted on plan, shall be covered with only 1 inch thick asbestos air cell sectional pipe covering, carefully butted and fitted around hangers where such occur, and finished with factory cotton bound on. Elbows, tees, valves, etc., shall be covered with long fibre asbestos cement, and wrapped with cotton as specified for pipes. Flanges and unions shall not be covered.
Boiler shall be covered with 1 inch thick 4 ply asbestos air cell blocks wired in place, and plastered 1 inch thick with long fibre asbestos cement, applied in two coats; the last coat to be tempered with 10 per cent Portland cement and finished to a smooth finish. Paint two coats with water proof paint of an approved colour.

13. BOILER

Furnish and install where shown on plans, one boiler having specifications as noted on drawing. Boiler shall be cast iron square sectional hot water type and equal to the Viking as made by the Burden-King Co., of Canada Ltd., and shall be suitable for burning coal, hand fired.

The boiler shall be fitted with thermometer, pressure gauge, direct-acting aquastat and reverse-acting aquastat, located as shown on detail. Provide draft and check regulator and mount on basement ceiling above boiler. This unit to be complete with linkage, operating mechanism and all miscellaneous auxiliaries as hereinafter specified.

Provide valved drain-out connection from boiler, also pressure regulating and pressure relief valves on cold water supply to boiler generally as shown, and extend flow and return connections therefrom to the heating system all as outlined on plans. The Contractor shall provide one complete set of firing tools including 16" scoop shovel.

14. CUSHION TANK

Provide and install close to basement ceiling over boiler one cushion tank of a size as noted on drawings, and built to Inter-provincial regulations governing pressure vessels. Tank to be equipped with gauge glass, combination air charger and tank drainer, and supported from ceiling by 2 heavy strap iron hangers.

15. SMOKE DRAUGHTING

Furnish and erect smoke pipe from boiler of a size and gauge noted on plans, complete with connection to boiler. Provide and install one close fitting, manually operated damper in horizontal run in smoke pipe.

16. CIRCULATING PUMP

Provide and install near boiler, where shown on plan, circulating pump of a size and capacity as noted on drawing. Pump shall be equal to those made by Minneapolis-Honeywell or Bell and Gossett type as made by the S.A. Armstrong Co., of Canada Ltd., Toronto, and shall have horizontal type direct connected motor of size and electrical characteristics noted on drawing. Provide a valved by-pass with reducers, as shown on drawing.

17. CONTROL EQUIPMENT

This Contractor shall provide and mount where shown in Class Room approximately 6'-0" above floor, one heavy duty line voltage mercury switch type thermostat equal to Minneapolis-Honeywell No.T42A series 40 arranged to start circulating pump on room temperature falls. Furnish and install on boiler one immersion type reverse-acting aquastat equal to M-N No.L44B series 40 which shall be wired into thermostat-pump circuit so as to override room thermostat and start pump when boiler water temperature reaches 180 degrees F.
Contractor shall also provide and install on boiler where shown one direct-acting immersion type aqua-stat equal to U-N. No. 14448 series 40. Provide and locate on basement ceiling above boiler one 2 position spring return type damper and check regulator complete with all operating mechanism including linkage, pulleys, brackets, etc. This unit shall be equal to Minneapolis-Honeywell M465A series 40. The purpose of the direct acting aqua-stat and the draft and check regulator is to provide a means of combustion control. This Contractor shall, as mentioned previously, install these items. See Electrical Specification for wiring instructions.
VENTILATION

BOILER ROOM, SCHOOL BUILDING.

16. FAN AND MOTOR

Provide and install on steel brackets where shown in the boiler room, one centrifugal type exhaust fan, direct connected to 1/8 H.P. 1/110/60 A.C. standard motor. The fan shall have a capacity to deliver 435 cfm against 1/4" static pressure. Fan inlet shall be left open.

Provide manual motor starting switch with thermal overload protection and mount same 5'-0" above floor on wall under motor.

19. AUTOMATIC SHUTTERS AND DUCT WORK

Provide and install where shown on plan 10" x 10" standard automatic discharge louvres. Also provide and install 10" x 8" galvanized iron duct between fan and discharge louvres. Duct shall be made of 26 V.O. gauge and shall have cross broken panels to give visibility. Lengthwise joints shall be lock sewed. The duct shall be securely hung near the ceiling by metal bands not lighter than No.18 V.O. gauge, and such supports shall be so spaced as to prevent sagging.

20. GRILLES

Provide and install in walls approximately 6" above floor 2 - 10" x 8" grilles, each one fitted with a flap damper held open by a spring. Provide and incorporate a fusible link in the spring set to release at approximately 120 degrees F.

21. EQUIPMENT DATA

The Contractor shall submit in duplicate to the Chief Engineer, for approval, the name and rating of the boiler, circulating pump, aqua-stat, thermostat and draft and check regulator, that he proposes to install, and none of these items shall be purchased for this work until such approval has been obtained.

22. COMPLETION

Upon completion of the work, the Contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials resulting from his work, and leave the system in perfect working order.

23. RECORD PLANS

During progress of the work, the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans. Upon completion he shall forward to the Chief Engineer one set of blueprints with changes clearly recorded in red. Blueprints for this purpose will be furnished by the Department.

24. GUARANTEE

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance by the Department. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period, at his own expense, as soon as possible after having been notified in writing that such defect has appeared.

ELECTRICAL SPECIFICATION
for
STANDARD FOUR CLASSROOM SCHOOL
For PROJECT No. 864
Index No. 863

1. All clauses of the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

2. Scope of Work
The Contractor shall supply all materials required and shall install, in a thorough and workmanlike manner, a system of electric wiring as shown on accompanying electrical plan Sheet No. M1, Index No. 863. (Note in shaded area.)
Provide all conduit, wire, cable, fittings, panels, switches, lighting fixtures, wiring devices and all appurtenances necessary for a complete and approved system ready for operation.

3. Rules and Regulations
All work shall be carried out in accordance with the rules and regulations as set forth in the Canadian Electrical Code together with such additional regulations of the local Inspection Authorities as may be applicable. Before final payment on contract is authorized, a certificate of inspection and approval of work from the Inspection Department of the local authorities shall be submitted to the Chief Engineer. The Contractor shall file all necessary plans with the local authorities and pay all fees and take out all permits in connection therewith.

4. Plans
Electrical plan Sheet No. M1, Index No. 863, issued with these specifications, will show outlets, wire, cable and conduit sizes and other necessary details. However, outlet locations and the routing of cable and conduits shall be carefully checked, before installation, with the Engineer.
Switch outlets shall be on latch side of doors and shall be ranged where they occur together. All lettering appearing on the plan shall be considered as part of the specifications.

In all cases of discrepancies between the plans and specifications, or in cases where interpretation of the plans and/or specifications is in any way in doubt, the Contractor shall refer the matter to the Engineer. If the Contractor proceeds with the construction without getting the proper interpretation of the plans and/or specifications from the Engineer, it will be at his own risk, and he may be required to remove work which is not in accordance with the design, and will replace it. The number of conductors necessary to provide specified circuits are shown on the plan, but it shall be the responsibility of the Contractor to complete all circuits and connections irrespective of any omissions which may occur on plan detail.

5. Visit the Site

The Contractor must visit the site and see the conditions under which the work is to be done and all electrical work shall be planned and done in close cooperation with the workmen performing work of the other trades.

6. Material and Workmanship

All materials and workmanship shall be the best of their respective kinds. All pipes and fittings shall be galvanized. Lighting panels shall be galvanized and finished in black baked-on enamel. Materials shall be new and as detailed on plan and/or as herein specified. Substitutions will be permitted only by written approval of the Chief Engineer. Studs and joists must not be notched or otherwise cut except by drilled holes centred in wood members.
7. Service

Electric service to the building will be single phase, 115/230 Volts, 3 wire, and will be run to the building from overhead secondary mains by the Power Company. Provide service standpipe and equipment as detailed on plan to receive and distribute electrical energy. Leave thirty (30) inch length of service conductors outside of service entrance head for connection by Power Company to service secondary drops from Power Company pole. Lighting panel and service switch shall be provided complete with fuses.

Mount service switch and meter, as noted on plan, and provide connections between meter and main switch. Meter will be provided by Power Company.

Ground neutral and service equipment to fulfill code requirements.

8. Wiring

Except as noted on plan and/or as herein specified the wiring shall be done in 600 volt maximum rubber insulated braid covered wire enclosed in rigid galvanized conduit concealed in ceiling, wall and floor construction. Wiring drawn in basement floor slab shall be lead covered cable enclosed in rigid galvanized steel conduit of size noted on plan. Feeder from service switch to lighting panel shall be run exposed.

Terminate feeder from Heating Control Panel to hot water tank in ceiling outlet box and extend to 2 KWe and 1 KWe electric heaters and their controls using asbestos covered conductors.

All wiring shall be done according to Canadian Electrical Code regulations governing this type of installation.
9. **Painting and Labelling**

All exposed piping and fittings shall be painted two coats approved first quality paint. Inside of panels shall be touched up after installation to remove marks. Panels shall be fitted with combination lock and catch and shall be provided with index cards indicating circuit service.

10. **Electric Fixtures and Lamps**

Supply and install as specified on plan an electric luminaire on each lighting outlet complete with lamps of specified wattage. All incandescent lamps shall be inside frosted 1000 hour 125 volt Mazda quality and fluorescent lamps shall be 40 watt 2500 hour life, white (3800 K), Mazda quality.

11. **Connect up Equipment**

Heating and ventilating equipment will be provided complete with all electrical motors, heaters and required controls by others. Wiring for controls and equipment is shown on electrical plan for equipment to be provided; however, all wiring for equipment and controls supplied on the job shall be checked and all necessary changes shall be made to meet requirements to the approval of the Engineer.

The locations of all equipment shall be checked with workmen of other trades before running conduit and setting outlets.

The following equipment will be provided complete with all necessary automatic controls by others. Provide all wiring and make all electrical connections.

(a) Circulating pump on forced hot water heating system.
(b) 2 KW and 1 KW 230 volt electric domestic hot water heaters.
(c) Exhaust fans.
(d) Draft and check regulator for combustion control.
13. Record Plans

During the progress of the work the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans and shall forward to the Chief Engineer, upon completion, a blue print showing all changes clearly marked in red. A blue print for this purpose will be provided upon request.

14. Cutting

All cutting of finishing woodwork and ceiling and wall finishes for the installation of lighting fixture outlets and other wiring devices shall be carried out by workmen skilled in this work.

15. Guarantee

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period at his own expense as soon as practicable after being notified in writing that such defect exists.

For your information I have spent most of two days recently
inspecting equipment and St. Michael's Indian Residential School
in general. The school is now closed and I had a good opportunity
to examine everything.

In regard to the attached requisition I find some mattresses
in a most terrible condition. I examined every bed, spring and
mattress in the school, condemned those unfit for use and ordered
that they be burned up. Most of these mattresses were inexpensive
material in the first place and will not stand up to ordinary use.
Six beds were broken beyond repair and these also will have to be
replaced.

As it is necessary that they be supplied before school opens,
I would appreciate if these could be purchased at once and shipped
to the school so that they can be set up and ready for the opening
of school.

You will please note there are two different sizes of mattresses.
These must be supplied according to specifications in order to fit
the beds now in use.

It would be appreciated if the six beds could be white, similar
to the last ones purchased so that they will match. The Restmore
Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Vancouver, supplied the beds and mattresses
shipped during April last.

Recently local merchants have been complaining to me that their monthly accounts with St. Michael's Indian Residential School have not been paid. One merchant informed me he has received no remittance from the M.S.C.C. for four months. This information is becoming public property in this community and is casting a reflection on the Indian Affairs Branch. In respect to the Provincial Fund account, which I know has not been paid for four months, I should like to point out a voucher goes through each month covering their total grant, and I am sure the Department of National Health and Welfare pay this account each month as received; so there is no excuse whatsoever for this money not being passed on to the storekeeper when the Government have already paid it. It is felt this information should be known in Ottawa.

During a recent conversation with the Rev. Dixon, Principal of St. Michael's Indian Residential School, he informed me that he had been instructed by Archdeacon Cook, M.S.C.C. Head Office, that he was to employ his staff for the coming term on the same salary basis as heretofore, which means they do not intend to comply with Provincial Department of Labour minimum wage regulations. If this policy is followed through there is no hope whatsoever of ever getting efficient staff in this school and the result will be the same inefficiency, and the administration of this institution deteriorating beyond where it is at the present time. It seems to me the time has come when the Department must take a serious view of the administration of this school.

Mr. Dixon informed me that his present engineer who was receiving a cash salary of $112.00 per month, plus living accommodation and other considerations, has resigned and the M.S.C.C. are transferring the engineer from the Chapleau Indian Residential School here and he is to be paid only $60.00 cash per month, plus the same considerations the previous engineer received. This is the policy of the M.S.C.C. They are not increasing salaries after receiving extra grant so that this could be done but are actually decreasing them in this case.

If the present policy is continued I can see no possible improvement in this school. The recent Departmental circular defined the responsibilities of the Church and the Department and has clarified certain aspects and is welcome.

The standard of some of the personnel employed in this school is very low. Recently one woman who was employed at the school left and went to work in a local hotel which is known for bootlegging all up and down the coast. This is not an isolated case but will give you some indication as to the type of help employed and the reason they have to employ this type is on account of low wages paid. It appears they take just whoever they can get with the result inefficiency is prevalent and supervision of children lacking. The Indian Affairs Branch, who are indirectly responsible for the care of these children, are being criticized but there seems nothing we can do under the present set-up.
Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines and Resources,

W.S. Arnell, Esq., Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Water Works System, Alert Bay Residential School

Enclosed herewith please find a letter received this date from the residential School and concerns the present waterworks system at the school.

In this regard, I wish to advise that the Principal has on different occasions complained that the unit was not operating satisfactorily and I accordingly looked over the whole unit with a view to making my recommendation.

The system is required to pump into an 18,000 gallon storage tank which is situated about 400 yards from the well itself. The storage tank is about 75 feet above the head of the well, being located on a hill. The well itself is a drilled well depth being about 60 feet and enclosed in 3" steel casing. The suction pipe to the pump is 3" in diameter and discharges through the pump into a 3" outlet.

The existing pump is of the "Pomona" type, and has apparently been in operation for a period of twenty years, and is undoubtedly in need of replacing. Marshall-Wells Company are agents for this particular type of pump.

The engine which drives the pump is of English manufacture and is known as a "Fetter" type. It is a 7. H.P. Diesel. This engine was apparently installed during 1934, and has given constant service since that time. It is impossible to obtain new parts, as this particular model has been discontinued. Any parts requiring replacement must therefore be made up by a machine shop. Now that a reliable source of electricity is available, it is suggested that consideration be given to having an electric motor installed.

The school being rather a large institution requires a large volume of water each day, and from the information
available we find that the present unit can only keep up with requirements after pumping from 10 to 11 hours each day. A unit of this size should be capable of pumping about 2500 gals per hour, whereas it is now pumping less than half that amount. The engineer at the school has informed me that if the pump fails to operate for one day, the school is extremely short of water. This causes a serious fire hazard as well as making sanitary conditions an impossibility. This did actually happen about the time of School Inspector Davey's inspection, and he no doubt can inform you of conditions at that time.

I would also like to point out that we are taking off a small line from this particular system in order to get water to the new Indian Day School quarters which are adjacent to the area. This will not take any appreciable supply from the system, and is urgently required to put water into the teacher's residences which are included in the new unit.

It is understood that the Department will in the near future be going ahead with a new water system in Alert Bay Indian Village, and that this system will be extended to take in the Indian Day School. The present or proposed line which will be put into the Day school shortly will then act as a secondary line and can be used by the Residential School or the Day school in the event that either system fails.

I would recommend that replacement of the existing pumping unit complete be proceeded with at the earliest possible moment, and definitely should be installed not later than the summer holidays.

"J.C. Letcher"
Acting Indian Agent.
St. Michael's School
Alert Bay, British Columbia.

The Indian agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.

Dear Sir:

As you know, the domestic water pump and engine have been giving us a great deal of trouble. On looking over the files in this office I find that the engine is a Petters Atomic Diesel 7 H.P. purchased and installed in May 1934. This engine is no longer reliable as many parts are badly worn. In October 1947 the Vancouver Agents for this engine stated that the engine is now a very old model and that parts are practically unobtainable from England as the manufacture of this model has been discontinued. Requests for a new engine or an electric motor were sent to the Indian Agent in October 1938, July 10th 1941, and May 17th 1942.

The domestic pump is a Domona installed in August 1929. The pump was last pulled in 1941 and new impeller blades were installed. In July 1945 the pump behaved in a spasmodic manner. The Agents for the pump suggested re-setting the impellers and this was done. On December 23rd 1947 the pump jammed. We called in the same mechanic who pulled the pump in 1941, and he suggested that one of the sections may have broken and dropped off. It was impossible to undertake a complete overhaul at that time, so he freed the pump and it has operated since, but at a considerably reduced output. Spare parts have been ordered but they will have to be specially made at the factory.

It is obvious that both the pump and engine have given good service and that both should be replaced.

Yours truly,

"B.O.G. Dixon"
Principal.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Alert Bay Residential School
Water System

As instructed in your letter of April 27, 1948,
I looked into the water system at Alert Bay Indian Residential
School on May 16 to May 21 and hereby submit the following:

This residential school is situated on Lot 1957,
Rupert District. It is on Cormorant Island within a mile
of the white settlement of Alert Bay, B.C. Two hundred and
twenty-five people and some thirty head of stock are dependent
upon the water supply.

Present Water System

The present water system is as described in Mr.
W.G. Warren's report of May 2, 1930 except that the 5 H.P.
crude oil engine as originally installed was replaced with a
7 H.P. crude oil engine in 1934. (Letters referring to this
replacement are on file in the Indian Commissioner's office,
Vancouver, B.C.)

Distribution System in Good Condition

The concrete storage tank and all steel and cast iron
mains are in excellent condition. An inspection of all faucets
and water closets at 11 p.m. on May 16, 1948 showed that these
were in good repair. A check on the storage tank level at
9:15 p.m. May 20 to 6:15 a.m. May 21, gives further proof that
the piping system is in good condition. (See Appendix II)

Pumping Equipment

Since the distribution system is without leaks, the
excess time of pumping could be contributed to unnecessary
running of faucets or to poorly operating pumping equipment.
The pumping equipment consists of an Atomic Petters Engine
rated at 7 H.P. at 650 r.p.m. This engine drives through a
24" pulley, a flat belt with a \( \frac{1}{2} \) turn to the pulley on a Pomona deep well turbine pump. According to the quotation of March 23, 1929 from Pumps and Power, this pump will deliver 30 to 50 U.S. gpm when operating at 1750 rpm. It is made up of 15 stages and the column is 3\( \frac{1}{2} \)" diameter, the drive shaft \( \frac{3}{8} \)" diameter stainless steel supported by ballless rubber bearings at 10 ft. intervals.

**Test Runs on Pump**

A test run of the pumping unit was made on May 16, 1948 and the data collected is given in Appendix I, together with a graph of quantity pumped in relation to pressure at surface of well. It should be noted that the pump ran at approximately 1610 rpm., the engine at 600 rpm, apparently being governed to that speed. If the engine ran at the rated speed of 650 rpm, the pump would run at 1750 rpm which closely corresponds to that shown on Pumps and Power quotation of March 22, 1929. A graph showing the expected capacity at the higher speed is also shown in Appendix I. By adjusting the setting of the impellers the quantity delivered can be varied somewhat.

A further test was made on the pumping unit by recording the time operated and the water levels in the storage tank from day to day. This data is given in Appendix II. This data shows that the average daily consumption is 22,400 U.S. gallons or about 100 U.S. gallons per person per day.

On May 21 the engine was not running at 600 rpm but varied considerably. It is estimated it ran at \( \frac{3}{4} \) speed for much of the time. Also it was noted that on May 22 the engine was running poorly. On removal of base plate it was noted that the crank shaft bearing had excessive play. Timing gears seemed to be in good condition but cams were worn.

The pump itself cannot be checked thoroughly without withdrawing from the well but it is considered that it is in fair condition. The seizing which occurred in December, 1947 was probably due to the impellers running on the seats, which
Recommendations

It is recommended that the Petter 7 H.P. Atomic Diesel Engine be removed from its foundation and shipped to the agents, namely, B. C. Equipment Co., of Vancouver, for advice and estimate on a complete overhaul. This firm has a complete stock of parts for this engine and it is considered by the undersigned that the engine will be found to be well worth overhauling. The freight and cartage from Alert Bay to Vancouver is estimated to be $6.35 for steamship freight and $6.65 for trucking, making a total of $13.00. Upon remounting the engine after overhauling, the pump impellers should be adjusted to the correct setting and a test run made. It is further recommended that some care be taken to prevent wastage of water.

Alternative Recommendation

If the Petters engine is not found to be worth overhauling, consideration should be given to a direct drive electric motor, automatically controlled from a float switch in the reservoir.

Time to do Work

A new well on the school subdivision of Lot 1957 was interconnected to the Residential school system in May, 1948. This new well and pump can handle the requirements of the school when in session. However, as the well and equipment has not been proved over many days, it would be better not to depend on it until the summer vacation. Therefore, it is considered that the diesel engine for the Residential School well should be sent to Vancouver for overhaul immediately upon the closing of the school for summer vacation and the new well operated to meet school requirements. Overhaul should be complete in about twenty-one days.

inspecting equipment and St. Michael's Indian Residential School

of school.

the beds now in use.

Re: Alert Bay Residential School
Kwakelth Indian Agency, B.C.

We have memoranda from Mr. Hoey dated July 26th and August 5th 1948, bearing notations from your office dated July 27th, and August 5th respectively.

In the first instance Mr. Hoey advises that $4000.00 has been included in the 1948-49 estimates for waterproofing the main school building, while the latter memorandum quotes from a letter to Indian Commissioner Arneil by Superintendent Todd, wherein the need for major repairs to the plumbing system is reported.

Commenting on the need for waterproofing, this Division conducted an investigation on the school in 1941, and a comprehensive report was furnished to Indian Affairs, including an estimate of cost amounting to approximately $4000.00. Indian Affairs advised on June 5th, 1941, that no funds could be made available for the work that year, and the matter has been dormant until the present. It is apparent that the amount of the 1941 estimated cost was included in the Indian Affairs 1948-49 annual estimates.

Not only will the available funds be greatly below present costs, but water infiltration will have added tremendously to damage apparent when the report was made. A further investigation will be necessary, and it will not likely be possible to initiate work this year. Further the need for extensive plumbing repairs has arisen, and should be included when any additional examination of the building is made.

We are therefore writing to Mr. Webb at Vancouver, requesting him to assign an officer to this work, and to furnish us with a complete report, with estimate of cost. Upon receipt a summary with recommendations will be furnished to you for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

Mr. Hoey - For your information.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Accounts - St. Michael's Anglican Indian School, Alert Bay, B.C.

In April, 1948, I received the enclosed certified account, dated 31st March, 1948, of Peterson & Edward of Alert Bay for $87.50 covering the provision and installation of a burner at St. Michael's School. I sent it to the Principal with instructions to take up with your local Agent the question of payment as it appeared to be a service for which your Department normally assumes responsibility in Government-owned Schools. I have just been advised by the Principal that your Agent has returned the account to him with advice that it must be paid by the School. I am forwarding this account to you with the request that it be paid direct by the Department under the provisions of your recent formula.

I enclose also duplicate copies of a certified account dated 30th April, 1948, of Pumps and Power Limited, Vancouver (their invoice No. 9542-J) for $345.35 covering repair parts for pump. In forwarding this account, our Principal makes the following comment:

"The account with Pumps and Power Ltd although dated April 30 was incurred at the end of December, 1947, when we were having a good deal of trouble with the water pump. Mr. Letcher, then acting Indian Agent, was away for the Christmas holidays but as Mr. Todd was in Alert Bay I asked him for permission to buy these parts and he gave me that permission. I have nothing in writing to prove that but it seems to me that if proof in writing has to be produced for every conversation between a Principal and Indian Agent then there is something very wrong about the set-up."

As this service appears to be covered by your Formula for Government-owned schools, I would request that this account too be paid direct by the Department.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Alert Bay Indian Residential School - Kwawkewlth Agency, B.C.

Regarding memoranda from Director of Indian Affairs dated July 26th and August 5th and your marginal notes thereon, and further to our letter of August 20th, Mr. Webb has had a general survey made of the school and in a report dated November 2nd advises as follows:

1. Arrangements were made to have Mr. Ward of Alert Bay submit a price to Indian Affairs for work in connection with an improvement to the hot water supply which it is considered will correct the present condition.

2. It was also arranged to have Mr. Ward re-install the water supply pump engine which has been sitting outside the pumphouse since its return from overhaul in Vancouver. Cost of this is to be paid by Indian Affairs.

3. The wooden floor in the Assembly Hall and Boys room requires replacement. An estimate re this work of $800.00 was supplied to the Indian Commissioner.

4. The question of the provision of a second wash room for smaller boys was considered and an estimate of $600.00 re this has been supplied to the Indian Commissioner.

5. The Preventorium in connection with this school was looked over. A considerable amount of repair work is necessary, chiefly as follows:

   (a) Finishing basement and installing necessary drains...........$1,100.00
   (b) Placing siding over basement.. 200.00
   (c) Roofing - duroid type......... 300.00
   (d) New furnace installed..........1,000.00
   (e) Decorating and new lining of lower panel of wards with three ply or masonite................400.00

   $3,000.00

The above figures are considered liberal and work, if done by contract, might be carried out for a lesser amount, and if so, any balance could be used for improvement of porches off the wards. These are very desirable. If detailed plans are required, arrangements will be made to secure these at an early date.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
6. Plumbing - Although plumbing in the school was reported to be in bad shape, an examination did not confirm this report. No taps were found to require repairs and, while some minor repairs are required to toilets, nothing which could not be considered maintenance was noted.

7. Waterproofing - Unfortunately, due to the absence of the principal, who has in any case only been there a few months, and an almost completely new staff, also to the fact that Alert Bay was having an unusually dry spell, it was not possible to determine the full extent of the waterproofing urgently needed. The only part of the building on which details were secured were the front walls in the basement. It would appear that if the sum of $4,000.00 is again made available, it would be possible to contract for a certain part of this building, say the front, to be carried out during next summer season when rainfall is less likely than can be expected between now and the end of the fiscal year. It is suggested the work be done in June, July or August, when monthly precipitation average is in the vicinity of 2 inches, whereas the average increases from that figure to over 3 inches in December and is still 4.75 in March.

If it proposed to do this work in 1949-50, it is suggested work be done by contract and that tenders be called for in April so that successful tenderer can get work completed in the good months. In the meantime, arrangements will be made to inspect the building after a wet period to definitely determine the points in walls where leaks are occurring.

Re Item 7, Waterproofing, it has been our experience that a partial waterproofing job is never satisfactory; moisture works around through the unwaterproofed areas and destroys the value of the work.

This report is supplied for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch for inclusion or rejection in their 1949-50 estimates. If it is decided to do this work in whole or part, we will have Mr. Webb secure definite estimates.

Chief Engineer.

Indian Commissioner Arneil has submitted to this office for payment your voucher #717 for $25.50 covering the cost of overhauling and testing the Petter engine at the Alert Bay Residential School.

We have reviewed our file and do not appear to have been requested to give authority for repairs to this engine, nor is there any explanation attached to your voucher intimating why such a heavy expenditure was necessary.

We have on our file a report from the Lands and Development Services Branch regarding a report they received from their British Columbia representative dated November 2, 1948. This report read in part as follows: "It was also arranged to have Mr. Waite re-install the water supply pump which has been sitting outside the pump house since its return from overhaul in Vancouver".

We presume that the above report referred to the Petter engine and if so, we would like to know why there was a delay in reinstalling the engine.

Payment of the account will be withheld until your reply is received.

The Principal of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School has requisitioned for a washing machine, for use in his residence, and Superintendent Todd has recommended the supply of this equipment. This is a matter which was discussed during the visit I made to the School and I am of the opinion that provision of an electric washing machine is warranted.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources,
Vancouver, B.C.

From past reports made in respect to St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, the Department is aware of conditions that have existed during recent years, and also that a concentrated effort is being made to bring the physical condition of this school back to where it should be.

Several inspections have been made by officials from various Departments who are responsible for certain work to be done. Certain recommendations have been made, approved, and some money authorized for repairs. I have been giving personal attention to these repairs and I am pleased to advise you that what we have been able to complete to date has made a marked improvement, but there is still much to be done, particularly with heating, plumbing and electrical installations. The kitchen was allowed to get in a deplorable condition. The Department have completed the following repairs to date:

1. Kitchen: Two large Army Camp cookhouse kitchen ranges (two ovens each) have been installed with new stove pipe. One kitchen range had coils put in it and connected up direct to a small hot water tank in the kitchen to give them surplus hot water.

The walls of the kitchen are glazed tile. A year ago the School obtained a spray gun and painted the ceilings and part of the walls with paint. The walls were very dirty and greasy and this was not removed before painting, which not only darkened the kitchen but made it necessary that we purchase special acid to remove the paint and grease from the walls before redecorating could be done. The tile walls should never have been painted but rather washed. The other equipment such as tables, cupboards, etc., have all been gone over, and the kitchen is now in excellent shape.

2. The scullery equipment is being repaired, which is also now in good shape.

3. The plaster on the dining-room walls was all falling off. This has been repaired and the room painted. This is also now in good shape.

4. The boys' washroom has had the plumbing repaired and simple showers installed.

5. New lockers in the boys' playroom have also been installed.

6. Practically all broken window panes have been replaced.

7. Repairs to the diesel pumping engine have been made at a cost of over $400.00, and a new belt for same was also purchased and supplied. Their domestic water system is now in good working order.

8. A new electric washing machine for the residence has been purchased as well as some rugs for the residence and staff quarters.

Other minor repairs too numerous to mention have been completed.
Materials to lay new floors in the auditorium and junior boys' playroom are ordered and expected shortly. This installation will be made immediately upon receipt of the materials.

Materials for back porch steps have been purchased and received and this installation is being made at the present time.

Materials to hook up our high pressure boiler with the hot water domestic tank have been purchased but the installation is being held up waiting one safety valve. It seems to me that if Gordon and Belyea, Ltd., cannot supply this an effort should be made to purchase it from some other firm in Vancouver so that we will get some hot water in the school. This installation has been delayed nearly two months waiting the receipt of this valve.

Sufficient fence material has been purchased and supplied the school. This will be built as a manual training project when weather permits.

Electrical

When this school was constructed no provision was made for sufficient outlets including plug-ins for radios, reading lamps in staff quarters and office. At that time very few electrical appliances were used. As years went by the Department installed a frigidaire, electrical appliances in the laundry and kitchen, with the result that the school administration made temporary connections resulting in exposed wires running in all directions all through the school. About a year ago the school electric light plant, after nearly twenty years service, collapsed with the result the administration made an arrangement with the B.C. Power Commission to use D.C. power. This change-over from D.C. to A.C. meant considerable of the electrical equipment was of no further use without being changed over accordingly. When the hook-up to the B.C. Power Commission A.C. transmission line took place, a proper installation was not made with the result that the line was overloaded and continually burning out. I discovered this during one of my inspections sometime ago and sent a local electrician to the school to change the lead-in to remove fire hazard; but even this is only a temporary installation.

In my opinion, all these exposed wires and temporary installations (none of which would pass Government regulations) are a real fire hazard to this building and the lives of those who live therein. I requested the local electrician to make a survey of the school and then make a report, so that the Department will have some indication as to what is necessary, and be a guide as to what should be done to make this building safe.

I attach hereto copy of his report. In reviewing his report I feel it should be broken down into two parts: First, materials and labour to rewire and make necessary installations where necessary to comply with Government regulations. Second, to change over the present system of operating a diesel engine in the laundry to individual motors attached to each machine in the laundry; the diesel engine being worn out. I am fearful of fire and would kindly ask that Mr. Arnell give this his personal attention immediately upon his arrival back from the East.

Heating

This school is inadequately heated under the present set-up and has been for a number of years. The Department of Public Works Boiler Inspector recommended to increase the efficiency of the plant that a condensation pump be installed. This recommendation has been made on two occasions by the Boiler Inspector but no action has been taken. I am recommending that the question of this installation should receive immediate consideration and referred to the Boiler Inspector with a request that he advise our Department the type of condensation pump that would be suitable to correct this situation. The residence and school proper have been cold this winter and we are fortunate that we have not had a great deal of illness. I believe the administration
partially responsible for inadequate heat. In years gone by the school used mill-run coal almost entirely which, no doubt, gave a more intense heat. At the present time they are short of fuel and trying to fire the furnace with green, wet slabs to effect economy. However, I feel the Boiler Inspector's recommendation to install a condensation pump is necessary, and would ask that the installation of this be made as soon as possible.

Domestic Hot Water Supply

This is very inadequate - so much so that they cannot obtain sufficient hot water to bath the children. The principal informed me yesterday that some of the children had not had a bath for two weeks. The hot water is heated by a small hot water jacket. This hot water jacket needs considerable repairs and the Boiler Inspector has recommended that a larger hot water heater should be installed of suitable type for three hundred people to take the place of the present small worn-out heater. I would recommend that we request the Boiler Inspector to advise us the type and size of hot water heater to be installed and that immediate action be taken to purchase same and have the installation made.

This is a very serious situation from a health point of view as it is not possible to have sufficient hot water for the children and staff. To give you some indication as to the unclean condition of the children, I should like to mention this. A few days ago I accompanied Dr. Barelay to the Residential School one evening and assisted him in tuberculin testing. Dr. Barelay asked me to scrub the arms preparatory to hypodermic injection. One hundred seventy children were tested and I was amazed to see the dirty condition of a great many of these children. It was so bad that even after I had scrubbed the arm with alcohol, Dr. Barelay returned several pupils to me thinking I had missed them. It was rather embarrassing to the principal but his reply simply was that they had no hot water and thus could not keep the children clean. I attach a letter from the principal re this situation which will be self-explanatory.

I recall many years ago Mr. Anfield, then principal, having difficulty in getting sufficient hot water for domestic purposes. To overcome this the engineer put coils in one of the large boilers to supplement the hot water heater. Evidently this was against Government regulations because when the Boiler Inspector came the following year he ordered that they be removed. This was done and they have been struggling to get by ever since with the present small hot water heater. The Boiler Inspector has also recommended that certain installations be installed. This would help and I am enclosing requisition for this material. I also attach requisition for parts and materials ordered to be installed by the Boiler Inspector.

I am informed $4,000.00 was provided in this year's estimates to waterproof the exterior walls of the Residential School, but due to the Engineers not being able to have the work done in suitable weather, this money will not be used for that purpose this year. I am drawing this to your attention because I believe every cent of this money should be used for emergency repairs such as purchasing necessary equipment to provide ample heat and hot water, also to purchase materials and rewire part of the building to make it safe and remove present fire hazard.

This somewhat lengthy report is being made to keep the Department fully aware as to conditions in this Residential School. I should like to say that our new principal, Rev. Edwin Allsopp, is doing his best to correct a difficult situation including the physical condition of the building and in the classrooms. I find the children cheerful and happy discipline improved. Mr. Allsopp seems to handle the children well and is liked and respected. When Mr. Allsopp assumed his duties as principal he undertook a difficult task but with patience, firmness and kindness, he is making progress.

He has been able to employ a first-class kitchen matron who has been with the Department for many years. Miss Muir is a good cook, provides excellent meals for both the children and the staff and this has been one of the main factors in bringing about a happy situation.

p.t.o.
Staff problem is still a worry for the principal and until he obtains efficient supervisors, teachers and other staff members, particularly those in key positions, it will be impossible for him to do much more. The school has not been inspected this term. From observations during my many visits to this school in recent months my views are as follows:

Teaching Staff: The manual training instructor appears to have accomplished very little during the term. He appears listless, with little initiative, and is not of much assistance to the principal. It is requested that the school inspector investigate this part of the curriculum thoroughly on his next visit to the school.

There are four classrooms, one of which is on the half-day system. Only one qualified teacher is employed and she is very good. The other three teachers were only supervisors in the school but were transferred to the teaching positions when a change in the staff took place. They have no teaching qualifications.

Engineer and Matron: The engineer employed has no papers - not even fourth class, and in my opinion is one of the weakest members of the staff. On practically every visit I have made to the school I have found the boiler room and other parts of the building which come under his care in a filthy condition. He is very sloppy in his work and seems very uninterested. Minor repairs which he should be doing are left undone. On all my visits I have never found him actually working. He seems to like to sit around and complain about everything in general. I wish to point out that the Government have a very large investment in valuable equipment which needs constant attention; otherwise, we are going to be constantly called upon to make expensive, major repairs due to the fact that an inexperienced, inefficient person is in charge. I am going to be quite frank and say that I do not think he is rendering the service the principal needs to keep the school in good running order. I will be making a further report later in connection with this position.

I also feel that the young matron, who has had little experience, is not able or willing to give the principal much support. I do not wish to comment further.

On most visits I find the school not as tidy and clean as I would like to see it but there is a vast improvement from a year ago. This, no doubt, can be attributed to lack of supervision.

The farm seems to be a thing of the past. The large herd of cattle which in former days supplied plenty of rich milk for the children, have now been disposed of. It can now only be considered as a vegetable and fruit garden. I believe the farming instructor is a very conscientious, faithful worker, and should be a real support to Mr. Allsopp.

I understand the school have increased the wages slightly, effective as from January 1st, 1949, and I attach hereto copy of the present salaries paid.

Some repairs and replacements in plumbing and sewerage are required are required, and this will be dealt with in another report.

In view of the fact that the school has permitted staff members to carry out alterations in the building proper to suit their personal needs, and that of the school, by making changes in electrical and plumbing installations, etc., without authority from our Department, and which has now proved dangerous to life and against standard Government regulations; I am recommending that our Department issue instructions that this be discontinued and that no changes or alterations be made in the physical condition of the building without proper authority from the Department.

p.t.o.
I should like to state that the Rev. Allsopp is making a determined effort to correct the situation of a year ago, and is gradually succeeding. To me it is just a matter of having efficient staff - he cannot do it alone.

This office is giving him every support possible and will continue to do so, and it is hoped that the Indian School Commission will make every effort to obtain efficient help even though they may have to pay key employees a higher salary than at present. If that were done, I can see this school return to the high standard of efficiency of former years.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.
