Mr. M. S. Todd,
Superintendent of Indian Agencies,
Alert Bay, B.C.

Dear Mr. Todd:

Recently I had the occasion to call the attention of the Supervisors to the matter of appearance and cleanliness of the children resident in this school. I discovered that certain of the boys had not been bathed for a period of two weeks. The explanation given by the Supervisors concerned was to the effect that they had been unable to obtain sufficient hot water for bathing purposes. Also the grimy appearance of the boys' hands was due to the fact that hot water was not available for washing purposes.

I would refer you to the Inspector's report dated October 1st, 1948, referring to remarks on sheet re Boiler No. 44262 where he states as follows: "A new hot water heater should be installed, of suitable capacity for 300 people to take the place of the discarded heating pipes from the boiler." I have also received many complaints from staff members as to the inadequacy of the hot water supply.

As you are already aware, we find the Indian children generally subject to various skin diseases and it is important, as a matter of control, that strict cleanliness is insisted upon at all times.

I shall be grateful if you would bring this matter to the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs with a view to having a new water heater system installed at the earliest possible moment. I assure you that every care is taken to ensure the economical use of the hot water supply. Nevertheless, you will realize from what I have stated above that, at the present time, it is absolutely impossible to obtain a regular supply of hot water comparable with the normal requirements of this institution with a total resident population of 230 people.

Yours truly,

"J. Edwin Allsopp"
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I recently made a service call at the Indian Residential School to repair defective wiring originally installed to power a one h.p. refrigeration plant.

I found that the original two wire 110 volt, 30 ampere service was powering, in addition to the original load of the refrigerator plant, two motor-driven 120 watt Ironers; one 1000 watt Hand Iron; a one-third h.p. motor; two employees' houses and five outlet receptacles. This load on an overfused switch resulted in heat damage to the switch to the extent that it was useless. I made temporary repairs and returned next day to make a more careful survey of the wiring in the school in company with the school engineer.

The original wiring installed for 110 volt D.C. current was adequate for the restricted capacity of the plant in use.

When use of this plant was discontinued and 220 volt A.C. was drawn from city mains, and power equipment added in the laundry and at other points in the building, a lot of makeshift wiring was put in and in many cases this wiring is not only a fire hazard but is dangerous to personnel.

The building throughout is inadequately lighted by any standard and except where they have been added since the original wiring there are no outlet receptacles. This has resulted in improvised circuits strung on lamp cord in many parts of the building—a dangerous practice at best.

The diesel motor powering the laundry machines is ready for replacement. With this in mind, and general state of the wiring throughout the building, disrepair and inadequacy, I would strongly recommend that a new three phase 220 Volt A.C. service be installed, and that the original lighting circuits in good repair be powered from this.

That wiring in disrepair and other dangerous circuits be replaced and powered from this.

That the washing machines be powered by individual motors and the line shaft and belting be discarded.

That additional circuits be installed to provide at least a minimum standard of good lighting in classrooms, sewing rooms, dormitories, infirmaries, offices, work rooms and recreation rooms.

Following are listed points in the building where improvements are necessary:

Two playrooms require outlet receptacles.

Kitchen requires additional lighting and outlet receptacles.

Power kitchen mixer be replaced or powered with A.C. motor. (Now done.)

Exhaust fans in drying rooms be replaced by A.C. units. Wiring to these should be replaced.

Laundry requires outlet receptacles for irons and mangle.
Engine room requires outlet receptacles for power tools and trouble lights.

Boiler room requires additional and improved lighting.

Main offices require additional lighting and outlets for best illumination.

Fifteen staff rooms now using lamp cord circuits require properly wired outlet receptacles.

Sewing rooms require additional lighting and outlet receptacles.

Dispensary requires more light and outlet receptacles.

An infirmary used for x-ray and dental clinics requires improved lighting and adequate outlet receptacles.

Boys' infirmary requires more light and provision for heat treatments, etc.

The principal's residence requires outlet receptacles in living-room and kitchen.

The garage requires three lights and one outlet receptacle for small power tools.

The farmer's house has an inadequate entrance service. Requires porch light.

Engineer's house requires improved entrance service. Dangerously inadequate wiring to outlet receptacles should be replaced.

Listed are items only intended to provide a minimum standard of lighting and service outlets for an institution of this type and such changes and additions as will bring the wiring within the minimum requirements of the Electrical Code.

The type and cost of added lighting fixtures and machines would decide the overall cost of carrying out such a program of improvement but, providing for laundry motors, exhaust fans for drying rooms and A.C. motor for kitchen mixer and fluorescent fixtures for the sewing rooms, together with all wiring, appliances, materials and labour, the final cost would not exceed $3,150.00.

Yours truly,

"W. Keele"
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

During my absence from duty in 1948 Mr. J. C. Letcher, Acting Indian Agent, arranged for the purchase of the material listed on the attached invoice #5799 of Stanley Brock Ltd., Vancouver. When the invoice was received no prepaid freight bill was attached and accordingly the voucher was paid less the $2.00 prepaid charges, as shown on the invoice. At the same time we wrote to Stanley Brock Ltd. requesting them to forward us the prepaid express bill but heard nothing from them.

Later a letter was received from Canon H. G. Cook, Superintendent of the Indian School Administration, in which he was making inquiries about the payment of this invoice and also another one from Stanley Brock Ltd. Upon investigation we find Stanley Brock Ltd. billed the Indian School Administration, Ottawa, for $1.40, it being additional charges covering prepaid express on their invoice #5799. Prepaid express bill covering the charges was attached to the invoice and is now in the office of the Indian School Administration, Ottawa.

Evidently the School broke a hinge on the extractor in the laundry and ordered another one to replace the broken part. This was done without consultation with the Department, and it is presumed they felt it was a rightful charge against the school and intended to pay for it themselves but failed to do so. I attach hereto copy of invoice #6346 covering this account in the amount of $17.90.

As we are unable to obtain the prepaid express bill covering invoices #5799 and #2242, and as the Department did not authorize the charges amounting to $17.90, I am forwarding the file direct to Ottawa and would kindly ask that you interview Canon Cook relative to his payment of this account in the amount of $17.90. The payment of $3.40 express charges is the responsibility of our Department but we cannot do anything about it as the Indian School Administration have the receipted express bill in their office.

With reference to Mr. Pratt's letter of February 14th and Supt. Todd's report of February 1st regarding conditions at the Alert Bay Residential School, there has been some delay in dealing with this matter due to difficulty in determining exactly what is required and securing prices and estimates of costs. Even now it is apparent that some of the requirements cannot possibly be attended to this fiscal year. Mr. Todd has dealt with these requirements under various headings:

(1) Electrical: Mr. Keele's report with regard to the wiring, etc., is quite comprehensive but is not sufficiently detailed to form a basis for a contract with him. Mr. Todd is being requested to discuss the matter with him with a view to securing a detailed tender on the work necessary.

immediately I would request that I be so advised by Army Signals so that delivery can be taken before March 31st.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 7th last, file #875-5 (E.1), in respect to Voucher #244, amounting to $194.43, dated January 31st last, in connection with repairs to the laundry and fire pump engines at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. I regret that I did not write you a covering letter explaining this expenditure as there was no authorization given by Ottawa prior to the work being done.

For your information both these engines broke down about the same time which meant immediate action had to be taken. Prior to this breakdown Commissioner Arneil had inspected the School in company with myself and the late Col. Whyte of the Surveys and Engineering Branch. At that time the School Engineer pointed out to us that neither engine were working properly and we had had under consideration reporting the matter to Ottawa and requesting authority to have these units overhauled, but before I could take this action the breakdown occurred.

As the work had to be done to protect the school from fire and to allow them to continue with their laundry, I immediately arranged for a local mechanic to have the repair work done. I have no other explanation and trust that this will be satisfactory. I might add both units are now working properly.

Possibly I should also say here that the Engineer in charge at the Residential School has no papers, not even fourth class, and I have found him reluctant to make ordinary repairs. The feeling seems to be not only with the engineer himself but with the Principal himself that any repair work necessary is the responsibility of the Department with the result that as you now know, the Department have spent considerable money in this school during the past year.

p.t.o.
If our equipment received the same attention as in former years a great many breakdowns and major repairs would not occur, and it is for this reason that I am bringing it to your attention. My own opinion is that we should have an experienced engineer capable of doing ordinary repairs as needed, which would give better supervision and greater care to our equipment.

(M. S. Todd)

As requested, the Department forwarded an accountable advance amounting to $590.00 to cover the repairs recommended by the late Col. Whyte. In addition to this we had a small balance of $23.70 left over from an accountable advance forwarded by the Department, their cheque #51045 of July 16/48, for minor repairs to the Residential School.

As the time was getting short and as I was having difficulty to find suitable labour to complete the above mentioned work, I went to Mr. T. Westerlund, local contractor, and informed him of the work the Department required done, and asked him if he would undertake the work by day labour, pointing out it had to be done by March 31st, as that was the end of our year.

Mr. Westerlund accompanied me to the school where I showed him the work which was required to be done and he then stated it would be far better for him to take a contract to complete the job, as it was already evident there was a shortage of some materials which had been ordered on instructions from the Surveys and Engineering Branch. Mr. Westerlund agreed to supply any shortages of material and provide all the labour for the full amount of $598.40.

As this was the only way in which I could complete this work before the end of the year, I drew up a tender which covered the necessary material and all labour to complete the job, and this was signed by Mr. Westerlund.

The work was completed by March 31st and we received a very satisfactory job and I attach the tender to the Credit Voucher #347, and trust the Department will approve of the action I have taken.

Attached find requisition for materials received from Principal Allsopp for repairs to various projects. In submitting this requisition there is some doubt in my mind whether it is our responsibility to provide this material or not.

The 18½ M Shingles is to reshingle the woodshed and root house. These old buildings were not built by the Department but rather by the school itself. In regard to the reshingling of the woodshed this building was built by the school as a cover for wood when they changed over from burning coal to wood. When the school was built the Department provided a fuel bin for coal sufficient to take care of their needs but later the school thought they could reduce the cost of fuel by burning wood and this building was erected. I am inclined to feel that if they wished to use this building it is the school's own responsibility and they should pay for the repairs out of the grant.

In regard to the shingles for the root house, this also was built by the school but now as they have no stock and not using the barn I can see no reason why the vegetables cannot be stored therein and used as a root house.

The item on this requisition which I feel is the responsibility of the Department is the 2,000 fbm. 2 x 10 Rough Fir Planking, which is to be used to repair steps and sewerage covers. I will mark on the requisition the items I consider we should supply.

If the Department considers they should supply the total requisition, it is satisfactory with me but I felt I should give you this information so that you can make a decision as to responsibility.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, July 5, 1949.

Res: Alert Bay Indian Residential School,
Alert Bay, British Columbia.

In accordance with a request from Major MacKay, you are advised that our Mr. Hargreaves visited the above on the 5th and 6th of June, and carried out an inspection of the mechanical services. His report may be summed up as follows:

This building was erected in 1929 and is generally substantially sound. It must be stated however, that additional attention to general all round cleanliness would make conditions more attractive inside and out.

The heating plant consists of two portable fire box type steel low pressure steam heating boilers of approximately 44 horsepower each, with an allowable working pressure of up to 10 lbs. per square inch, permitted by the Provincial Boiler Inspector on his 1949 inspection report. The boilers are fired with slab wood of very poor quality in an effort to cut operating expenses.

The distribution system consists of a two pipe low pressure steam and is run to the various parts of the building in a fairly good manner with some exceptions. The Principal's residence which is integrally built, is impossible to heat. This is caused by a faulty arrangement of the branch mains in the basement of this area.

Condensation is returned to the boilers by gravity through a combination boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly, which is not in good operating condition, thereby contributing to improper circulation. As the result of this design, in which no traps are used at the ends of the mains and branch mains, the rooms farthest from the boiler can not be properly heated.

The radiation is sufficiently large with some exceptions. The radiator traps and valves appear to be in relatively good condition and should function efficiently when the problem of distribution is overcome.

The domestic hot water requirements could never be met with the present undersized burnt out, and ill-designed equipment. The domestic hot water storage tank has capacity of approximately 800 gallons and appears to be sound. The jacket heater is practically burnt out, and is far too small to cope with the normal demand. A line connected to the tank from the high pressure boiler does not, nor could be expected to materially increase the heating capacity even if no other service from this boiler was to be provided. The high pressure boiler is rated at 165 horsepower and the hourly heating rate of the domestic hot water demand is equal to a minimum of 25 horsepower. The high pressure boiler incidentally is in good condition and large enough to meet the requirements of the laundry services for which it was originally intended.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
In addition to the foregoing, various arrangements of coils in the heating boilers have been tried out and have failed. On one attempt to increase the domestic hot water capacity, coils were installed in the smoke box of one of the heating boilers. This has resulted in the smoke box rusting out when the coil broke and will have to be replaced as soon as possible, in order to keep this boiler in service.

It was noted that the domestic hot water piping system was somewhat undersized, but it is felt that it is unnecessary at this time to replace it in its entirety. This piping will in all probability have to be replaced however within the next 5 to 6 years.

The drainage system was brought to the attention of our officer. It was reported by the caretaker and Principal, to be plugged in some sections. Careful observations on the part of our officer leads us to believe that most of this trouble has been the result of a lack of supervision in the basement where the bulk of the plumbing fixtures are. The same holds true with the dormitory where several W.Cs are located for emergency use at night.

One floor drain in the basement was found to be packed solid with sand and dirt and it is logical to blame this on improper supervision and a lack of good housekeeping. The drainage system will have to be cleaned out and it has reached the stage where the maintenance staff at the school can not cope with this job, due to the lack of suitable tools and a knowledge of how to use them.

Our officer was informed that the underfloor drains were laid in tile, but could find no basis to support this. Tile lines are used outside the building to carry raw sewage to a discharge point in the bay with no intervening septic tank. This is a deplorable method as much of the raw sewage is washed on to the beach at high tide. If a septic tank were installed, the effluent could then be safely discharged into the bay.

In order to bring the various mechanical services up to the minimum required efficiency, it is recommended that the following operations be carried out:

(a) Re-grade spring pieces and run-outs to risers and radiators where necessary.

(b) Install float and thermostatic traps at ends of all steam and branch mains.

(c) Remove present boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly and replace with suitable condensation pump and receiver making some minor changes to the piping at the rear of the boilers.

(d) Replace pipe covering on steam mains and branches, in sections where it has been torn off.

(e) Remove branch mains in basement in Principal's residence and replace in a manner which will be outlined on drawings.
(f) Provide an indirect steam fed heater of suitable capacity to provide adequate means of heating the domestic hot water and in conjunction with same, install self contained regulating valve assembly, for automatic control of water temperatures.

(g) If it is decided to convert from wood to coal, it would be highly desirable to install one stoker of the proper size and characteristics.

(h) In addition to the foregoing operations, there will be several minor items to be taken care of, which can only be determined when a layout and specification is prepared.

The foregoing operations cannot be accurately estimated until plans and specifications are prepared, but it may be safely assumed that if the work recommended is carried out, it will cost in the neighborhood of $8,500.00.

When advised that approval has been given, we will proceed with the design covering the revisions to the mechanical services as soon as possible.

GENERAL OBSERVATIONS

It was noted that the wiring was in a very dangerous state. Exposed lines together with evident over-loading of circuits contributes a very real source of fire hazard. Fuses are blowing regularly and the Principal was warned not to permit the use of heavier fuses than those now being used.

The fire pump located in a pump house at the bay about 1/8 of a mile from the school, was undergoing repairs. The impeller was found to be clogged with bark, pieces of wood and other foreign matter. This indicates that the strainer is either missing or so badly deteriorated, that it is of no further use. It was also noted that the governor on the diesel engine which drives this pump was not functioning properly and attempts to make satisfactory repairs had not been successful. The Indian Superintendent, Mr. Todd, was advised to replace this governor as well as to install a strainer at the end of the intake line to the pump.

The boilers appear to be in good condition, but the boiler room staff was not impressive. The boiler room was in a filthy condition and there is no excuse for such lack of attention on the part of any fireman or operating engineer. It is felt that if this fireman is to be retained, he should be advised to clean up and pay more attention to ordinary mechanical maintenance duties, which is certainly an important part of his work, and which can be expected to contribute to longer life of all items of mechanical equipment.

It is also felt that the fire pump should be connected to a suitable electric motor with a starting switch located in the Principal's office as well as a switch in the Pump House. This would assure positive starting of the fire pump when required, whereas under the present arrangement, the diesel engine must be started by hand after the operator has had time to reach the pump house.

The foregoing remarks under the heading of General Observations are not definite recommendations included in our rough estimate, but suggestions only.

Chas. H. Buck,
For Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

Ottawa, July 19, 1949.

Re: Roof Repairs and Waterproofing Walls, Alert Bay Residential School, Kwawkewlth Agency, British Columbia.

Reference Indian Affairs memorandum of July 11th and your marginal notation dated June 13th in respect to the above.

The report mentioned does not refer to the recent plumbing and heating investigations carried out by Mr. Hargreaves. It is concerned with an old standing complaint, that rain enters through the brick walls, and dates as far back as 1936. In 1938 repairs to roof and waterproofing of a portion of the east wall residence was undertaken, a sum of approximately $1,345.00 having been made available.

Since that date a number of inspections have been made and reports submitted, the latest being the present report from Mr. D.W. Gordon, dated June 24th, 1949, which in effect supports previous recommendations. The essential facts are as follows:

A portion of the east wall of the main school building and the residence have been waterproofed and appear satisfactory.

The report recommends that the following work be done:-
(a) the remaining portion of the exterior east wall and the entire exterior south wall be waterproofed (b) the infirmary gun room, which has settled, be raised and repaired (c) the roof along the south wall parapet be repaired (d) repair two leaks in residence and a crack in north concrete basement wall. All the repairs have to do with rain entering the building, a condition which is considered serious.

The cost of the above work is estimated at $4,400.00 and Mr. Gordon recommends that the work be carried out on the basis of cost plus a percentage. Mr. Gordon's statement that the work might require a contractor's fee of 15% is interpreted to mean a profit of approximately 10% with 15% for other items usually considered as payable charges exclusive of the actual cost of materials.

We consider Mr. Gordon has submitted a good report and the recommendations are concurred in, but if Indian Affairs can find funds for the work, comparative prices must be obtained for the waterproofing and roofing, and we would request Mr. Webb to provide supervision for the work while in progress.

A copy of same with Mr. Webb's covering letter is attached for the information of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Waterproofing
St. Michael's School, Alert Bay,
Kwawkewlth Agency, B.C.

In accordance with your instructions of May 13, 1949, I visited St. Michael's School at Alert Bay. The following are my observations.

References

1. Report on Proposals for Further Waterproofing of Walls and Repairs to School Roof at Alert Bay School, Kwawkewlth Agency, by W. C. Warren dated July 21, 1937.

2. Report on Inspection of St. Michael's School Alert Bay, Kwawkewlth Agency and Waterproofing Recommended by W. C. Warren, dated February 6, 1941

Location

St. Michael's School is situated at Alert Bay on Cormorant Island some 200 miles north-west of Vancouver, B.C. Alert Bay has a regular steamboat service several times a week and a daily plane service from Vancouver. The school property adjoins the Nimpkish I.R. No. 1, Kwawkewlth Agency.

General Description of School

The outside walls consist of brick veneer, structural tile backup, wooden furring strips, metal lath, and plaster. The outside brick construction is struck joint in common bond. The horizontal joints average almost half an inch in thickness, the maximum about three-quarters of an inch. Vertical joints are narrower on the average.

The bricks, being run of the kiln, are not of good quality and are pitted and possibly although none of these defects appear serious. The mortar is good and has not parted off.
The sand in the mortar appears to be coarser at the top of the building than at the bottom.

The east wall of the main school building and the residence have been waterproofed, as described in a report by W. G. Warren, dated February 6, 1941, and are still in good condition. See photo Number One in Appendix I. Most of the cracks and pitting in the south wall and parts of the north wall of the main building, laundry and auditorium walls have been filled with Minwax Caulking Compound. This compound is still in fairly good shape and seems to be sealing the cracks successfully. See photo Number Two in Appendix I. It has peeled and hardened at the outer fringes of thin sections but this separation is not spreading beyond the fringes.

During the winter of 1948-49, no water has leaked through the walls of the school except in three localized areas which are discussed later. However, this winter has been colder than usual with the result that much of the precipitation has been in the form of snow, and the driving south-easterly rain storms, which penetrated the school in previous years, have been absent. At the time the school was visited by the undersigned, Alert Bay was enjoying warm, dry weather and therefore the effect of water penetration was not evident in most places.

Defects Causing Leakage

1. There is a large crack on the north cement wall of the west basement. Water entered here last winter. This could be closed by chipping the crack out clean and refilling with cement and a waterproofing compound.

2. The reported leakage into the infirmary sun room has evidently resulted from a settling of the front brick column supports of the room. These supports have settled until the roof slopes away from its drain and the
top west side of the roof has come away from the main outside wall of the school as much as three-quarters of an inch. The supports will have to be adjusted before any caulking or waterproofing can be attempted.

3. On the main roof where the roofing sheet meets the parapet wall, it does not, in some places, lap up under the copper flashing. One bad section, in this respect, was along the eastern part of the south face of the main building. It should be noted that a lot of the seepage reported during the past few years was on floors and basement below this section.

4. There were two leaks at the residence, both active last winter. One was over the doorway between the residence and the school; the other was in the ceiling of the residence bathroom on the second floor. Neither of the sources of these leaks could be established. The roof appears to be watertight, the drains are clear, and the caulking and waterproofing above the doorway on the residence roof and the school east wall is good. It is considered that the water is entering in narrow localized holes or cracks and not seeping through large areas or walls or roof.

5. The caulking around the windows on the south side of the school, especially on sides and bottom is poor and needs replacing. The window caulking on the other walls is better but not good. However, the seepage on the south side which has occurred in previous years does not seem to have entered the inside walls around the windows.

General Location of Leakage in Previous Years

The south inside wall of the east wing on the second and third floors has leaked. The plaster has been saturated mostly between the ceiling and windows.

The plaster on the south and east part of the west dormitory on the top floor has been saturated from the floor to
a height of four feet. Water has also come in from the upper south-east corner of this dormitory.

The basement of the east wing has on several occasions collected one to two inches of water which has apparently drained down the south wall. The plaster is directly on the concrete in the basement.

Moisture has collected on parts of interior walls on other rooms facing south but not on as large areas nor as harmful as the areas just described.

Leakage on the east wall of the laundry was stopped when the drains were cleared.

It must be remembered that the discussion in this section is based partly upon conversations carried on at the school with persons previously employed there, and partly upon the evidence remaining on the walls concerned.

METHODS OF REPAIRS TO THE SCHOOL

1. Infirmary Sun Room

The front part of the sun room should be raised to its original correct elevation with screw jacks and 6" x 6" columns, using the assembly shown in Sketch Plan I. Then, steel shims inserted on top of the brick columns and the remaining space on the columns grouted in. The earth should be dug out around the present footings, half of one column at one time, and concrete support added to the footings as shown in Sketch Plan II. The total cost, including labour and materials, is estimated to be $550.00. Cost details are given in Appendix II.

II. Roof Repairs

The roofing along the south wall of the main school should be repaired in the following manner:

1. Clean gravel off present roofing surface up to two feet from the parapet wall.
2. Raise flashing enough to work on parapet.

3. Brush wall surface clean and apply layer of Plastic Elastic Gum to it and the cleared two foot section of roof.

4. Apply three layers of felt, each smeared with Plastic Elastic Gum, to cover cleared roof and to lay up parapet wall 8 to 10 inches.

5. Copper flashing, see details in Sketch Plan III, to be inserted and nailed to roof deck.

6. One layer of twelve inch wide felt smeared with Plastic Elastic Gum and layed horizontal, covering flashing as shown in Sketch Plan III.

7. Second layer eighteen inch wide felt applied as in 6.

8. Roofing surface relaid using Plastic Elastic Gum and then gravelled.

9. Replace caulking on parapet where necessary.

The total cost, including labour and materials, is estimated to be $530.00. Cost details are given in Appendix II.

III. Waterproofing Outside South Wall of Main School and Small Portion of East Wall not already Waterproofed

The total area is 7800 square feet. The net area, excluding windows and doors, is 6000 square feet. See Sketch Plan IV.

The waterproofing can be done by this office or by contract with some approved waterproofing firm.

If done under supervision of this office, the method would be as follows, using Minwax products.

1. Brush down wall surface.

2. Point and re-caulk brick where necessary.
3. Re-caulk around all windows and other openings.

4. Apply three coats Minwax Brick and Cement Coating of appropriate colour, the first two coats to be thinned with Minwax Brick and Cement Coating Thinner.

5. Paint brick molding on windows, two coats.

The total cost of above, including labour and materials, is estimated to be $3,300.00. Cost details are given in Appendix II.

The Minwax treatment could also be done by contract, probably at the same cost. However, if contracting the work is to be considered, there are available waterproofing materials which are applied with special equipment by trained operators. In some instances, the company distributing the material have their own machines and personnel for the work and in other cases, certain contracting firms specialize in the use of a specific product. Two materials which come under the above category are "Insul-Mastic" and "Tremco" products.

The cost of contracting the above is estimated to be approximately $3,500.00.

The estimated useful life of these treatments is in excess of ten years.

All of the waterproof coatings discussed have one feature in common, that is, they completely cover the brickwork and the distinctive mortar lines are lost, thus changing the pleasing architectural characteristics of a brick building. They are also subject to possible changes in colour themselves by chemical action, usually within one or two years after application. Although these changes do not affect the waterproofing qualities of the covering, the good appearance of the school might have to be restored by painting.

There are available waterproofing agents that do not alter the appearance of the original brick structure. These are transparent substances which deter absorption and have a
probable life of three to five years; comparable to the life of an ordinary paint covering. The successful use of these products necessitates the prior pointing or caulking of all holes and cracks in the brick as well as caulking around openings of doors and windows. The difficulty in ensuring the absolute sealing of all cracks in the expanse of wall at the school and the short useful life of the treatment discourages its use.

IV. Repairing Two Leaks at Residence and Crack in North Concrete Wall of West Basement

These repairs could be made easily at the same time as I and II with a slight extra cost of $20.00.

RECOMMENDATIONS

It is respectively recommended that the repairs to the concrete wall in the west basement, and to the infirmary sun room supports be carried out before October this year by this office. Total Cost $570.00.

The repairs to the school roof can be contracted or done on a cost plus basis as well as by this office. Contracting, or cost-plus, by a recognized roofing company is recommended for the following reason.

The repairs to the roof, although of a minor nature and not expensive, are vitally important to the state of the building. Any other waterproofing applied to wall, etc., will be nullified if the roof is not sound. Thus, the work could be accomplished to a greater degree of reliability by a company who are specialists in roofing and roof repair.

The cost-plus arrangement is preferred for the reason that it would be less costly than a contract. A contractor bidding on the job would have to provide for the contingency attendant upon wet weather which is a
common occurrence in that area, whereas, on the cost-plus basis, if fair weather prevails, a saving is effected.

The estimate cost of repairing the roof is $530.00.

It is further recommended that the waterproofing to the south wall be done during July and August by a reputable waterproofing company rather than under direction of this office. This is suggested because:

1. Labour and tradesmen are very difficult to obtain at Alert Bay during the summer.

2. Waterproofing a building of this size is expensive and can be better done by skilled tradesmen under experienced and qualified supervision.

Total cost of roof repairs, infirmary repair, and waterproofing south wall is estimated to be $4,400.00.

It is suggested that the window frames of the school be painted and the stucco on the infirmary sun room be replaced. These two repairs could be done by the school authorities as they are actually maintenance jobs.

Following receipt of a memorandum from Mr. T.R.L. MacInnes dated July 27th last, which carried your marginal notation of the 29th ultimo, and which transmitted concurrence by Indian Affairs in operations covered by our memorandum to you of July 15th, 1949, this office requested Mr. Webb of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau in Vancouver, to obtain competitive tenders for carrying out the recommendations included in the report prepared by Mr. Gordon of his office, dated June 16th, 1949, and which he estimated would cost approximately $4,400.00, made up of items as follows:

1. Repairs to Infirmary Sun Room and Concrete Wall in West Basement...........$ 570.00
2. Repairs to School Roof.....................$ 530.00
3. Waterproofing exterior brick walls.......$ 3,300.00

On the 10th instant however, Mr. Webb sent us an Army Signal, wherein he advised that he considered it advisable to employ an experienced roofing foreman and to execute the roofing repairs by day labour. He proposes however to draw up specifications and a contract agreement from which to obtain tenders for the waterproofing work, to be submitted to this office for approval. It is felt that the repairs to the sun room and school roof could very well be executed by day labour at less cost than by a cost plus contract. On the waterproofing work we will expect lump sum tenders.

The Indian Affairs Branch is satisfied with this arrangement, but Ministerial approval has not been obtained.

Memorandum

Re: Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, British Columbia.

Following receipt of a memorandum from Mr. T.R.L. MacInnes dated July 27th last, which carried your marginal notation of the 29th ultimo, and which transmitted concurrence by Indian Affairs in operations covered by our memorandum to you of July 19th, 1949, this office requested Mr. Webb of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau in Vancouver, to obtain competitive tenders for carrying out the recommendations included in the report prepared by Mr. Gordon of his office, dated June 16th, 1949, and which he estimated would cost approximately $4,400.00, made up of items as follows:

1. Repairs to Infirmary Sun Room and Concrete Wall in West Basement...........$570.00
2. Repairs to School Roof.....................$530.00
3. Waterproofing exterior brick walls.......$3,300.00

Estimated total Cost $4,400.00

Mr. Webb in his letter covering the submission of Mr. Gordon's report, recommended that the roofing and waterproofing work be carried out by contract, based on cost plus a percentage and that the repairs to the basement wall and infirmary sun room should be executed by day labour, all under supervision from his staff.

On the 10th instant however, Mr. Webb sent us an Army Signal, wherein he advised that he considered it advisable to employ an experienced roofing foreman and to execute the roofing repairs by day labour. He proposes however to draw up specifications and a contract agreement from which to obtain tenders for the waterproofing work, to be submitted to this office for approval. No mention is made of repairs to the sun room.

It is felt that the repairs to the sun room and school roof could very well be executed by day labour at less cost than by a cost plus contract. On the waterproofing work we will expect lump sum tenders.

The Indian Affairs Branch is satisfied with this arrangement, but Ministerial approval has not been obtained.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6429, file 875-5, part 12)
It would therefore be appreciated if approval could be obtained, allowing us to instruct Mr. Webb to purchase materials and engage labour to the best advantage locally, to execute repairs to the infirmary sun room, and school roof, under his supervision as soon as possible, at a total cost of approximately $1,100.00.

When tenders are received for the waterproofing work, we will again request you to obtain Ministerial approval.

Chas. H. Buck,
for Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

The tender submitted by Mitchell Brothers Limited, is the lowest received and conforms with all the requirements of our drawings, specifications and other tendering documents. Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

Please find hereunder Inspector Davey's report on the Alert Bay Residential School. In a discussion with him I was able to learn that little improvement can yet be noted in the classroom work, general discipline and morale of this school.

Therefore I called Canon Cook and General Turner to a meeting in my office to discuss this situation.

They realize the staff situation is far from satisfactory but advise that it is almost impossible in British Columbia to compete with local industry for general staff and with our Indian day and provincial schools for teaching staff.

I advised Inspector Davey that funds would be made available for the purchase of furniture for the staff quarters and also for paint which can be used to advantage in brightening the teachers' living accommodation.

Inspector Davey does not recommend the painting of the interior of the school until discipline has been restored to a much greater extent than at present.

While this is primarily a staff problem, the Principal would seem to be at fault in that he had not held a
single staff meeting up to the time of Inspector Davey's visit. He is apparently trying to do too much himself and is even handling some of the classroom work. This leads to the unhappy position of having the Principal tied up in a classroom when he should be supervising the many other activities of the school.

As you are aware, the contract for the heating repairs will shortly be let and we had just finished waterproofing the outside of the building. In other words, the Department has done its share in restoring this building to proper working shape and the M.S.C.C. has not been able yet to provide the proper staff.

Inspector Davey has recommended that either Mr. Caldwell or Mr. Anfield be sent to this school for a period of two weeks or more in order that their experience can be used to advantage in reorganizing the entire staff and working conditions.

I feel that these matters should be brought to your attention as this is the only residential school in British Columbia which is now not functioning in a fairly efficient manner.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education

SPECIFICATIONS

APPENDIX IV

Scope

This specification shall cover the painting of all window sash and trim and glazing of windows on the entire front (south) exterior wall of St. Michael's Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C.

Paint Work Materials

All materials shall be of good quality, standard brand and approved manufacture delivered at the building in their original sealed containers. No paint shall be reduced or altered in any way except in accordance with the manufacturer's direction or as hereinafter specified.

Unless otherwise specifically authorized, ready mixed paints, varnishes, stains and enamels of a reliable and recognized manufacture shall be used.

Colours

All work shall be finished to the colours stipulated by the engineer.

Preparation

All new work shall be thoroughly dry and cleaned of any dirt, lime or foreign matter before priming coat is applied. All knots or "sappy" areas shall be given a coat of white shellac after priming.

Nail holes, cracks and crevices shall be filled with putty after priming coat has dried, and all surfaces sanded smooth, ready for finished coats.

All old work shall be properly prepared to receive new paint work. The preparation depends entirely on the condition of the old paint work.

If the surface is smooth and unbroken and the old paint well anchored, clean off all dust and dirt and proceed as for new work.
Small areas of loose or scaly paint shall be carefully scraped or wire brushed to remove all unanchored paint, and the areas filled and sanded smooth to the plane of the remaining work.

Where the old paint is badly sealed, checked, or marred, it shall be removed with approved material and means, cleaned with turpentine or benzine and treated as new work.

Where old paint has considerable gloss, the surface shall be wiped with benzine immediately before painting to kill the gloss and avoid "creeping". Ammonia shall not be added to the paint under any circumstances.

Application

No paint or other finish shall be applied on surfaces which are damp, dirty, greasy, rough or otherwise imperfect, and each coat of paint shall be thoroughly dry before the succeeding coat is applied.

No paint or other finish shall be applied at temperatures below fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit, or under any condition unsuited to good work.

All surfaces shall be finished smooth and even and free from runs, sags, brush marks, bristles, or other defects.

Finish

All window sash and trim shall be finished with two coats of oil paint. The colour of the finish shall be that known to commerce as ivory.

Glazing

All windows shall be glazed and all broken window glass shall be replaced.

All old putty or other similar material used to secure the glass to the sash shall be removed and the glass and dry surface of the sash shall be thoroughly cleaned.
The dry surface of the sash shall be primed with boiled linseed oil in an approved manner before the glass is secured to the sash.

St. Michael's School, Alert Bay,

With reference to Memorandum re Waterproofing
St. Michael's School, Alert Bay, Kwawkewlth Agency, B.C., by
D. W. Gordon dated 16 June 1949, I beg to advise that
recommended work outlined in that memorandum has been completed.
The work accomplished, together with costs, are herein detailed
for your consideration.

School, Kwawkewlth Agency, by W. C. Warren, dated
21 July, 1937.

2. Report on Inspection of St. Michael's School,

Recommended by W. C. Warren, dated 5 February 1941.

General

The most recent report by Mr. Gordon dated 16 June
1949, provides pertinent information as to the location of
St. Michael's Indian Residential School, its structural
characteristics, and defects in the structure causing moisture
penetration through the exterior walls.

The defects causing moisture to leak into the
interior of the building were noted as follows:

(1) Basement - Moisture penetration through a crack in
the concrete at the north wall of the west basement.

(2) Infirmary Sunroom - Moisture leaking to this room
evidently resulted from settling of the brick column supports.
These supports had settled until the roof sloped away from its
drain and the top west side of the roof had been separated from the main outside wall of the school by some three-quarters of an inch.

(3) Roof Flashing - On the roof, at the south face of the main building where the roof sheeting met the parapet wall, it did not lap up under the flashing. Seepage of water was reported on the floor and basement below the section.

(4) Residence - Two leaks were reported at the residence during the winter 1948-49. One of these leaks was over the doorway between the residence and the school and the other was in the ceiling of the residence bathroom located on the second floor. It was considered that the water was entering through narrow localized holes or cracks and not through large areas of walls of roof as these appear in good condition.

(5) Caulking Around Windows - The caulking around the windows on the south side of the school was in poor condition and required replacement. It was not considered that moisture was seeping into the building around these window openings. Nevertheless, to ensure a good job of waterproofing the walls, it was deemed necessary to replace the existing caulking with fresh compound.

Repairs Made

The repairs completed and the methods employed were, with minor exceptions, those recommended. The repair of the crack in the basement wall was undertaken by the school authorities before other work of repair was started. The crack was filled with a cement and sand mortar without a waterproofing admixture.

The repair to the sunroom and the roof of the school was conducted under Mr. Gordon's direction with the use of hired labour. Undermining the brick column footings, intended in the sunroom repair, was too difficult and the alternate method shown in the attached plan was employed. The footing
dimension was increased to 4'-1" x 4'-1" and the new concrete was bonded to the existing footing by five, three-quarter inch diameter, dowels, twelve inches long. These dowels were imbedded for an equal length in the old and the new concrete. Patching of the stucco finish to the sunroom was also done at the time. This patching required only a small outlay in time and material and therefore the work was done to preserve the appearance of the building and to prevent further spalling of the stucco finish.

Also completed under Mr. Gordon's direction, with the aid of a qualified roofer, was the repair to the roof flashing. The work was done as recommended, with the minor exceptions that; (a) hot application of asphalt was used to mop on the felt rather than using the cold application initially considered, (b) sixteen ounce copper sheeting was used in place of the twenty ounce originally intended. With the lighter gauge copper, "drivins" were used to fasten the sheeting to the back of the parapet wall. The method of repairing the roof is indicated in figure 3 on the attached plan.

The cost of repairs to the sunroom columns supports and the roof flashing was $985.39. A detail of this estimate is attached.

The waterproofing of the south wall of the school was done under contract by the firm of J. T. Devlin and Company of Vancouver. Tremco Manufacturing Company products were used. The treatment consisted of sealing the masonry surface with "Tremco 101 Primer" and then applying a coating of "Tremco 101 Mastic Waterproofing". Both primer and mastic were applied with spray gun. Two coatings, and in most areas three coatings of the primer, were applied. The actual rate of application averaged one gallon per 100 square feet. The rate of application of the mastic treatment was 4½ gallons per 100 square feet.
The colour of the mastic is dark red over the entire wall surface; copings and sills are treated with a natural cement coloured mastic to contrast, and the whole presents a pleasing appearance.

Although not included in the contract agreement, the infirmary sunroom was also treated, at no extra cost, in the same way as the main wall to which it adjoins. This was done to ensure a pleasing appearance to the front elevation of the building.

All copings, sills, parapet walls, flashings and stone work on the south exterior wall of the school were caulked before the waterproofing treatment was applied. A copy of the technical provision included in the contract agreement is attached as Appendix III.

The cost of the work completed under the agreement was $3,052.00. All work was done to the complete satisfaction of Mr. D. P. Hunter, of this office, who conducted all inspections in connection with the J. T. Devlin and Company Contract. The small area on the east wall of the school noted in Mr. Gordon's memorandum was not included in the Devlin & Company contract. No treatment of any type was given to the east wall at this time. Conclusive evidence of moisture penetration through the surface was lacking. Should seepage through this wall section occur, it would be advisable in the interest of appearance of the school, to treat with the identical "Minwax" product used by Mr. W. C. Warren on the remainder of this east wall. Particulars of this treatment are given in this engineer's report of 21 July 1937.

An additional contract, that of painting and glazing sash and windows on the south face of the school, was awarded to J. T. Devlin and Company. No transfer of funds was made to the Engineering and Construction Division for the work. The contract was arranged directly between Indian Affairs Branch and the contractor. The necessary specifications were prepared.
In this office and a copy of these is attached as Appendix IV. The inspection of the work, as in the instance of waterproofing was done by Mr. D. P. Hunter.

Originally it was suggested that this work could be done by the school authorities as it was actually a maintenance task. However, the painting and glazing was not done at the time the waterproofing contract was started. It was therefore arranged to have the contractor do the work. The amount of the contract was $410.00. This contract was satisfactorily completed. The principal reason for insisting that the sash be painted at this time was the fact that the mastic waterproofing used is characteristically soft or pliable from one to three years after application. For this reason it is advantageous to ensure ladders or scaffolding are not placed against the treated walls for the first few years, as such procedure would damage the mastic finish and permit moisture to enter through the wall of the building.

Cost

The cost of the completed work outlined above was $4,447.39. A detail of this cost is attached as Appendix I.

Conclusion

The repairs to this building recommended in Mr. Gordon's memorandum of 16 June 1949 have been completed in an acceptable manner. The weather during the waterproofing operation was satisfactory. When the primer was applied, the weather was particularly good and better than average conditions for this type of work were encountered. This ensured that the walls were dry before sealing with the primary treatment. Some rain fell before the mastic application was complete. This was not serious because the walls were then impervious to moisture by reason of the priming treatment. No mastic, of course, was applied during the rain.
No further trouble with moisture penetration is expected through the exterior south wall of the school. It is expected that moisture will be experienced on the interior walls of the residence. The residence is a two-storey structure attached to the east wing of the main building. The source of entry of the moisture reported on the wall of this building could not be definitely determined and therefore no recommendation to rectify the trouble could be made.

The appearance of the school has benefitted by the work done. Appendix II, figures 1, 2, and 3, show the pleasing elevation of the front of the school after the waterproofing treatment. Other photographs in the Appendix show the marked improvements effected by the waterproofing, glazing and other repairs.

Further work could be done to advantage on the exterior of the remainder of the school, particularly on the copings and sashes. No estimate was made on the cost of restoration work necessary. However, it is respectfully suggested that this building be thoroughly examined in the near future and a comprehensive schedule of maintenance and repair work necessary be outlined for execution.

Scope

This specification shall cover the painting of all window sash and trim and glazing of windows on the entire front (south) exterior wall of St. Michael's Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C.

All materials shall be of good quality, standard brand and approved manufacture delivered at the building in their original sealed containers. No paint shall be reduced or altered in any way except in accordance with the manufacturer's direction or as hereinafter specified.

Colours

All old work shall be properly prepared to receive new paint work. The preparation depends entirely on the condition of the old paint work.

If the surface is smooth and unbroken and the old paint well anchored, clean off all dust and dirt and proceed as for new work.
Small areas of loose or scaly paint shall be carefully scraped or wire brushed to remove all unanchored paint, and the areas filled and sanded smooth to the plane of the remaining work.

Where the old paint is badly sealed, checked, or marred, it shall be removed with approved material and means, cleaned with turpentine or benzine and treated as new work.

Where old paint has considerable gloss, the surface shall be wiped with benzine immediately before painting to kill the gloss and avoid "creeping". Ammonia shall not be added to the paint under any circumstances.

Application

No paint or other finish shall be applied on surfaces which are damp, dirty, greasy, rough or otherwise imperfect, and each coat of paint shall be thoroughly dry before the succeeding coat is applied.

No paint or other finish shall be applied at temperatures below fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit, or under any condition unsuited to good work.

All surfaces shall be finished smooth and even and free from runs, sags, brush marks, bristles, or other defects.

Finish

All window sash and trim shall be finished with two coats of oil paint. The colour of the finish shall be that known to commerce as ivory.

Glazing

All windows shall be glazed and all broken window glass shall be replaced.

All old putty or other similar material used to secure the glass to the sash shall be removed and the glass and dry surface of the sash shall be thoroughly cleaned.

Glazing shall be done on the outside of the sash.

New glass shall be that quality known to commerce as single. Back pullying shall be used and the new glass shall be glazed with the convex side out. The glazing shall be done as for old panes as set out in these specifications.

Clean up

All windows and wall areas adjacent to the work shall be left clean and unmarked by paint, glazing compound, or other material employed on the work.

General

The most recent report by Mr. Gordon dated 16 June
1949, provides pertinent information as to the location of
St. Michael's Indian Residential School, its structural
characteristics, and defects in the structure causing moisture
penetration through the exterior walls.

The defects causing moisture to leak into the
interior of the building were noted as follows:

(1) Basement - Moisture penetration through a crack in
the concrete at the north wall of the west basement.

(2) Infirmary Sunroom - Moisture leaking to this room
evidently resulted from settling of the brick column supports.
These supports had settled until the roof sloped away from its
drain and the top west side of the roof had been separated from the main outside wall of the school by some three-quarters of an inch.

(3) Roof Flashing - On the roof, at the south face of the main building where the roof sheeting met the parapet wall, it did not lap up under the flashing. Seepage of water was reported on the floor and basement below the section.

(4) Residence - Two leaks were reported at the residence during the winter 1948-49. One of these leaks was over the doorway between the residence and the school and the other was in the ceiling of the residence bathroom located on the second floor. It was considered that the water was entering through narrow localized holes or cracks and not through large areas of walls or roof as these appear in good condition.

(5) Caulking Around Windows - The caulking around the windows on the south side of the school was in poor condition and required replacement. It was not considered that moisture was seeping into the building around these window openings. Nevertheless, to ensure a good job of waterproofing the walls, it was deemed necessary to replace the existing caulking with fresh compound.

Repairs Made

The repairs completed and the methods employed were, with minor exceptions, those recommended. The repair of the crack in the basement wall was undertaken by the school authorities before other work of repair was started. The crack was filled with a cement and sand mortar without a waterproofing admixture.

The repair to the sunroom and the roof of the school was conducted under Mr. Gordon's direction with the use of hired labour. Undermining the brick column footings, intended in the sunroom repair, was too difficult and the alternate method shown in the attached plan was employed. The footing
dimension was increased to 4'-1" x 4'-1" and the new concrete was bonded to the existing footing by five, three-quarter inch diameter, dowels, twelve inches long. These dowels were imbedded for an equal length in the old and the new concrete. Patching of the stucco finish to the sunroom was also done at the time. This patching required only a small outlay in time and material and therefore the work was done to preserve the appearance of the building and to prevent further spalling of the stucco finish.

Also completed under Mr. Gordon's direction, with the aid of a qualified roofer, was the repair to the roof flashing. The work was done as recommended, with the minor exceptions that; (a) hot application of asphalt was used to mop on the felt rather than using the cold application initially considered, (b) sixteen ounce copper sheeting was used in place of the twenty ounce originally intended. With the lighter gauge copper, "drivins" were used to fasten the sheeting to the back of the parapet wall. The method of repairing the roof is indicated in figure 3 on the attached plan.

The cost of repairs to the sunroom columns supports and the roof flashing was $985.39. A detail of this estimate is attached.

The waterproofing of the south wall of the school was done under contract by the firm of J. T. Devlin and Company of Vancouver. Tremco Manufacturing Company products were used. The treatment consisted of sealing the masonry surface with "Tremco 101 Primer" and then applying a coating of "Tremco 101 Mastic Waterproofing". Both primer and mastic were applied with spray gun. Two coatings, and in most areas three coatings of the primer, were applied. The actual rate of application averaged one gallon per 100 square feet. The rate of application of the mastic treatment was 4½ gallons per 100 square feet.
The colour of the mastic is dark red over the entire wall surface; copings and sills are treated with a natural cement coloured mastic to contrast, and the whole presents a pleasing appearance.

Although not included in the contract agreement, the infirmary sunroom was also treated, at no extra cost, in the same way as the main wall to which it adjoins. This was done to ensure a pleasing appearance to the front elevation of the building.

All copings, sills, parapet walls, flashings and stone work on the south exterior wall of the school were caulked before the waterproofing treatment was applied. A copy of the technical provision included in the contract agreement is attached as Appendix III.

The cost of the work completed under the agreement was $3,052.00. All work was done to the complete satisfaction of Mr. D. P. Hunter, of this office, who conducted all inspections in connection with the J. T. Devlin and Company Contract. The small area on the east wall of the school noted in Mr. Gordon's memorandum was not included in the Devlin & Company contract. No treatment of any type was given to the east wall at this time. Conclusive evidence of moisture penetration through the surface was lacking. Should seepage through this wall section occur, it would be advisable in the interest of appearance of the school, to treat with the identical "Minwax" product used by Mr. W. C. Warren on the remainder of this east wall. Particulars of this treatment are given in this engineer's report of 21 July 1937.

An additional contract, that of painting and glazing sash and windows on the south face of the school, was awarded to J. T. Devlin and Company. No transfer of funds was made to the Engineering and Construction Division for the work. The contract was arranged directly between Indian Affairs Branch and the contractor. The necessary specifications were prepared.
in this office and a copy of these is attached as Appendix IV. The inspection of the work, as in the instance of waterproofing was done by Mr. D. P. Hunter.

Originally it was suggested that this work could be done by the school authorities as it was actually a maintenance task. However, the painting and glazing was not done at the time the waterproofing contract was started. It was therefore arranged to have the contractor do the work. The amount of the contract was $410.00. This contract was satisfactorily completed. The principal reason for insisting that the sash be painted at this time was the fact that the mastic waterproofing used is characteristically soft or pliable from one to three years after application. For this reason it is advantageous to ensure ladders or scaffolding are not placed against the treated walls for the first few years, as such procedure would damage the mastic finish and permit moisture to enter through the wall of the building.

Cost

The cost of the completed work outlined above was $4,447.39. A detail of this cost is attached as Appendix I.

Conclusion

The repairs to this building recommended in Mr. Gordon's memorandum of 16 June 1949 have been completed in an acceptable manner. The weather during the waterproofing operation was satisfactory. When the primer was applied, the weather was particularly good and better than average conditions for this type of work were encountered. This ensured that the walls were dry before sealing with the primary treatment. Some rain fell before the mastic application was complete. This was not serious because the walls were then impervious to moisture by reason of the priming treatment. No mastic, of course, was applied during the rain.
No further trouble with moisture penetration is expected through the exterior south wall of the school. It is expected that moisture will be experienced on the interior walls of the residence. The residence is a two-storey structure attached to the east wing of the main building. The source of entry of the moisture reported on the wall of this building could not be definitely determined and therefore no recommendation to rectify the trouble could be made.

The appearance of the school has benefitted by the work done. Appendix II, figures 1, 2, and 3, show the pleasing elevation of the front of the school after the waterproofing treatment. Other photographs in the Appendix show the marked improvements effected by the waterproofing, glazing and other repairs.

Further work could be done to advantage on the exterior of the remainder of the school, particularly on the copings and sashes. No estimate was made on the cost of restoration work necessary. However, it is respectfully suggested that this building be thoroughly examined in the near future and a comprehensive schedule of maintenance and repair work necessary be outlined for execution.

Dear Sir:

As you know, the domestic water pump and engine have been giving us a great deal of trouble. On looking over the files in this office I find that the engine is a Petters Atomic Diesel 7 H.P. purchased and installed in May 1934. This engine is no longer reliable as many parts are badly worn. In October 1947 the Vancouver Agents for this engine stated that the engine is now a very old model and that parts are practically unobtainable from England as the manufacture of this model has been discontinued. Requests for a new engine or an electric motor were sent to the Indian Agent in October 1938, July 10th, 1941, and May 17th, 1943.

The domestic pump is a Pomona installed in August 1929. The pump was last pulled in 1941 and new impeller blades were installed. In July 1945 the pump behaved in a spasmodic manner. The Agents for the pump suggested resetting the impellers and this was done. On December 23rd, 1947 the pump jammed. We called in the same mechanic who pulled the pump in 1941, and he suggested that one of the sections may have broken and dropped off. It was impossible to undertake a complete overhaul at that time, so he freed the pump and it has operated since, but at a considerable reduced output. Spare parts have been ordered but they will have to be specially made at the factory.

It is obvious that both the pump and engine have given good service and that both should be replaced.

Yours truly,

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Proposed Conversion to Oil Firing
Alert Bay Indian Residential School

Reference is made to Major MacKay's memorandum of the 15th of February which bears your notation of the 16th in connection with the above. As you are aware, general mechanical revisions are now being carried out at the above institution by Mitchell Brothers Limited of Vancouver.

Should the Indian Affairs Branch approve of the proposed conversion to oil firing along the lines outlined below, the Contractor would be requested to submit a price, which if found to be fair and just, would be the basis on which an extra work order covering these operations could be prepared.

We have first hand knowledge that the slab wood used for fuel in this school is of very poor quality and since it is now reported that wood is increasingly difficult to obtain, it is felt that consideration should be given to the use of oil in one boiler.

The building is served by two low pressure steam steel fire box boilers, each rated at 44 H.P. One boiler oil fired, would handle the entire load including the heating of domestic hot water except under the most adverse weather conditions. Under such conditions the second boiler could be cut in to service.

It is felt that the second boiler should be kept as a standby and either fired by wood or coal. This would preclude the possibility of a total shut-down in case of electric current failure.

Based on the most up-to-date method of estimating fuel consumption and assuming a 200 day heating season, 80% efficiency of combustion with oil firing using No. 2 light diesel oil, 23,036 gallons of oil would be required, which is an average of 115 gallons per day. If the Principal's figure of 15.2¢ per gallon plus 1¢ for delivery is correct for that area, this would amount to $18.63 per day, which is under the price now being paid for slab wood.

It must be clearly understood that the above data is based on the use of light oil No. 2 or 3 so-called diesel fuel oil. Since the school electrical system is served by a generating set it would not be possible to use crude oils requiring electric preheaters as the electrical equipment is not large enough to handle additional loads which would be imposed.
Great care should be exercised in the selection of an oil burner for this school, which is remotely located from Vancouver or any other industrial centre. A burner designed embodying the most up-to-date, fool proof and trouble free operation should be selected, as it may be difficult to obtain skilled service in case of mechanical failure. Such a burner is available locally, and its characteristics have been thoroughly checked. If approval is given to this work, it is strongly recommended that the Indian Affairs Branch purchase the burner upon advice which will be given to them at a later date. However auxiliary items including the oil storage tank, controls, refractory lining in the combustion chamber together with piping and other incidental accessories could be supplied by the Contractor.

It is roughly estimated that this work could be carried out for $2,600.00. We therefore request that the Indian Affairs Branch advise us of their decision in this matter.

Chief.
Mr. W.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner,
PO Box 70, Vancouver, BC.

The writer has just returned from an inspection trip re the steamfitting and plumbing work that this firm is doing under contract to the Department of Indian Affairs re the above School.

The Boiler installation, Condensate Pump, Drip lines, Covering etc., are completed. We were not able to obtain sufficient steam pressure on the system with either one or two boilers being fired to get a comprehensive test over the whole building with special regard to the production of heat, which no doubt the system was revised for. The School authorities are at present firing both boilers with slab cordwood in four and five foot lengths, which is soaking wet and of very poor quality, and the b.t.u. output from which is extremely low. It is the only available fuel, and will never gain sufficient output at the boiler to heat this building, especially since the lines are now trapped and not of sufficient pressure to lift the indicator off the pin, so the steam pressure gauges cannot be raised at any time except by shutting the main steam valves for a test on the installation work, at which time we raised sufficient pressure to give the immediate pipe a sound test.

Only those Rads in the Boiler-room's immediate vicinity get warm, and at no time did the pressure gauge ever register pounds of steam.

Memorandum to Mr. Arneil:

Re: Hastings - Alert Bay Residential School

This will acknowledge your request of 17 March to review Mr. Weir's memorandum to our Director dealing with conversion to oil firing at the above mentioned school.

There is no question of the need to change to some fuel other than the slash wood as used at present. Mr. Weir's suggestion to convert one boiler to oil is a good one; the other boiler to be used as a standby which would preclude the possibility of a total shutdown in case of electric current failure. Unless there is an assured supply of dry cordwood available for standby use, coal is recommended. The assumption that one boiler, oil fired, could handle the entire load except under adverse weather conditions is correct.

The estimate of fuel consumption and cost of operation appears to be reasonable, providing that the boiler setting is tight and free from leakage and the furnace draft adequate.

From the information presently at hand, it would seem that in the Alert Bay area oil fuel would be restricted to the light grades, that is, No. 2 or No. 3. The use of No. 5 or 6 oils does not appear practical at this institution.

The suggestion that great care should be exercised in the selection of an oil burner for this school is well taken. However, it would be more advantageous to obtain the necessary burner locally rather than follow the suggestion that the equipment be shipped. It is preferable in cases of this nature to have a reliable local contractor tender for the specified burner and installation. In this way quick, efficient, and reasonable servicing and repair is assured.

If the Engineering & Construction Service would provide the specifications for a suitable burner, these would serve as a guide in obtaining the desired type of equipment.

It is noted in Mr. Philo Phelan's letter of March 9 that coal may be obtained laid down at the school for the price of $12.00 per ton. Assuming this to be a medium grade bituminous coal, considerable saving in fuel costs would be obtainable with coal firing. However, the cost of $12.00 a ton appears low and before concluding that coal might be less expensive than oil, further enquiry should be made as to the price of this fuel laid down at the school.

If required, this matter may be investigated thoroughly by your engineering staff in the course of the next few weeks.

Norman P. Robinson

Re: Heating - Alert Bay Residential School

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of March 9th (file 875-5 EL), and Army Signals message of March 31st regarding the proposed conversion to oil heating at the Alert Bay Residential School, it has taken some time to fully investigate this proposal because of the necessity of securing information with regard to oil storage problems at the school, the cost of oil and methods of delivery, etc., and on the other hand the necessity of securing information with regard to the cost of coal landed at the school, facilities for handling, etc.

Mr. Robinson, in his memorandum of April 4th attached, comments with regard to the relative values of coal and oil and refers also to Mr. Weir's memorandum of February 27th and the suggestion that great care should be exercised in the selection of a suitable oil burner and that the Indian Affairs Branch should purchase such a burner for installation by a contractor. I think the point raised by Mr. Robinson with regard to the future servicing of such installation should be carefully considered and as a matter of fact I am inclined to agree with him that we will get a maximum of service in the future if the contractor who makes the installation provides a burner to our specifications.

Since writing the attached memorandum Mr. Robinson has secured additional information with regard to the relative costs of coal and oil and it is apparent that if we could
secure coal at the price mentioned by the Principal it would be far more economical than oil, but enquiries have failed to reveal any source of supply of coal at $10.00 a ton. The best price secured so far on the supply of coal with a rating of 12,000 B.T.U.s per pound is $15.50 per ton landed on the dock at Alert Bay, in 100 ton quantities, plus $1.50 a ton cartage to the school. A comparison of costs based on the B.T.U. rating of coal and the B.T.U. rating of diesel oil indicates that oil will cost approximately one-third more than coal but the cost of the coal does not include the cost of handling the coal at the school and as a matter of fact I doubt very much whether there are facilities in Alert Bay for handling coal in 100 ton lots.

We will investigate the matter further should you so desire but personally I am of the opinion that the information above warrants the installation of oil burning equipment.

Extra copies of this letter and Mr. Robinson's report are attached for the information of Mr. Weir.
