Memorandum to Mr. Arneil:

Re: Heating - Alert Bay Residential School

This will acknowledge your memorandum of 17 March requesting that consideration be given to a tender and specification from Mitchell Brothers Limited on the installation of oil burning equipment in one of the low pressure boilers at the above mentioned school.

In the main, the specifications cover the requirements at the above school. However, it is suggested that an oil burner capable of consuming 16 to 20 Imperial gallons of fuel oil per hour should be installed. The components of the burner as outlined by Mitchell Brothers are acceptable. The controls required are as follows:

(1) A re-cycle control to protect in the event of power or flame failure and to withhold restarting of the burner until a suitable scavenging period has elapsed. This control to include a delayed action oil valve opening feature to ensure the burner will come to full operating speed before fuel oil is fed to the furnace.

(2) A high-low limit pressure control should be connected to the re-cycle control circuit to stop and start the oil burner.

(3) Low water cut-off should be wired into the oil burning circuit so as to prevent the burner from operating in the event of low water levels in the boiler. If these are of the float type, it should be equipped with blow-down valve and piping to facilitate removal of sediment from the float chamber.

(4) An automatic draft regulator should be installed to ensure that draft in the combustion chamber is reduced to a level consistent with the proper disposal of the gases of combustion.
(5) One high limit control valve.

Room thermostats are not considered advisable in this institution. Manual operation of the radiator valves in the various rooms is considered adequate for an institution of this type.

The size of the oil storage tank should not exceed 3,000 gallons. Oil delivery is obtainable at Alert Bay by tank truck with a capacity of 500 gallons. The current price of this type of delivery which could be obtained under, say, annual contract, is about 15.2¢ per gallon.

In deciding the correct size of fuel storage tank, consideration must be given to the fact that there is possibly only one truck available in the community for delivering fuel oil and, too, the limited number of motor vehicles and the isolated nature of Alert Bay would suggest that in the selection of a storage tank the choice should be made for a larger tank than might otherwise be considered adequate.

It is suggested that a 3,000 gallon tank be obtained. This tank should be buried underground in accordance with the regulations set out for the Province of British Columbia governing such devices. Possibly allowance should be made for constructing a pit under the boiler to provide a combustion chamber of about 44 cubic feet as recommended by the oil burner manufacturer.

The side walls of the boiler furnace box, target wall, and the furnace box floor would have to be rebricked and properly insulated.

The cost of such an installation would be approximately $4,000.00. However, competitive bids based on a firm specification might better this estimate. With an annual consumption of 2,336 gallons of oil as noted in Mr. Weir's memorandum to our Director of the 22nd February, fuel oil would cost $3,500.00 a year, whereas coal, if obtainable at $17.00 per ton which appears to be the best price to date, would cost possibly $900.00 less. However, coal does not seem practical at Alert Bay because of the lack of off-loading facilities and storage on the wharf.

If it is decided to install one oil burner at Alert Bay, definite specifications could be drawn up and tender prices received from reliable local firms.

Norman F. Robinson

MEMORANDUM - Norman P. Robinson, Esq.

Re: Alert Bay Residential School

Diesel Engine Driving Domestic Water Supply Pumping Plant.

In accordance with your instructions, I made an examination of the 5 HP Diesel engine driving the deep well pump at the Alert Bay Residential School on April 15, 1950.

General

From observations and previous correspondence written to this Department on this subject, it appears that the plant as it exists today was installed in 1930.

The installed length of the pump and casing is 65', the depth of the well is about 76' and the depth to the water 55'.

The pump is a 15 stage type, fitting into a 6" case and driven by a belt passing around a vertical pulley on the pump and a horizontal pulley on the diesel engine to make altogether a one-quarter turn.

Previous tests run on the pump showed a capacity of 45 Gals. per minute into a reservoir situated about 100' above the ground elevation of the pump house. However, the present 5 HP Petters Diesel Engine when run at this output was overloaded and the pump capacity was therefore reduced to 30 Gals. per minute. If a new engine is installed it should have a rating of not less than 8 HP in order to cut down on the pump time and increase the efficiency of the plant.

Diesel Engine Presently Installed

The 5HP Petters engine presently in use is 20 years old, breaks down continually since it is worn out, and should be completely rebuilt. This engine is now an obsolete model and the Supplier has informed us that they would probably have to have many of the parts made up specially if they were to carry out an overhaul job on the engine. This would run the cost of the overhaul job to about $250.00, roughly estimating. The repair bills for the engine alone during the past years have been running up to several hundred dollars annually. This cost could probably have been drastically reduced if the engine had been shipped to Vancouver for a complete overhaul but until recently the main pumping plant for the Alert Bay Village was not adequate to supply both the School and the Village requirements so the plant had to be repaired on the spot in the shortest time possible.

Cost Comparison for Diesel and Electric Driving Units

Electric Motor, 7½ HP

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| 1 - 440V 3-phase 60-cycle Induction Motor | $168.00|
| 1 - Contactor                             | 29.00  |
| 1 - Disconnect Switch                     | 15.00  |
| 1 - Belt Drive with Pulleys               | 100.00 |

Electrical and mechanical installation costs, including about 375' of pole line

Freight - Vancouver - Alert Bay

$422.00
8 HP Diesel Installation

1 - 8 HP AV-2 Petters Diesel Engine $575.00
1 - Belt Drive with Pulleys 100.00
Mechanical Installation 30.00
Freight - Vancouver - Alert Bay 10.00
Total $715.00

Operation Cost Comparison

The following costs have been estimated on an average daily consumption of 12000 Gals. per day:

Static Head 100 ft 55 = 155 ft
Friction Head 20 ft
Total Dynamic Head 175 ft

Theoretical HP used up in pumping 45 Gals. per minute = \(\frac{175 \times 45}{33,000} = 2.39\)

Assuming overall efficiency of 50% HP required = \(\frac{2.39}{.50} = 4.78\)

Pumping duration per day = \(\frac{12000}{45 \times 60} = 4.45\) Hrs.

Diesel Engine Operating Cost

Fuel consumption based on .5 Lbs. per break HP Hr.

Consumption per day = \(4.78 \times 4.45 \times .5 = 10.6\) Lbs.

Cost per month with Fuel Oil at 18¢ per Gal.

\(30 \times 10.6 \times 0.18 = \$5.68\)

Electric Motor Operating Cost

KW Hrs. per month \(4.78 \times .746 \times 4.45 \times 30 = 477\) KW Hrs.

B.C. Power Commission Rates for 7 HP Motor:

| Service Charge | $7.00 |
|----------------|-------|
| 0-350 KW Hrs. @ | .03 |
| 350-700 KW Hrs. @ | .12 |
| 700 - KW Hrs. @ | .2 |

Operating Costs - \(700 \times 3 + 127 \times 1.2 = \$19.40\)

Summary of Costs Per Month

Electric Power $19.40
Diesel Power $5.68
Difference $13.72
RECOMMENDATIONS

From the above it can be seen there is a wide difference in the energy costs which will amount to about $165.00 per year. It is therefore recommended that arrangements be made to purchase a new Diesel Engine to replace the old machine. Since the installation cost of the Diesel engine is only $300.00 more than the electric motor and this will be made up in about two years through a saving in power costs, it can be readily seen that the Diesel engine will be the most practical installation although there will be a slightly higher maintenance cost. But this maintenance cost should not enter into the picture for four or five years and should be more than amply taken care of by the savings in power.

The most suitable engine for this job would be an 8 HP Petters AV2 with removable sleeves. The Manufacturers' Agent informs me that the cost for a complete overhaul of this machine would run to about $100.00, which is very reasonable when he estimates the life of the engine before requiring this overhaul to be 12 years.

Thos. A. G. Beeching.
Vancouver, B.C.,
May 26, 1950.

Memorandum to Mr. Arneil:

Re: Completion Report re Revision to Mechanical Services at Alert Bay Indian Residential School - Alert Bay, B.C.

Upon instructions from Mr. N. P. Robinson of this Department, I visited the Alert Bay Residential School to make a final progress inspection of the work which had been carried out in connection with this project.

In general, the work assigned to the Contractor has been done satisfactorily and in accordance with the drawings supplied by our Head Office.

Heating Plant

The Contractor has forwarded to us a sketch of the piping plan in the boiler room which is slightly different from the isometric detail shown on the original plan No. 577, Sheet H-1, due to the fact that the boilers were differently positioned as mentioned in our letter to the head of the Engineering & Construction Division dated 9 December 1949. It will also be noticed that the indirect heater is connected to a drip line which is not an ideal arrangement but probably alright in this case. We have, however, taken this matter up with the Contractor and he has agreed to change the hook-up if the exchanger does not operate efficiently when we are able to raise steam to test the system.

The drip lines from the condensate traps on the header and heat exchanger in the boiler room are 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" which we consider adequate.

The size of the traps installed on the main steam line at the front end of the building has been changed to one with a capacity of 2,600 square feet of equivalent direct radiation since it was considered that a larger trap would be...
more desirable here.

Septic Tank

The septic tank has been constructed as shown on Drawing No. 577, Sheet P-1, with the exception of the top of the tank which has been raised about two feet to eliminate the manhole trunks. This change was made without our sanction before we were called in to inspect the job but appears to be fairly practical since the ground has been graded to the level of the top of the tank.

Recommendations

(1) It is recommended that an oil burner be installed as outlined in Mr. N.P. Robinson's recent memorandum since, with the present wood fuel available at Alert Bay, it is impossible to raise steam in the low pressure boilers when the main valves to the heating distribution system are open. For this reason the indirect water heater is presently of no value and the domestic water is now heated by separate coils immersed in the hot water tank supplied with steam from the high pressure boiler. Since the low pressure boilers cannot be fired sufficiently to raise steam, we are of the opinion that the heating system will operate less efficiently since the new steam traps and sump pump have been installed.

(2) The basement radiators are presently not fitted with thermostatic traps so when the steam pressure is available, it will be by-passed to an extent through these radiators.

(3) There are still several of the old drip return lines in the basement without steam traps. It is recommended that these lines be plugged since the new traps now installed should be adequate to handle the condensate in the system lines.

(4) The bellows in the traps at the radiators in the upper floors have not been overhauled since the school was originally constructed. These traps should be fitted with new
bellows and the valve seats overhauled to ensure efficient operation.

It is recommended by the writer that arrangements be made in the near future to call for tenders to cover the aforementioned points since the heating plant in its present condition is of little value and serious trouble could develop in the coming winter.

Thomas A. G. Beeching

Memorandum to Mr. Arnell:

Re: Wiring Alert Bay Schools

Residential School

In reply to your memorandum of June 26, we would like to inform you that during Mr. Beeching's visits to the above mentioned school, he did not examine the electrical installation in particular and it would require a survey trip in order to ascertain the exact amount of work required to bring the wiring of the school and the adjacent buildings up to reasonable first class electrical standards required in this province.

However, Mr. Beeching noticed that the illumination in the class rooms was well below the standard requirements and this would have to be changed entirely if these rooms are to be used for teaching purposes in the future. Although Mr. Beeching did not examine the staff rooms, it is very probable that the same condition exists as at St. George's Residential School, and outlet receptacle plugs should be installed in each room.

The system in use at present was originally designed for D.C. and is a 2-wire system but could be easily changed over to a 3-wire system. It was noticed that the conduits and solid neutral connections in the distribution panels and disconnect boxes were not properly grounded. Of course, this is a very dangerous condition.

Several additional appliances such as movie picture projectors and cooking electrical appliances are in use at the school and the wiring for this equipment has had to be brought in directly from the outside in a most unsatisfactory manner.
From the above remarks it would appear that the school definitely needs a complete electrical overhaul and we therefore feel that it would not be practical to carry out an inspection and rewiring job on the manual training building alone since this is a small wooden structure apart from the school and actually of small importance in comparison to the other buildings.

Day School

During Mr. Beeching's visit to Alert Bay he was shown over the day school and it was noticed by him that there were many small changes required to bring the electrical installation for this school up to reasonable standards. Some of these changes which he noticed included wire sizes required increasing, conduit and distribution panels required grounding, and insulators required fitting to the service entrances, etc.

We feel that this day school should be given an inspection at the time Mr. Beeching, or any other engineer, visits the residential school for inspection of the electrical installation there, since the latter school is of wooden frame construction and could easily be damaged by a short circuit.

Dear Major Mackay:

Re: Heating fuel at St. Michaels School, Alert Bay

Since returning from an extended tour of our sub-Arctic schools I have learned with concern that the Department has now decided not to convert one of the boilers at the above mentioned school into an oil burner. I understand too that this decision has been influenced by the intervention of J. L. Gibson, M.P. for Comox-Alberni.

From correspondence received from the "Telegraph Cove Mills Limited" it is evident to the I.S.A. that the lumbering industry on the B.C. coast has more or less complained about the possible conversion to oil at St. Michaels.

You will realize that the department's decision is most unsatisfactory to us. We asked for conversion to oil for the simple reason that the use of wood and slab-wood as a fuel source was anything but satisfactory. I would like to review some points in the problem.

Re: Slabwood:
(a) For years past the slabwood supplied by the Telegraph Cove Mills has been of very poor quality and they admit as much to I.S.A. in a letter dated May 18/50. It has also increased considerably in price.
(b) Handling expenses at the school have increased.
(c) The whole heating unit is designed to function under a constant and maintained heat source. This is impossible with the use of slabwood as when the fire is made up periodically the heat output is reduced as the heat energy is utilized to ignite, dry out and burn the freshly placed slab wood. As the heat source lowers in heat output the steam pressure is naturally reduced causing undue condensation in the pipes. If we are
Major D.M. Mackay

forced to continue the use of slabwood the recent costly overhaul to the heating system will be so much wasted effort, as it cannot function properly.

Cordwood -

This source of fuel has been investigated and while it would be a better fuel than slabwood it has disadvantages as well.
a - It is very expensive per cord
b - handling costs at the school would be high
c - An assured source is un procurable. No white concern handles cordwood in or near Alert Bay and the only way the school could get a supply would be from Indian cutters. The Indians are very well off financially and do not want to cut wood even at the present high prices. Even when an Indian can be found who will accept a wood-cutting contract there is no guarantee of delivery.

Coal -

This source of fuel has also been investigated
a - Its use is impossible because of the very high cost per ton landed at Alert Bay.
b - We have no facilities at the school for hauling from the barge to the school.
c - It is dirty and handling costs in the boiler room would be expensive.
d - No storage facilities at the school for a safe stock pile - It cannot be stored outdoors because of weathering.

It has been said against St. Michael's use of fuel oil that it would put lumbermen out of work and thus effect the labour situation. If a service is feasible at Alberni it would certainly seem that a similar service is feasible at Alert Bay and if it is a question of condition of the existing structure my casual inspection of the barn at Alert Bay did not give an impression of unsound timber or imminent collapse of the structure.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner.

Sir:

I have the honor to refer to Departmental file No.156-0-9 in connection with the agreement concerning the leasehold of this Department with the Anglican Synod of British Columbia at Alert Bay, B.C., incidental to which this Department is obligated to the necessary removal of sawmill buildings from the site in accordance with its Agreement dated the 1st day of June 1931.

In this connection I beg to advise the Department that I received a call from His Lordship Bishop Schofield a few days ago who informs me that the machinery which has for some time been housed in the main building thereof is preventing the demolition thereof. It has now also been arranged that we may now proceed to demolish the building and move the debris from the site. As it is understood there are some heavy timbers connected with this building to be disposed of, it is suggested that the services of a good all round man with carpentry knowledge be obtained to supervise the work. I am not quite sure what the cost will be of clearing this site satisfactorily to ourselves and to the Church Authorities but I would judge that the sum of $500.00 would be an absolutely outside figure. By an understanding reached with the Church Authorities the material to be removed will probably be disposed of partly to the Residential School and local Anglican Church and the balance to deserving Indians who may wish to have it. All other unusable debris to be burned up and the site left in clean condition.

In view of the fact that it is understood from Mr. Indian Agent Halliday that during last winter certain old buildings were removed from part of this site as they stood within a Right-of-way of a Provincial public thoroughfare in course of construction a sum of money was expended by the Department on relief work under the direction of the Indian Agent, the latter being of the opinion that the sum (approximately $200.00) expended on this work should be reimbursed to this Department by the Provincial Public Works Authorities, and if this is done the amount to be received from the Provincial Authorities might be applied to the above-mentioned undertaking. With this suggestion I am in accord since the question of compensation for clearing the thoroughfare has not yet been adjusted between this Department and the Department of Public Works. It is understood that an engineer of the Provincial Government has recently been on the ground and has made or is making a report to his Department in regard to the thoroughfare.

In the meantime I would ask that the Department be good enough to advise me if possible what was the amount actually spent....

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
spent by the Department in removing the debris from the public thoroughfare last winter. The Department's letter of March 21st last on file here indicates that a sum of approximately $100.00 was authorized to be spent by the Agent for clearing that portion of the site required for right-of-way. The Department will be aware that Mr. Halliday has now left Alert Bay and his successor may not be able to advise me as promptly as the Department could of the amount spent on this work. I would ask that authority be given to complete the clearing of the site.

Your obedient servant,

C. C. Perry,
Asst. Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, October 19, 1933.

Sir:

I have your 15/6/31338 of the third instant, enclosing copies of communications between yourself and His Lordship the Bishop of Columbia and also with Mr. E. G. Newnham, Acting Indian Agent, regarding the wharves at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

With reference to the wharf situated in front of the school building, I have to say that Mr. Newnham has been authorized to repair same, at a cost not to exceed $250, provided there are sufficient funds left over from the appropriation of $2,000, which was allowed for repair work at the school.

Regarding the sawmill wharf, which the Department leased from the Anglican Synod of the Diocese of British Columbia as from June 1, 1931, at a nominal rental, I have to say it is noted that this wharf is no use, either to the church authorities or the Department and considerable expenditure would be necessary for repairs. It is noted, further, that Mr. Newnham and myself recommend that the agreement between the Anglican Synod and the Department, in connection with this wharf, be cancelled. As you are of opinion that this wharf is of no use in connection with the school, the Department will approve of the cancelling of the lease of same, provided the church authorities will agree. The Department does not appear to have a copy of the lease, as, by official letter dated May 17, 1931, same was returned to the late Commissioner Betchurn, after execution by the Deputy Superintendent General. After taking the matter up with the church authorities, please advise if they will consent to the cancelling of the lease of the sawmill wharf. In view of the cancellation, the Department would give favourable consideration to the keeping in repair of the school wharf, in so far as funds permit from time to time.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your No. 15/6/26651 of the 18th instant, regarding the removal of the old sawmill buildings from the Alert Bay Indian Residential School site, in accordance with the agreement with the authorities of the Anglican Church, and giving an estimate of the cost.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $500 in having the old buildings removed and moving the material and debris from the site. It is noted that the machinery which had been housed in the main building has now been removed. Indian labour should be employed as far as possible, and, if necessary, the services of a man with carpentry knowledge could be engaged to supervise the work.

It is understood that the material in the buildings to be removed will be disposed of, partly to the Residential School and local Anglican Church and the balance to deserving Indians who may wish to obtain same. All the other unusable debris should be burned and the site left in a clean condition. Accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the labour employed and for any other expenses, should be forwarded for payment.

Sir,

This special covering letter is being written on behalf of Gideon Whonnock, Indian of the Kwawkewlth Band and ex-pupil of the Residential School, who owns a house on that portion of Hill Street located between Lots 6 and 7 and between Front Street and Broughton Street on the sub-division of the Special Industrial School reserve, and is living there permanently.

Whonnock has made application to this office to have this portion of Hill Street allotted to him as a lot, to be known as Lot No. 6A, and that he be given a certificate of approval from the Department.

Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve
Cormorant Island, Rupert District, B.C.

The original Minute of Decision setting this reserve apart stated that the land was set apart as reserve No.6 of the Nimkeeshe band and this was approved by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works. At the suggestion of the Department, the Minute was amended by Commissioner O'Reilly and again approved by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works, as follows:

"Minute of Decision, 5th Mar. 1891, approved by Chief Commissioner of Lands 10th Mar. 1891, setting apart as reserve 410 ac."

"Minute of Decision,
Alert Bay Indian Industrial School reserve.

A reserve of four hundred and ten (410) acres situated at the western extremity of Cormorant Island, and to the West of, and adjoining the Revd. A.J. Hall's Claim, Section Four (4) Rupert District.

Commencing at the Southwest corner post of Section Four (4), Rupert District, and running North to the seacoast; thence in a westerly direction, and following the seashore to the place of commencement.

In a letter dated June 6th 1904, the Indian Agent requested that a portion of the land be subdivided and allotted to certain ex-pupils of the school who had been permitted by the former Agent to settle on a portion of the property. This being recommended by the Indian Superintendent, the Department approved and a subdivision was laid out by A.H. Green, B.C.L.S. The question of issuing location tickets to the Indian locators was then brought up and it being decided that the reserve was set apart for a special purpose and not an Indian reserve or a special reserve within the meaning of the Indian Act, the Department could not issue location tickets.

The Department endeavoured to obtain title to the land from the Province, but were unsuccessful, the decision expressed by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works being, "that owing to the unsatisfactory state of affairs between the Dominion and the Province in relation to the question of Indian reserves, the Executive considers it inadvisable in the meantime to make further allotments, but..."
will be prepared to consider any application by the Department for purchase or deal with suitable exchanges." Here the question was dropped. The Royal Commission, on being requested to declare a portion of the land including the subdivided portion to be an Indian reserve, replied that, "Inasmuch as the tract of land comprised in the Industrial School reserve at Alert Bay was alienated by the Province of British Columbia and subsequently acquired by the Government of the Dominion of Canada for a school reserve, the Commission has no authority to constitute or confirm the whole or any portion thereto as an Indian Reserve under the terms of the Agreement, the Dominion being the unquestionable owner of the property and unhampered by the terms of the Agreement in dealing therewith in such manner as may appear to the Dominion Government to best meet the purposes of the purchase of the said land; but that from what the Commission learned at meetings with the Indians at Alert Bay, it seems to the Commission that it would be right and proper to secure in occupation the Indians who have, with the consent or acquiescence of the Department of Indian Affairs, made homes upon the said tract of land."

Following this opinion, the Department on Sept. 14th 1914, instructed the Indian Agent to "give recognition of title in writing to each individual occupant of land on this property," but the regular form of Location Ticket was not issued.

On the recommendation of Mr. Ditchburn, Inspector of Indian Agencies, instructions were issued on Jan. 29th 1915 to subdivide a portion of the reserve extending across the island and contiguous to the East boundary, into lots of approximately one acre to include within the new lots the improvements contained in the former subdivision. A subdivision of 40 lots, including streets, was laid out, the aggregate area of the lots being 66.21 acres and of the streets 15 acres, more or less, or approximately 80.25 acres in all, as shown on plan B.C.277.

In 1928, the Department built a new school on the property, the total cost of which, including furnishings, and clearing sufficient for the use of the school, was in the neighbourhood of $200,000.00.

Although the communication from the Royal Commission refers to the property as having been purchased there is no evidence of the purchase on the departmental files. The reserve is not shown on the Schedule of Indian Reserves, was not included in the report of the Royal Commission, nor is it included in the schedule of those lands presently to be conveyed to the Department by the Province.
So far as the school is concerned, the title to the reserve is secure so long as it continues to be used for the purpose for which the grant was made, but it will be necessary at some time to purchase the subdivided portion, in order to protect the improvements of the Indians who have been encouraged to settle thereon.

Sir,-

Many years ago the Department surveyed a forty acre parcel belonging to the Industrial School Reserve at Alert Bay into one acre lots, and had it set aside for ex-pupils who wished to build a home and to escape from the environment of villages where the "Potlatch" was still being practiced.

I do not believe this regulation in regard to the practice of the Indian Custom was ever officially recorded although it was understood definitely by the Indians, the Residential School and the local Indian Agent at that time, and this policy has been followed ever since.

During the past few years the practice of the Indian Custom has become more evident with the result that ex-pupils of the school are now being forced into it against their own better judgment, and in view of this it is felt the Department should be asked to make a definite regulation that any ex-pupil applying for a lot in this Industrial Reserve site should definitely give the Department an undertaking that they will give up the Custom and have nothing further to do with it if a lot is given to them for the purpose of building a home.

This is one way in which we may check the practice and protect these young people who desire to live according to the teachings of good citizenship.

I would therefore ask the Department to approve and issue definite instructions that any person applying for a lot in this Industrial School Reserve should definitely state and agree not to practice the Indian Custom in any respect before the Department will approve of locating him on this Reserve, and failure to keep such agreement forfeits any claims he may have if proven against him.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

Sir,

Replying to your letter No.156-0-9 dated July 8, 1936, in reference to Indians being located on the Special Industrial School Reserve at Alert Bay, I beg to herewith submit the following report on those Indians who have made application to reside on this reserve and whose application has been recommended by the Indian Agent and approved by the Department, as well as those Indians residing on this reserve without permission or authority from the Department. For the purpose of making a complete report, we are taking each lot separately as shown on Map No. 277 B.C., subdivision of Part of Indian Industrial School Reserve, Alert Bay, Cormorant Island, Rupert District, B.C., of which the Department no doubt have a copy.

In order to have the status of each lot brought up to date, we are requesting the Department to confirm all former approvals given by them, and recommending that all lots now held by various Indians through purchase, be approved and confirmed by the Department.

Lot No.1 - This lot is registered in the name of Stephen Cook, a member of the Nimpkish Band, who made application for the same as an ex-pupil of the Residential School, and was granted authority in Departmental letter dated September 14, 1914. This lot has been held by him ever since, and although at the present time he is not living thereon, it is nevertheless recognized as his property and he is holding it for one of his sons.

I would recommend that the approval granted by the Department on September 14, 1914, be confirmed, and a certificate to this effect issued.

Lot No.2 - This lot was applied for by Charles Newman, an Indian of the Kwawkewlth Band, and his application approved by the Department on September 14, 1914. He has now transferred his interests to his son, Carey Newman, of the Kwawkewlth Band, who is now living on this property.

I would request the Department's approval of this transfer from Charles Newman to Carey Newman, and would recommend that a certificate be issued to Carey Newman.

Lot No.3 - This lot was granted to Chief Joseph Harris of the Nimpkish Band by Departmental letter of September 14, 1914, and he is still residing thereon. I would therefore recommend that the Department issue a certificate confirming this approval to Chief Joseph Harris.

Lot No.4 - Annie Kamano was the original owner of this lot by authority in Departmental letter of September 14, 1914. She sold her interests, and the improvements on this property have changed hands many times, and the present owner is Benjamin Brotchie, ex pupil, and member of the Kwawkewlth Band, but there is no record of his location having been approved by the Department. As he intends to keep his home on this property, I would recommend that the Department approve of his location on this lot, and issue a certificate approving of same to him.
Lot No.6 - This is one case where it would appear the Department has given permission to settle on land where Indians have apparently squatted without the approval of the Department. From old-time Indians we have learned in regard to Lot No.8 that Richard Flanders, a member of the Namiklikulla Band and ex-pupil of the Residential School, built a small house on this lot, later selling it to an Indian lady by the name of Lily of the Klowitzis Band. This Indian has now disposed of her interests to Herbert Cook of the Nimpkish Band, who has improved the property and is making his home there.

In this case I would recommend that the Department approve of Herbert Cook's location on this lot, and issue a certificate to this effect to him.

Lot No.5 - An application from Michael Kamano, white, was forwarded to the Department on March 1st, 1921 for this lot, and the Department later approved of his location in a letter dated March 11th, 1921. At the time his application was forwarded a special covering letter was enclosed explaining this application, which was later approved by the Department.

This lot has changed hands through the sale of the improvements, and is now owned and occupied by Charles Newman, Indian of the Kwawkewlth Band, an ex-pupil of the Residential School, and I would recommend that the Department approve of Charles Newman as owner of this lot and issue a certificate to him to that effect.

On this same lot there is another small house built which is partially located on Lot 6 and partially on the street known as Hill Street. This house was originally built by Spruce Martin, member of the Kwawkewlth Band whose children are all ex-pupils of the Residential School. He has returned to his own village at Fort Rupert and the house is occupied by Charlie James, a member of the Kwawkewlth Band who is the step-father of Spruce Martin.

In connection with this house, I would recommend that it be moved back to a position on the back end of Lot 6 so that it will be entirely on this lot as there is plenty of room for a house at the back end of this lot.

On Street Allowance Between Lots 6 and 7 - Gideon Whonnock, ex-pupil of the Residential School, has built a home on Hill Street, fronting on Front Street, between Lots 6 and 7. No approval was given to him for the erection of this house as far as our records show but as the back portion of this street leading to Broughton Street is a very steep grade and in my opinion would not be suitable for street; I would recommend that the rear portion of Hill Street be transferred from a thoroughfare to a lot calling the front portion if it Lot No. 6A, and the upper or back half Lot No. 6B, and granting the front portion of it to Whonnock where he has already settled. It will never be used for street purposes, and the lots to the rear can be reached more satisfactorily by way of Park and Broughton Streets. A special letter in this connection is being forwarded on behalf of Whonnock, making this recommendation.

Lot No.7 - This lot was applied for by James Prevost, Indian of the Nimpkish Band, and granted to him by Departmental letter of September 14th, 1914. It is still held by him and he has lived for many years in his home erected on this location. I would recommend that the Department at this time confirm the approval given to James Prevost as to his location on this lot.
Lot No. 8 - This lot was allotted to David Shaughnessy, Indian of the Seminole Band, an ex-pupil of the Residential School and he was approved under date of January 9, 1920 by the then Indian Agent, Mr. W.M. Halliday, but we cannot locate in our files where the Department approved of this, although no doubt their approval had been received as Mr. Halliday states he "had been instructed by the Department to issue this approval." Mr. Shaughnessy has lived on this property ever since, has improved it greatly, and during the past year has built another home on the back of the lot for his son.

I would therefore recommend that the Department issue a certificate of approval granting this lot to David Shaughnessy.

Lot No. 9 - This lot was granted to William Brothie by Departmental letter dated September 14, 1914. He is now deceased but he had sold his interest and the improvements on this property to Thomas Howell who is now also deceased. Before Thomas Howell died, he left the improvements on this lot jointly to his daughter Dorothy Howell and his step-son Bertie Blenkinsop, both of the Kwakwaka'wakw Band, and the property remains today in their names. Since then Dorothy Howell has married an Indian by the name of Ben Isaac who belongs to the Katzie Band of the New Westminster Agency and they have made their home here most of the time since they were married as Mrs. Isaac was caring for her mother who had just died. Bertie Blenkinsop her half-brother, and part owner of the property, has always made his home here, and has kept the property in repair. Both the owners of this lot are ex-pupils of the Residential School, but as Ben Isaac, husband of the former Dorothy Howell is not a desirable resident in this Agency, it is my desire to have him moved back to his own Agency. A special letter is being forwarded the Department in regard to this particular case, but I would recommend that Bertie Blenkinsop purchase Mrs. Ben Isaac's interest from her, and that a certificate be issued to Bertie Blenkinsop at the time of transfer.

Lot No. 10 - I am advised by Mr. Anfield, Principal of the Alert Bay Residential School, that this lot has been transferred to the school property, and that it no longer belongs to the subdivision of the Industrial School Reserve, but has been cleared and a residence built on it for the engineer of the Residential School, therefore it is not available for residential purposes as far as this Special Reserve is concerned.

As we have no particulars in regard to this, would the Department kindly advise me the date on which this lot was transferred and any other particulars pertaining to the transfer.

Lot No. 11 - Arthur Stanley, an ex-pupil of the Residential School but who has always been classed as white, was granted this lot and approved by the Department in their letter of September 19, 1922. The covering letter at the time of his application gives a full explanation why this was approved. Arthur Stanley owned this house on this lot until recently when he sold it for cash to Moses Alfred, an Indian of the Nimpkish Band and an ex-pupil of the school, who is now the present owner.

I would recommend that the Department issue a certificate of approval to Moses Alfred for his ownership of this lot.

Lot No. 12 - No approval was given by the Department as far as our records show to Mrs. William Brothie, ex-pupil, who built a home on this lot and greatly improved it. About a year ago after Mr. Brothie died, Mrs. Brothie sold the house to Godfrey Hunt, an ex-pupil, a member of the Kwakwaka'wakw Band, who owns it at the present time and is living therein. I would therefore recommend that the Department issue a certificate of approval to Godfrey Hunt for his ownership of this lot.
Lots No. 19 are vacant, and no application is on file or any approval granted for any of them.

Lot No. 20 - Price Bruce, an Indian of the Matilpi Band, and ex-pupil of the Residential School, has built a house and done certain improvements on this lot, but we cannot find where any approval was given by the Department for his location, however there is a possibility that the then Indian Agent gave him permission to build there. He is making his home on this lot at the present time, and I would recommend that the Department approve of Price Bruce's location on this lot and issue a certificate accordingly.

Lots No. 21 to 40 - the remainder of the lots in this subdivision are unoccupied with no improvements made and no applications on file for occupation.

As no doubt the Department have a copy of Survey and Plan No. 277 B.C. as surveyed by F.E. Leach under date of June 13, 1915 which gives full particulars as to the amount of land in each lot, with the further information given in this report as to the lots located upon, the Department will be able to arrive at the amount of land occupied and by whom, and the amount still untenanted and available for residential purposes.

As we are anxious to get this situation straightened out satisfactorily, would the Department please give it their early consideration?

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Allan:

Among the hundred or more parcels of Ordnance and Admiralty lands being investigated by this Commission is one listed on the Return to the Legislature of British Columbia in 1873, No. 65, Cormorant Island, being the westerly part of Cormorant Island, north of Vancouver Island. It was set aside for Admiralty purposes, supposedly to command the entrance to Johnstone Strait, and was estimated to contain 500 acres.

Provincial records show this reserve surveyed as 412 acres, and to be the western part of Cormorant Island, and noted "Indian Industrial School Reserve" on their existing maps. It is known to have an Industrial School in operation, which, according to the files in the office of the Indian Commissioner at Vancouver, cost upwards of $200,000, and being administered under your Branch.

According to the Provincial records, the title to this land is held in the right of the Crown Provincial, and never has been transferred to the Crown Dominion. There does not seem to be any explanation, although there is evidence it was approved to be so transferred some years ago.

It is not included in the schedule of reserves conveyed to the Crown Dominion by Order-in-Council, 29th July 1936. There does not appear to have been any application for the same, and it would appear that the only consideration given by the Royal Commission 1912-14 is summed up by the following memo, dated 4th April, 1935, by D. Robertson, Chief Surveyor:

"The Royal Commission, on being requested to declare a portion of the land including the subdivided portion to be an Indian reserve, replied that, 'Inasmuch as the tract of land comprised in the Industrial School reserve at Alert Bay was alienated by the Province of British Columbia and subsequently acquired by
the Government of the Dominion of Canada for a school reserve, the Commission has no authority to constitute or confirm the whole or any portion thereto as an Indian Reserve under the terms of the Agreement, the Dominion being the unquestionable owner of the property and unhampered by the terms of the Agreement in dealing therewith in such manner as may appear to the Dominion Government to best meet the purposes of the purchase of the said land; but that from what the Commission learned at meetings with the Indians at Alert Bay, it seems to the Commission that it would be right and proper to secure in occupation the Indians who have, with the consent or acquiescence of the Department of Indian Affairs, made homes upon the said tract of land.

"Although the communication from the Royal Commission refers to the property as having been purchased, there is no evidence of the purchase on the departmental files. The reserve is not shown on the Schedule of Indian Reserves, was not included in the Report of the Royal Commission, nor is it included in the schedule of those lands presently to be conveyed to the Department by the Province."

I believe that the Province may now be in the attitude to clear off this item by negotiation along with the other Ordinance matters, but first we should be sure of the history, and when mention is made by the Royal Commission that the land had been purchased, and title obtained, it should be ascertained without a doubt that the Indian Affairs records do not have particulars of such purchase and the conveyance giving title.

Provincial records show very definitely the land held in the name of the Province of British Columbia, and the Deputy Minister is at a loss to know why title has not been transferred.

I have taken the matter up with Mr. D.M. Mackay, Commissioner for British Columbia, and we think this an excellent opportunity to clear up the question.

Will you please furnish me, at your earliest possible convenience, with information as to the status of this Reserve as it appears on your Departmental records.

Yours sincerely,

Dominion Representative.

Ottawa, 4th April 1935.

Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve
Cormorant Island, Rupert District, B.C.

The original Minute of Decision setting this reserve apart stated that the land was set apart as reserve No. 8 of the Nimkeesh band and this was approved by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works. At the suggestion of the Department, the Minute was amended by Commissioner O'Reilly and again approved by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works, as follows:

"Minute of Decision, 5th Mar. 1891, approved by Chief Commissioner of Lands 10th Mar. 1891, setting apart as reserve 410 ac."

"Minute of Decision,
Alert Bay Indian Industrial School reserve.

A reserve of four hundred and ten (410) acres situated at the western extremity of Cormorant Island, and to the West of, and adjoining the Revd. A. J. Hall's Claim, Section Four (4)
Rupert District.

Commencing at the Southwest corner post of Section Four (4), Rupert District, and running North to the seacoast; thence in a westerly direction, and following the seashore to the place of commencement."

In a letter dated June 6th, 1904, the Indian Agent requested that a portion of the land be subdivided and allotted to certain ex-pupils of the school who had been permitted by the former Agent to settle on a portion of the property. This being recommended by the Indian Superintendent, the Department approved and a subdivision was laid out by A. H. Green, B.C.L.S. The question of issuing location tickets to the Indian locators was then brought up and it being decided that the reserve was set apart for a special purpose and not an Indian reserve or a special reserve within the meaning of the Indian Act, the Department could not issue location tickets.

The Department endeavoured to obtain title to the land from the Province, but were unsuccessful, the decision expressed by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works being: "That owing to the unsatisfactory state of affairs between the Colonization and the Indians in relation to the question of Indian reserves, the Executive considers it inadvisable in the meantime to make further allotments, but will be prepared to consider any application by the Department for purchase, or deal with suitable exchanges." Here the question was dropped. The Royal Commission, on being requested to declare a portion of the land including the subdivided portion to be an Indian
reserve, replied that, "Inasmuch as the tract of land comprised in the Industrial School reserve at Alert Bay was alienated by the Province of British Columbia and subsequently acquired by the Government of the Dominion of Canada for a school reserve, the Commission has no authority to constitute or confirm the whole or any portion thereto as an Indian Reserve under the terms of the Agreement, the Dominion being the unquestionable owner of the property and unhampered by the terms of the Agreement in dealing therewith in such manner as may appear to the Dominion Government to best meet the purposes of the purchase of the said land; but that from what the Commission learned at meetings with the Indians at Alert Bay, it seems to the Commission that it would be right and proper to secure in occupation the Indians who have, with the consent or acquiescence of the Department of Indian Affairs, made homes upon the said tract of land."

Following this opinion, the Department on Sept. 14th 1914, instructed the Indian Agent to "give recognition of title in writing to each individual occupant of land on this property," but the regular form of Location Ticket was not issued.

On the recommendation of Mr. Litchburn, Inspector of Indian Agencies, instructions were issued on Jan. 29th 1915 to subdivide a portion of the reserve extending across the island and contiguous to the East boundary, into lots of approximately one acre to include within the new lots the improvements contained in the former subdivision. A subdivision of 40 lots, including streets, was laid out, the aggregate area of the lots being 66.21 acres and of the streets 15 acres, more or less, or approximately 80.25 acres in all, as shown on plan B.C. 277.

In 1928, the Department built a new school on the property, the total cost of which, including furnishings, and clearing sufficient for the use of the school, was in the neighbourhood of $200,000.00.

Although the communication from the Royal Commission refers to the property as having been purchased, there is no evidence of the purchase on the departmental files. The reserve is not shown on the Schedule of Indian Reserves, was not included in the Report of the Royal Commission, nor is it included in the schedule of those lands presently to be conveyed to the Department by the Province.

So far as the school is concerned, the title to the reserve is secure so long as it continues to be used for the purpose for which the grant was made, but it will be necessary at some time to purchase the subdivided portion, in order to protect the improvements of the Indians who have been encouraged to settle thereon.

Lot No.9 - This lot was granted to William Brotchie by Departmental letter dated September 14, 1914. He is now deceased but he had sold his interest and the improvements on this property to Thomas Nowell who is now also deceased. Before Thomas Nowell died, he left the improvements on this lot jointly to his daughter Dorothy Nowell and his step-son Bertie Blenkinsop, both of the Kwawkewlth Band, and the property remains today in their names. Since then Dorothy Nowell has married an Indian by the name of Ben Isaac who belongs to the Katzle Band of the New Westminster Band, and they have made their home here most of the time since they were married as Mrs. Isaac was caring for her mother who had been kept by Bertie Blenkinsop her half-brother, and part owner of the property. Bertie always made his home here, and has kept the property in repair. Both these owners of this lot are ex-pupils of the Residential School, but as Ben Isaac, husband of the former Dorothy Nowell is not a desirable resident in this Agency, it is my desire to have him moved back to his own Agency. A special letter is being forwarded the Department in regard to this particular case, but I would recommend that Bertie Blenkinsop purchase Mrs. Ben Isaac's interest from her, and that a certificate be issued to Bertie Blenkinsop at the time of transfer.

Lot No.10 - I am advised by Mr. Anfield, Principal of the Alert Bay Residential School, that this lot has been transferred to the school property and that it no longer belongs to the sub-division of the Industrial School Reserve, but has been cleared and a residence built on it for the engineer of the Residential School, therefore it is not available for residential purposes as far as this Special Reserve is concerned.

As we have no particulars in regard to this, would the Department kindly advise me the date on which this lot was transferred and any other particulars pertaining to the transfer.

Lot No.11 - Arthur Stanley, an ex-pupil of the Residential School but who has always been classed as white, was granted this lot and approved by the Department in their letter of September 19, 1922. The covering letter at the time of his application gives a full explanation why this was approved. Arthur Stanley owned this house on this lot until recently when he sold it for cash to Moses Alfred, an Indian of the Nimpkish Band and an ex-pupil of the school, who is now the present owner.

I would recommend that the Department issue a certificate of approval to Moses Alfred for his ownership of this lot.

Lot No.12 - No approval was given by the Department as far as our records show to Mrs. William Brotchie, ex-pupil, who built a home on this lot and greatly improved it. About a year ago after Mr. Brotchie died, Mrs. Brotchie sold the house to Godfrey Hunt, an ex-pupil a member of the Kwawkewlth Band, who owns it at the present time and is living thereon. I would therefore recommend that the Department issue a certificate of approval to Godfrey Hunt for his ownership of this lot.
Lots 13 to 19 are vacant, and no application is on file or any approval granted for any of them.

Lot No. 20 - Price Bruce, an Indian of the Matilpi Band, and ex-pupil of the Residential School, has built a house and done certain improvements on this lot, but we cannot find where any approval was given by the Department for his location, however there is a possibility that the then Indian Agent gave him permission to build there. He is making his home on this lot at the present time, and I would recommend that the Department approve of Price Bruce's location on this lot and issue a certificate accordingly.

Lots No. 21 to 40 - the remainder of the lots in this subdivision are unoccupied with no improvements made and no applications on file for occupation.

Ottawa, 4th April 1935.

Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve
Cormorant Island, Rupert District, B.C.

The original Minute of Decision setting this reserve apart stated that the land was set apart as reserve No. 6 of the Nimkeesh band and this was approved by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works. At the suggestion of the Department, the Minute was amended by Commissioner O'Reilly and again approved by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works, as follows:

"Minute of Decision, 5th Mar. 1891, approved by Chief Commissioner of Lands 10th Mar. 1891, setting apart as reserve 410 ac."

"Minute of Decision,
Alert Bay Indian Industrial School reserve.

A reserve of four hundred and ten (410) acres situated at the western extremity of Cormorant Island, and to the West of, and adjoining the Revd. A. J. Hall's Claim, Section Four (4)
Rupert District.

Commencing at the Southwest corner post of Section Four (4), Rupert District, and running North to the seacoast; thence in a westerly direction, and following the seashore to the place of commencement."

In a letter dated June 6th, 1904, the Indian Agent requested that a portion of the land be subdivided and allotted to certain ex-pupils of the school who had been permitted by the former Agent to settle on a portion of the property. This being recommended by the Indian Superintendent, the Department approved and a subdivision was laid out by A. H. Green, B.C.L.S. The question of issuing location tickets to the Indian locators was then brought up and it being decided that the reserve was set apart for a special purpose and not an Indian reserve or a special reserve within the meaning of the Indian Act, the Department could not issue location tickets.

The Department endeavoured to obtain title to the land from the Province, but were unsuccessful, the decision expressed by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works being,- "that owing to the unsatisfactory state of affairs between the Dominion and the Province in relation to the question of Indian reserves, the Executive considers it inadvisable in the meantime to make further allotments, but will be prepared to consider any application by the Department for purchase, or deal with suitable exchanges." Here the question was dropped. The Royal Commission, on being requested to declare a portion of the land including the subdivided portion to be an Indian
reserve, replied that, "Inasmuch as the tract of land comprised in the Industrial School reserve at Alert Bay was alienated by the Province of British Columbia and subsequently acquired by the Government of the Dominion of Canada for a school reserve, the Commission has no authority to constitute or confirm the whole or any portion thereto as an Indian Reserve under the terms of the Agreement, the Dominion being the unquestionable owner of the property and unhampered by the terms of the Agreement in dealing therewith in such manner as may appear to the Dominion Government to best meet the purposes of the purchase of the said land; but that from what the Commission learns at meetings with the Indians at Alert Bay, it seems to the Commission that it would be right and proper to secure in occupation the Indians who have, with the consent or acquiescence of the Department of Indian Affairs, made homes upon the said tract of land."

Following this opinion, the Department on Sept. 14th 1914, instructed the Indian Agent to "give recognition of title in writing to each individual occupant of land on this property," but the regular form of Location Ticket was not issued.

On the recommendation of Mr. Ditchburn, Inspector of Indian Agencies, instructions were issued on Jan. 29th 1915 to subdivide a portion of the reserve extending across the island and contiguous to the East boundary, into lots of approximately one acre to include within the new lots the improvements contained in the former subdivision. A subdivision of 40 lots, including streets, was laid out, the aggregate area of the lots being 66.21 acres and of the streets 15 acres, more or less, or approximately 80.25 acres in all, as shown on plan B.C. 277.

In 1928, the Department built a new school on the property, the total cost of which, including furnishings, and clearing sufficient for the use of the school, was in the neighbourhood of $200,000.00.

Although the communication from the Royal Commission refers to the property as having been purchased, there is no evidence of the purchase on the departmental files. The reserve is not shown on the Schedule of Indian Reserves, was not included in the Report of the Royal Commission, nor is it included in the schedule of those lands presently to be conveyed to the Department by the Province.

So far as the school is concerned, the title to the reserve is secure so long as it continues to be used for the purpose for which the grant was made, but it will be necessary at some time to purchase the subdivided portion, in order to protect the improvements of the Indians who have been encouraged to settle therein.

(sgd.) Geo. Patrick

The road referred to in your memorandum of the 3rd April, your file 2315-29, runs through the subdivided part of the Alert Bay Industrial School property on Cormorant Island. The title to the whole of this parcel is unsettled. A search has been made to try to prove that this school reserve occupies the same ground as parcel number 68 mentioned in a list of Military and Naval reserves supplied by the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch of this Department, a copy of which I believe is of record on one of your files. We are convinced that the parcels do overlap but proof is lacking due to the fact that the plans have been sent to Mr. Taggart care of the Deputy Minister of Lands, Victoria. These gentlemen are a commission to determine the locations of these Military reserves (commonly called Ordnance Lands).

The cemetery lies immediately east of the subdivided portion of the school property and not on the school reserve, nor is the cemetery on an Indian reserve. We believe it is on land formerly held privately and was a part of lot 4. The location of the road to it, shown on the blue print on file which is from our plan Rd. 2723, was approved by this department in 1957 and the province was authorized to enter the reserve for purposes of construction. The road allowance was not transferred to the province. It is understood by our Department that the Dominion Government owns the land through which the road passes and over which the road runs, but it is not clear whether it is a Military reserve or an Industrial School reserve.
Under the circumstances, it would not appear to be practicable to use Indian funds for the construction of the road, but a government grant might be considered, as no doubt the Indians do to a small extent use this road. The Indians have a burial ground called No. 2 or Nimipkish band situate about 30 chains south of the Indian reserve. The Indian reserve is immediately south of lot 4 and the Industrial School lot is immediately west of lot 4, so that it appears doubtful that the Indians make much use of the cemetery to which the road runs.

PROVIDED NEVERTHELESS that it shall at all times be lawful for Us, Our heirs and successors, or for any person or persons acting in that behalf by Us or their authority, to resume any part of the said land which it may be deemed necessary to resume for making roads, canals, bridges, towing paths, or other works of public utility or convenience; so, nevertheless that the lands so to be resumed shall not exceed one-twentieth part of the whole of the lands aforesaid, and that no such resumption shall be made of any lands on which any buildings may have been erected, or which may be in use as gardens or otherwise for the more convenient occupation of any such buildings:

PROVIDED also that it shall be lawful for any person duly authorized in that behalf by Us, Our heirs and successors, to take and occupy such water privileges, and to have and enjoy such rights of carrying water over, through or under any parts of the hereditaments hereby granted, as may be reasonably required for mining or agricultural purposes in the vicinity of the said hereditaments, paying therefor a reasonable compensation:

Dear Captain Jackson:

J.R. Sharpe of Alert Bay wires me and writes me that he applied on April 15th for a lease on the foreshore of the Industrial Reserve, Alert Bay for the purpose of building a marine ways and boat building industry. He says he is being seriously embarrassed by not getting any action and the application was made through the Indian Agent, who is doing all he can. He further says he is willing to sign a lease, etc., and would like to get a permit to enter the foreshore and establish his business on the foreshore which has been agreed to by the Indians and Mr. Todd.

It is not clear to me what he wants. Presumably he is trying to lease a piece of the Industrial Reserve, which if not a regular Indian Reserve, at least belongs to the Indian Department. If that is the case, why not let him go ahead on the understanding that he will sign the regular lease. It would seem to me as if he would also need to get a lease of the foreshore from the Provincial Government, which, except for one or two public harbours, all belong to the Province. I don't suppose the fact that this Industrial Reserve belongs to the Dominion who give them any claim on the foreshore, except that it is customary when someone applies to the Provincial Government for a foreshore lease, to ask them to produce the consent of the riparian owners. Apparently he is in a desperate hurry, because he has had to move immediately from his previous location.

Yours faithfully,

A.W. NEILL.

Dear Mr. Anfield:

The North-West Telephone Company wishes to apply for permission to use the transmitter site which was discussed with you and Mr. Todd on Mr. Tupper's visit to Alert Bay last week. A map is attached showing the proposed site in detail.

It is proposed to erect three wooden 50-ft. poles for an antenna system, and a small frame building to house the new radio transmitter. The power and telephone facilities will be extended around the back of the Preventorium to this location.

Once the equipment is installed, it will be remotely controlled from the Telegraph Office. It will be necessary, of course, for our staff to make periodic inspections of the equipment every three or four months.

After a thorough investigation this was found to be the only site which met all the requirements for a station of this type. For maximum efficiency a location should be chosen which has a clear unobstructed view in the direction of Vancouver. As the island is for the most part heavily wooded with steep hillsides, this is the only readily accessible point which meets these requirements.

It is very unlikely that this equipment will interfere with the broadcast receiving sets used by the School; but if any interference arises, this company will guarantee to eliminate it to your satisfaction.

With regard to possible danger to the children, the power service will be 3 phase 220 volt which, of course, is already on the school property; and the line will be constructed to conform to standard practices. The antenna will be made from heavy duty telephone material and set well above the ground, and will carry no dangerous voltages. A small shatter-proof glass window with a heavy mesh screen and a double locked door should eliminate the possibility of the children entering the building.

The North-West Telephone Company would pay $50.00 a year for the use of this property. It is felt that this is a reasonable amount for the use of this property as it is on a side hill and unsuitable for agricultural purposes.

It is believed that all the details discussed by Mr. Tupper, our Radio Engineer, with yourself and Mr. Todd have been outlined above, and if this proposal meets with your approval we would appreciate any action you might take to expedite the agreement in that we wish to improve the telephone service to the Alert Bay community as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) "C.B. Wiflock" (?)

There is one point which I am not clear on, and that is the status of the school property between the province and the Dominion, and I would not care to have anything take place which would infringe upon the Crown Grant of this property.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter dated the 27th June requesting to be advised as to the status of Alert Bay Indian Industrial School Reserve which was transferred to the Dominion Government by the Province of British Columbia by Order in Council No. 621, dated 21st June, 1939, and in reply I wish to state that in all respects the status of this Reserve is the same as that of all other Reserves in British Columbia outside of the area of the former Railway Belt and transferred to the Dominion Government by the Province of British Columbia by Order in Council No. 1036, dated the 29th July, 1936.

This Reserve is, therefore, subject to those provisions as set out in Order in Council No. 1036 which apply to all other Reserves in British Columbia.

With the passing of this Order in Council this Department is now in a position to deal with the matter of allocation of the various lots shown on the plan of survey that was made some years ago and can now issue location tickets covering such lots and we will be glad to have you forward a list of those entitled to the various lots, when consideration will be given to the issuing of the required location tickets.
