Dear Sir:

Re Subdivided Lands on Cormorant Island adjacent to the Alert Bay Indian School.

Your letter of April 30th, 1941, in which you ask for approval of allocations to various Indians on Cormorant Island, has resulted in a more complete examination of this whole problem.

The writer is embarrassed in the matter due to the fact that under date of April 15th you were advised that Edwin Cook might be located to Lot No. 19 in the subdivision, and on July 8th, 1940, that with the passing of the Order-in-Council confirming ownership in His Majesty the King in the Right of Canada it was intimated that location tickets might be issued. There are probably other instances where the writer has encouraged you to believe that locations might be granted on Cormorant Island.

We have now run into administrative difficulties. If you will consult Section 21 of the Indian Act you will note that it provides that no one shall be deemed to be lawfully in possession of any land on a reserve unless he has been, or is, located for the same by the band, or the council of the band, with the approval of the Superintendent General. It is obvious that the provisions imposed by this section cannot be implemented in the case of Cormorant Island, and it is not possible, therefore, to locate Indians to the subdivision lands.

Cormorant Island according to the title belongs to all the Indians of British Columbia. We can see no way, therefore, in which we can legally transfer ownership in any part of it to any individual Indian. Should we attempt to do so we would be creating a new Indian band recruited from Indians who already have band membership in their band of origin and giving them title to land to which as individuals they have no possible claim. The matter has been very

M.S. Todd, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.
carefully considered departmentally and the suggestion is being entertained that the Cormorant Island lands adjacent to the Alert Bay School should be regarded as Indian property used in conjunction with the school. As the school itself is presumably operated for the general benefit of the Indians of British Columbia this would not be an inconsistent view to take. Should the school administration wish to use these lands as a field for a sort of extension course possibly graduates of the school could possess and use them on a permit basis during pleasure of the Superintendent General. Those capable of serving as an example to succeeding crops of pupils could be permitted to remain so long as they performed that function. On the other hand if they did not make good and ceased to be a source of inspiration to the pupils in the school they could be returned to their band of origin and their places taken by others.

The writer has been charged by the Director with the task of finding a solution to this problem of land holding on Cormorant Island. This letter will not go forward to you until it has been considered by the Superintendent of Welfare and Training. No conclusion save that we cannot grant locations has been reached, and we would very much appreciate any observations with relation to these lands which you, or the principal of the school, or both of you, care to submit.

A copy of this letter is going forward to the Commissioner for British Columbia for his consideration and for any comment which he may care to make in this matter which relates not exclusively to your own agency but to the Indians generally of your province. In order that Major MacKay may be fully informed it is suggested that your reply should be submitted through his office.

The writer again expresses regret that we may have started you on a false trail in this connection, but it does appear wise that the situation should be faced before it becomes even more complicated.

Yours truly,

D.J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.
Memorandum to: The Director.

Re Alert Bay Industrial School,
otherwise known as Cormorant Island Indian Reserve.

This Indian reserve consisting of .......... acres, and in part occupied by the Alert Bay Industrial School, was conveyed from the Crown Provincial to the Crown Dominion by Order-in-Council 1036, dated 29th July, 1938.

The writer's information is that it is held in common to all the bands of British Columbia.

It appears that dating back some years, possibly to 1904, ex-students or graduates from the Alert Bay Industrial School have been encouraged to take up and settle on allotments in the Cormorant Island Reserve. It in fact appears that 61 acres was surveyed and laid out in sub-division lots for this express purpose. Recent applications have been made by Indian Agent Todd to actually locate Indians to these sub-division lots.

We immediately run into difficulties by reason of Section 21 of the Indian Act which, as you will recall, provides that no one shall be deemed to be lawfully in possession of any land in a reserve unless he has been, or is, located for the same by the band, or the council of the band, with the approval of the Superintendent General. As the provisions imposed by the section cannot be implemented it is not possible to issue location tickets.

It is suggested in Mr. Taggart's memorandum hereunder that the provisions of Section 21 and related sections might be avoided if His Excellency in Council were to proclaim Section 21 of the Act inoperative insofar as Cormorant Island Indian Reserve is concerned. Even were this done, however, it would only have the effect of rendering the present provisions of the Act relating to the issue of location tickets inoperative and would substitute no alternative procedure under which location tickets might be issued.

This..........
This brings up the whole question as to whether or not it is expedient and desirable to give "individual Indian title" to an Indian covering lands which belong to all the Indians of British Columbia.

The writer is not aware or does not understand what Agent Todd's objective is in settling school graduates on little 8 acre patches of land at Cormorant Island presumably far from the communities of which such students are members. It would appear to follow that in doing so he is in effect setting up a new band recruited from the school population on land that belongs not to them, or to such new band, but to the Indians of British Columbia generally.

On the other hand it is suggested that if the settling of students on land adjacent to the residential school is in the nature of a post-graduate course in domestic economy it might be well to retain the land as part of the school equipment. As the school itself is presumably operated for the general benefit of the Indians of British Columbia the lands used expressly for the extension of the school's sphere of influence would fall into the same category of use for the general benefit of the Indians of British Columbia. This I think we can justify. I frankly do not think we can justify conveying an interest in this land to young Indians who presumably are members of bands elsewhere in the province.

With all respect the writer suggests that no location tickets be issued, and that the occupants be advised immediately that it is not proposed to give them location tickets or any other evidence of Indian title. If desirable to set up students on the Cormorant Island Indian Reserve might it not be well to confine it to a yearly permit. In this way undesirables could be sent back to their bands should they fail to make good, or in other words they would be retained on this reserve only so long as by their presence and hoped for success they were an object lesson and source of inspiration to succeeding graduating classes.

Granting an Indian graduate of the school a location ticket would be the means of establishing him on Cormorant Island by legal process. On the other hand it might be argued that the test applicable to whether or not he remain on the island should be his proven capacity to maintain himself in such a manner as to be a source of inspiration to those who follow him to this school.

It is...........
It is suggested that the matter might be carefully considered. The writer confesses that he has not helped the situation much by signing a letter dated April 12th, 1941, advising the Agent that Indians may be registered as owners of the land. However on giving the matter more careful consideration I do not think he can be under the Act, and I do not think he should be as a matter of departmental policy.

Our Files Nos. 156-0-9B, 15156-4, and 15156-5, are submitted with this memorandum for consideration.

D.J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Allan

Re: Cormorant Island Indian Reserve,
Alert Bay Industrial School,
Lot No. 1957, Runert District, B.C.

Although this area is used as an Industrial School site, it is, in reality, a regular Indian Reserve of the same status as any other Indian Reserve in British Columbia, for by the terms of Provincial Order in Council 821, 21st June, 1939, which transferred title from the Province to the Dominion, it is subject to the same provisions as the majority of British Columbia Indian Reserves conveyed from the Crown Provincial to the Crown Dominion by Order in Council 1036, 29th July, 1938.

So far it has not been allotted to any particular Band, but is said to be common to all Bands in British Columbia.

As outlined in Mr. Brown's memorandum hereunder, the question of allotment of parcels of land to ex-students of the School dates back to 1904, when application for approval was made, but this was eventually held up awaiting the clearance of the title.

You raise the question of authority by which such allotment may be made. It seems to the writer that this Reserve is in the same category as a few others in British Columbia; for instance Poplar Island, which was conveyed from the Province to the Dominion by Order in Council 1036 and is held in common for tribes in the Fraser River Valley; and the Lots in the city of New Westminster, which were set aside in the same manner and which are administered absolutely from Head Office with no reference to any group of Indians. Another such case
somewhat similar is Hamilton Island (although this property is owned by one Band by special legislation) but it would appear that the same principle applied.

However, it is evident that by provisions of the Indian Act, once this land became an Indian Reserve as defined by the provisions of the Act, it is subject to the provision of Clause 21 with respect to allotments or location tickets, unless the provision of Clause 3 has been or is to be invoked, in which case the Superintendent General would become in supreme control.

In the case in point it would seem desirable to have this Reserve removed from the control of any particular Band and placed in full control of the Superintendent General by proclamation, through the medium of an Order in Council.
MEMORANDUM

Mr. Allan,

re Subdivision of Industrial School Reserve, Alert Bay, B.C.

In 1891 the Provincial Government of British Columbia set apart as a reserve 410 acres on Cormorant Island, B.C., designated as the Alert Bay Industrial Reserve.

In 1904 the Agent requested a portion of the land be subdivided and allotted to certain ex-pupils of the school who had been permitted by the former Agent to settle on a portion of the property. The request was approved and a subdivision of 61 acres was laid out by survey. The question of issuing location tickets was brought up but it was decided the reserve was not an Indian reserve within the meaning of the Act as the title was in the Province not in the Dominion. In consequence although Indians have been located to lots since that date such location has been by approval only.

However on June 21st, 1939 title to the said Reserve was conveyed by Provincial Order-in-Council to the Dominion Government and when the Agent subsequently inquired re the issue of location tickets you advised him under letter of July 8th, 1940, that the Department now had the authority to do so and that if he would forward a list of...
list of the Indians located with Departmental approval we would consider the issue of tickets.

The matter has not progressed further, but recently we received requests for Departmental approval of locations to two young Indians. Do you wish me to take steps to start the location ticket system on this subdivision or did something (which doesn't appear on file) hold up the whole question?

Memorandum to: File.

The problem raised by correspondence on the attached file does not appear to have been settled. The facts would appear to be as follows:

1. Cormorant Island and the Alert Bay Subdivision is the property of all the Indians of British Columbia and belongs to no particular band.

2. The Act requires that Indians be "located" to land "by the band or the council of the band" with the approval of the Superintendent General (Section 21).

3. As there is no band (the group at Alert Bay being made up of a collection of individuals who already are band members of existing and recognized bands) there can be no band or band council to locate these people; hence it would appear to follow that no location under the Act is possible. That point appears to be clear.

4. From the above it would appear to follow that no Indian can acquire ownership (in the limited sense of Indian ownership under the Crown) to any land at Alert Bay.

D.J. Allen,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

Dear Mr. Todd:

Telegraph Cove Mills which for many years has supplied the School with slabs for heating purposes has been practically taken over by the Airforce and we are having extreme difficulty in getting supplies of fuel for the School. These people had a contract with us for 600 cords per year, but on the present contract only 200 cords have been delivered, and we are down to less than 50 cords on hand.

This situation has been grievously accentuated by the present cold snap. The mill is closed down completely and they have utilized every available piece of fire wood to keep their lighting plant running. They can give us no assurance whatever of any further cordwood for some considerable time, if ever.

We are taking immediate steps to try and get a supply of coal, and we expect 50 tons this week-end, and a further 100 tons inside of a month. This should do us until June.

Immediate steps must be taken to insure an adequate supply of fuel for the next School year 1943-44, and with the present coal situation it would appear to be essential that we put in a large supply of cordwood. There is an adequate supply of this on the School land, and I am planning to engage two Indians ex-pupils to cut 300 cords immediately.

I would like you to make sure with the Department that there are no objections to the School supplying itself with wood from the School lands, which I now understand are gazetted as a regular Indian Reserve.

I do not expect there will be much difficulty, but consider it wise to ask you to make sure of this to prevent any possible complications in the future. It is specifically understood that all wood cut will be solely for the use of the School and the Preventorium.

Ottawa, March 10th., 1944.

MEMORANDUM: SUPT. OF RESERVES & TRUSTS.

Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve.

Cormorant Island comprises the site of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School and the above tract of land consisting of 1/2 acres. When the Royal Commission on Indian Affairs for the Province of British Columbia were asked to declare this land an Indian Reserve, they replied, - "Inasmuch as the tract of land comprised in the Industrial School Reserve at Alert Bay was alienated by the Province of British Columbia and subsequently acquired by the Government of the Dominion of Canada for a school reserve, the Commission has no authority to constitute or confirm the whole or any portion thereto as an Indian Reserve under the terms of the Agreement."

School Reserves vested in the Dominion are usually considered as land set aside for school purposes rather than an Indian Reserve and prior to 1939 the file indicates the above Reserve was considered as such. Provincial Order-in-Council No. 621 dated June 21, 1939, transferred the title of the above Reserve from the Province to the Dominion. The words of this document which reads, - "conveyed to His Majesty the King in the right of the Dominion of Canada in trust for the use and benefit of the Indians of the Province of British Columbia" seems to have the effect of changing the status of this tract of land. It did not appear in the Schedule of Indian Reserves prior to the date of this Provincial Order-in-Council, but since that has been listed as Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve.

Last month we derived some revenue from this property in the form of wood dues and the status or ownership of the Reserve will determine the disposal of these funds. Proceeds from a School Reserve would naturally be placed in ordinary Revenue, but if it is an Indian Reserve belonging to all the Indians in British Columbia, I consider a special --
a special account would have to be opened. Immediately the question of expenditure comes up and the question of authority and fairness of disposing of these funds looms up as an administrative difficulty. May I suggest that we have a ruling (if you consider necessary from the legal office) as to the disposal of this revenue.

We have no Trust Fund Account set up which is owned in common by all the Indian Bands in British Columbia. I might here refer to the regulations provided by Order-in-Council P.C. 7282 in connection with the sale of "Out-offs" in that Province which stipulated that 50% of the proceeds therefrom shall belong to all the Indians in British Columbia, but a Departmental ruling to the contrary prevailed.

Chief Treasury Officer.

CERTIFIED COPY OF A MINUTE of the Honourable the Executive
Council, approved by His Honour the Lieutenant-
Governor on the 21st day of June, A.D. 1939.

TO HIS HONOUR
THE LIEUTENANT-GOVERNOR IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to recommend:

THAT under authority of Section 92 of the "Land Act," being Chapter 144, "Revised Statutes of British Columbia, 1936," and Section 2 of Chapter 35, "British Columbia Statutes 1919," being the "Indian Affairs Settlement Act," that Lot One Thousand Nine Hundred and Fifty-seven (1357), in Rupert District, containing Four Hundred and Twelve (412) acres, more or less, be conveyed to His Majesty the King in the right of the Dominion of Canada in trust for the use and benefit of the Indians of the Province of British Columbia, subject however to the right of the Dominion Government to deal with the said land in such manner as they may deem best suited for the purpose of the Indians including a right to sell the said land and fund or use the proceeds for the benefit of the Indians subject to the condition that in the event of any Indian tribe or band in British Columbia at some future time becoming extinct that any land hereby conveyed for such tribe or band, and not sold or disposed of as heretofore provided, or any unexpended fund being the proceeds of any such sale, shall be conveyed or repaid to the grantor, and that such conveyance shall also be subject to the following provisions:
PROVIDED NEVERTHELESS that it shall at all times be lawful for Us, Our heirs and successors, or for any person or persons acting in that behalf by Us or their authority, to resume any part of the said land which it may be deemed necessary to reserve for making roads, canals, bridges, towing paths or other works of public utility or convenience; so, nevertheless that the lands so to be resumed shall not exceed one-twentieth part of the whole of the lands aforesaid, and that no such resumption shall be made of any lands on which any buildings may have been erected, or which may be in use as gardens or otherwise for the more convenient occupation of any such buildings:

PROVIDED also that it shall be lawful for any person duly authorized in that behalf by Us, Our heirs and successors, to take and occupy such water privileges, and to have and enjoy such rights of carrying water over, through or under any parts of the hereditaments hereby granted, as may be reasonably required for mining or agricultural purposes in the vicinity of the said hereditaments, paying therefor a reasonable compensation;

PROVIDED also that the Department of Indian Affairs shall through its proper officers be advised of any work contemplated under the preceding provisions that plans of the location of such work shall be furnished for the information of the Department of Indian Affairs, and that a reasonable time shall be allowed for consideration of the said plans and for any necessary adjustments or arrangements in connection with the proposed works;

PROVIDED also that it shall be at all times lawful for any person duly authorized in that behalf by Us, Our heirs and successors, to take from or upon any part of the hereditaments hereby granted, any gravel, sand, stone, lime, timber or other material which may be required in the construction, maintenance, or repair of any roads, ferries, bridges, or other public works. But nevertheless paying therefor reasonable compensation for such materials as may be taken for use outside the boundaries of the hereditaments hereby granted;

PROVIDED also that all travelled streets, roads, trails, and other highways existing over or through said land at the date hereof shall be excepted from this grant.

AND TO FURTHER RECOMMEND THAT a certified copy of this Minute, if approved, be transmitted to the Registrar, Land Registry Office, Victoria, in the Province of British Columbia to the intent that such certified copy be accepted by him as a conveyance of the said land to His Majesty the King
in the right of the Dominion of Canada as represented by the Department of Indian Affairs of Canada, without further formal instrument of transfer subject to the said provisos and conditions.

AND TO FURTHER RECOMMEND that a certified copy of this Minute, if approved, be forwarded to the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

DATED this 20th day of June, A.D. 1939.

"A. W. Gray"
Minister of Lands

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 31st last, file #156-0-9A, and in reply to same I beg to advise you as follows.

I communicated with the Rev. S. J. Wickens, Principal of St. Michael's School, who discussed with me the question of spending the One Hundred Fifty Dollars ($150.00), as suggested by yourself. Mr. Wickens informed me that the fences and drainage appear to be in satisfactory condition, with the exception of the drainage system passing through the Preventorium property.

This matter is giving us great concern at the moment and is considered urgent. The drainage under this building is deplorable and certainly not in keeping with the health requirements of our department.

For your information, the run-off from a portion of the school property passes alongside and under the Preventorium building; and if a retaining wall could be built and some cement laid, it would solve this problem.

It would use most of this money, if not all, to make a proper job, and the money could not be spent for a better purpose. I would recommend that an accountable cheque be forwarded and that I be given authority to undertake and supervise this work. Pay sheets and invoices covering materials would be submitted at the conclusion of the project.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 20 NOVEMBER 1944

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 7th November, 1944, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, stating:

That Lot 1957 Rupert District, Province of British Columbia (412 acres) is held by His Majesty in the right of Canada in trust for the use and benefit of all Indians of the Province of British Columbia, subject to the right to deal with the said land and property in such manner as may be deemed best suited to the needs of the said Indians;

That the Alert Bay Industrial School is located on part of the said land and on the remainder there is reported to be approximately five hundred thousand (500,000) feet board measures of merchantable timber isolated from other commercial stands;

That the "Regulations for the Disposal of Timber on Indian Reserves (British Columbia)" established by Order in Council dated the fifth day of May, 1921, provide, inter alia, that no timber on Indian Reserves shall be disposed of without surrender (Sec. 1) and in case of sale shall be offered by public tender (Sec.3);

That it is considered impractical to attempt to obtain a surrender by a majority vote of all Indians of British Columbia and that due to the small size of the timber stand and its isolation there is no likelihood of obtaining competitive bids such as would warrant the labour and expense of public advertisement; and

That an offer has been received from William G. Lawson of Alert Bay, British Columbia, presently operating in adjacent areas, to cut the said stand of timber at a stumpage and royalty rate of Three Dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75) per thousand feet board measure, which offer is recommended for acceptance by the Indian Agent at Alert Bay and the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia.

The Minister, therefore, recommends that the merchantable timber on the Indian Reserve at Alert Bay described as part of Lot 1957 Rupert District, Province of British Columbia, be sold to William G. Lawson of Alert Bay, British Columbia, at a stumpage and royalty rate of Three Dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75) per thousand feet board measure, without formal surrender and without public advertisement as required by the "Regulations for the Disposal of Timber on Indian Reserves (British Columbia)", all other provisions of the said Regulations remaining in full force and effect.

The Honourable

Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B. C.

Your letter of June 19th last, file #33-6-1069, has been received, and in reply I beg to give you the following information.

(1) Originally Industrial School Reserve, Cormorant Island, Kwawkewlth Agency, consisted of 412 acres.

(2) On June 18th, 1915, a portion of this Reserve was surveyed and subdivided and known as Lot Plan 227 B.C. Sub-Division of part of Indian Industrial School Reserve, Alert Bay, Cormorant Island, and contained 40 acres. This portion was surveyed into lots of approximately one acre, and since then quite a number of the lots have been taken up by various Indians of this Agency who have built homes thereon.

(3) The balance of Indian Industrial School Reserve consists of 372 acres, part of which has been cleared and occupied by St. Michael's Indian Residential School, but this part has never been surveyed. The School has merely been clearing land on this portion of the Reserve year after year and putting it under cultivation. This area consists of a strip of land running straight through the Reserve from the foreshore in front of the School buildings to the foreshore at the rear of the Reserve, as per the attached rough sketch. The acreage cleared by the School is not known but I would say that it would be in the neighborhood of 40 acres. The balance of the Reserve south-west of the cleared land occupied by the School is virgin timber now being logged off.

(4) As I have been working on a plan for some considerable time to have the Sub-Division and area now being logged off transferred to the Nimpkish Band to provide more space for them to build homes, it is considered a new survey should be made, setting aside the present portion of the Reserve now cleared and occupied by the School for school purposes.

(5) The 40 acre Sub-Division should be transferred to the Nimpkish Band and re-named "Nimpkish Reserve No. 8".

(6) That portion of Industrial School Reserve now being logged off and not occupied or used by St. Michael's Indian Residential School, be surveyed and transferred to the Nimpkish Band, naming it "Nimpkish Reserve No. 9".

In asking for these surveys and making these recommendations, it is being done for the following reasons:

St. Michael's Indian Residential School does not require any further property for the use of the School other than that which is now cleared and occupied.
could continue to give them permits to cut wood on the timbered area, if and when it was considered necessary.

In the early days the Nimpkish Band and the Department allowed members from other Bands to locate and occupy building sites on Alert Bay Reserve #1, owned by the Nimpkish Band. These people have been residents on this Reserve for a great many years and are trespassers. These members from other Bands are occupying property which is needed by members of the Nimpkish Band to build homes for their children, and has always been a source of trouble. Many Nimpkish Indians have been given lots on Industrial School Sub-Division because they could not find a location to build on their own Reserve.

Of recent years this question has been slowing coming to a showdown, and more recently some members of the Nimpkish Band have suggested that members of other Bands residing on Alert Bay Reserve #1 should either transfer to the Nimpkish Band or return to their own Reserves, and in this suggestion I have concurred.

At the present time I have a few applications from outsiders who are now living on Alert Bay Reserve #1, to be accepted into the Nimpkish Band, and these will be placed before a meeting of the Nimpkish people as soon as it can be arranged. I do not think that it would be fair to the outsiders not to give them an opportunity to transfer to the Nimpkish Band after they have been permitted to live here all these years and, therefore, it is my intention to approach this subject in the following way.

A meeting of the Nimpkish Band will be called to ascertain from them if they are willing to accept all outsiders now living on the Reserve into their Band, subject to their share of Band Funds being transferred with them, and the Department transferring the Sub-Division and timbered area of Industrial School Reserve to the Nimpkish Band, together with the proceeds of the sale of timber which is now being logged off.

Should the present trespassers not wish to transfer to the Nimpkish Band after being given an opportunity to do so, they will be asked to return to their own Reserves.

If this plan could be worked out it will solve all our present problems insofar as providing necessary space for the building of new homes so badly needed at the present time. It will also compensate the Nimpkish people for their generosity shown all these years to these trespassers.

As it will not be possible to place this plan before the Department at an early date, it is recommended that the proceeds of the sale of the timber now being removed from Industrial School Reserve be set aside in a special account in Ottawa, so that it will be available for clearing land and opening up roads on these Reserve, in order that the Indians may settle thereon. This money should definitely be set aside for this purpose because it is going to cost considerable, and no Indian will take up property unless he has access to it by a proper road.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM

THE DIRECTOR

Re: Alert Bay School Land

A parcel of approximately 412 acres on Cormorant Island is held by His Majesty in trust for "all the Indians of British Columbia" (authority executive minute No. 831 dated June 26, 1939). It is the writer's conception that this property is land held for school purposes and is not an Indian Reserve.

It appears from the correspondence that the bulk of this land is surplus to the needs of the school and parts of it have been used for many years as a place to locate pupils of the school who, for some reason or other, did not wish to return to their Band of origin. Now, under such circumstances, such Indians could obtain any legal right of possession eludes the writer. Not being an Indian Reserve, they could not hold under location ticket and even if it were desired that they should, there is no Band organization to allot the land to them as required by Section 21 of the Act. The fact, however, emerges that many Indians are actually there and the writer believes there are instances where Indians have sold their holdings on this land to others for a cash consideration. The whole legal situation is most obscure and unsatisfactory.

Indian Agent Todd now comes forward with a proposal. He suggests that all of this land that is not actually required for school purposes be transferred to the Nimpkish Band who live adjacent to it and who have inadequate land (approximately 45 acres) on their present Reserve. He further suggests that those who presently live on the school land and who have been there for some years be offered membership in the Nimpkish Band subject to the usual condition of transfer of any funds to which they may be entitled by virtue
of membership in their Bands of origin. He also suggests that if this were done a further subdivision of the Alert Bay school land could be made and Nimpkish Indians who require homes established thereon.

The proposal has, in the judgment of the writer, considerable merit but there are legal difficulties in the way concerning which I cannot clearly see the solution.

If in fact the Alert Bay land belongs to all the Indians of British Columbia, what authority has the Department to give it to the Nimpkish Band without consideration. In my judgment it would not be sufficient to declare the land surplus to the needs of the school and therefore unnecessary to retain it for its original purpose. It is suggested that either the Nimpkish Band or this Department on behalf of the Nimpkish Band would have to purchase it and place its value in money in the special account which we carry in the name of the Indians of British Columbia generally. It is apparent that Indian Agent Todd thinks it a simple matter to convey this land to the Nimpkish Band by executive order. It does not appear to the writer that it is so simple and I feel that if it is to be acquired for the purposes of the Nimpkish Band, it can only be by purchase either from the funds of the Nimpkish Band, which amount to only $1,950.00, or by purchase from appropriation for the Nimpkish Band at its actual appraised value. The latter would appear to be the only practical course of action and if it were done in this way, should be subject to the condition that all Indians presently resident on the Alert Bay land who are willing to be so absorbed should be transferred to the Nimpkish Band and those who object returned to their Bands of origin.

D. J. Allen,
Superintendent,
Reserves & Trusts.

You will recall that the problem which had its origin in the settlement of Indians of various Bands on the Alert Bay school property is giving the Agent at Alert Bay some concern. I am enclosing a copy of a memorandum from the Superintendent of Reserves and Trusts setting out the legal difficulties of implementing Agent Todd's suggestions which, were it not for the said legal difficulties, constitute a practical solution which merits serious consideration.

It does not appear that we would require for school purposes a large acreage at Alert Bay and it does appear from Agent Todd's recommendations and suggestions that we do require additional land at that point for the accommodation of the Nimpkish Band. The land in question is, however, the property of all the Indians of British Columbia and if that large group is to be deprived of this land asset, it seems to me that they should receive value for it in the form of money.

We have little idea here what the value of the block required by the Nimpkish Band is. We assume it would be beyond the capacity of the Nimpkish Band to pay for it out of their Band funds. It might, therefore, be necessary to purchase it from appropriation and allot it to the Nimpkish Band. Agent Todd suggests that the Indians presently living on the land could be voted into the Nimpkish Band and their affairs administered in future as a part of that Band. This appears to be a happy solution.

Will you, therefore, please give this matter consideration and if you think well of it you might make an appraisal of the value of the land to be transferred and recommend its purchase for the Nimpkish Band, bearing in

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Following my departure for Ottawa, Inspector Coleman had an interview with Agent Todd on June 8th with a view to assisting him in making up a report on the work accomplished on Lot 1957 Cormorant Island, Alert Bay, for the $1,500 expenditure authorized by the Department last January and what he proposed to have done for the additional $1,000 applied for. This conference was not, by any means, an agreement between them as to what should be done, as stated in the Agent's letter of June 12th enclosed herewith, but a statement of the latter's views.

The rough tracing enclosed of the subdivision of the Lot east of the Residential School will show the work already carried out from the information supplied by Agent Todd at the conference referred to, and this will be observed to consist of approximately:

1,000 ft. of beach on Broughton strait graded for a road, no clearing required.
4,000 ft. of roads cleared with a bull-dozer, stumps being pushed to sides of roads and yet to be disposed of. Require grading and graveling. This work exposed springs on Hill Street between Sub-Lots 34 and 35 making it unusable and requiring drainage as well as grading and graveling.
500 ft. of Park Street cleared, graded and gravelled, the only work completed, evidently with the intention to open up Sub-Lot 24 for a school and Sub-Lots 35 and 37 for a recreation ground for Alert Bay Indians.
Sub-Lots 35 and 37 partially cleared for recreation ground.
for Alert Bay Indians.

These cleared areas will all revert to bush as time goes on unless used or travelled over.

The work yet to be done and for which the $1,000 is applied for by the Agent is set out in paragraph (1) of his enclosed letter and would apparently consist of:

(1) Burning stumps on and grading and travelling road "leading to the school", which according to the plan would be about 250 ft. between Sub-Lots 22 and 24 on Park Street.
(2) Clear Lot 24 for construction of new Indian Day School.

His letter of application for the funds dated March 2nd last, forwarded to the Department, advised that the amount was required to carry out the following:

(1) Gravel the roads now cleared with the bull-dozer.
(2) Bridge over springs opened up on Hill Street and establishing drainage as this flow will erode the street, if not controlled.
(3) Clear school and playground site.
(4) Burn all slash and debris, apparently including the bull-dozed stumps alongside the roads opened up.

It will be noted that this is quite a different programme to that originally proposed for the amount asked for. While the Dominion Water and Power Branch will not be able to send a man up to Alert Bay for several months, according to Colonel Whyte of that Branch, the need for such an examination still exists in the light of the foregoing.

Agent Todd advised that the Nimpkish Band are now quite lukewarm about taking over Lot 1957 as an addition to their holdings and having the trespass situation cleared. From Agent Todd's letters, it would appear that they expect to secure the use of the land, ready for occupation, to take care of their overflow without any corresponding obligations. In discussing the Department's problem, as set out in their letter of April lst in which they stated that the interest of
All the Indians of the Province in the Lot would have to be liquidated before it could be transferred to the Nimpkish Band, the Inspector advised that a valuation would have to be made for this purpose and that it would probably be found to be not less than $15,000 for the whole, or about $27.50 per acre. To this he made immediate objection as being far too high which was quite interesting in view of his very much inflated values that we have had to contend with when the public and others endeavour to secure use of Reserve lands in very remote spots, asking an annual rental of $100.00 per acre for the road right-of-way on Thomas Point Reserve. An alternative solution would be to require of Indian occupants of the property, including the use of the recreation ground, an annual rental on a lease basis if the interest of the Indians of the Province as a whole is to be protected.

The greater part of the Agent's letter enclosed is taken up with the purchase of Air Force buildings at Hardy Bay and re-erecting them on Sub-Lot 24 as a five-room school with quarters for four teachers, no suggestion being made as to what use is to be made of the existing and somewhat substantial school on the Reserve. The use of the huts in this manner is expected to cost us $8,000. I can not recommend the expenditure of such a large amount on temporary structures nor do I see the necessity for such an extensive plan as that suggested. I consider that the existing Day School building should be continued as the primary room as the proposed location on Lot 24 on top of the hill is too far for the little legs of the village, being about a mile distant from the main Village and quite a climb.

I forwarded on June 18th a separate letter regarding the purchase of the R.C.A.F. buildings for school use all over the Agency, to the Department but if it is going to cost as much as we estimated in this case to make these buildings over into temporary school buildings, then we should consider proper construction for our money.

In conclusion, I would recommend that nothing further be done in the matter until the interest of B.C. Indians as a whole in the property is extinguished (See Mr. Allan's Memorandum of April 1st, 1946), an examination of the Lot be made by an Engineer of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau in
respect to the Agent's proposals, and a valuation of the property be made by an official of this Office.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Dinmore:

This is to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 1st last, file #L.B. 13718, together with copy of Mr. R. A. Hoey's letter dated May 21st, 1946, file #565586, and your letter of June 1st last, file #L.B. 13718, addressed to Mr. R. A. Hoey, Director, Indian Affairs Branch.

I have carefully perused the latter in which you set out the particulars in respect to the buildings Port Hardy Military Camp, and it is very difficult indeed to understand why the Government itself is not given more consideration by the War Assets Corporation in respect to their own property. These buildings which we are trying to obtain are for Government use, and unless we can obtain them we will be obliged to buy new material which is going to cost the taxpayers a great deal of money. It seems only reasonable that when the Government owns the buildings themselves they should have first priority.

It is my understanding that when any Government buildings are declared surplus to requirements they are turned over to the War Allocation Committee, and they in turn are obliged by regulation to notify all Federal Government Departments that these buildings are available and give them an opportunity to take them over before turning them over to the War Assets Corporation for disposal. Would you please advise me if our Department was advised in accordance with regulations. I am also informed that if Federal Government Departments find they need any surplus equipment/after it has been turned over to War Assets Corporation, that it can be returned to the War Allocation Committee for disposal to Federal Government Departments. I would appreciate if you would advise me if this still can be done.

p.t.o.
I have carefully examined the prices which you have placed on these buildings originally built for the Port Hardy Military Camp, and find the valuation placed on them is all out of proportion when you take into consideration these buildings are located in a swamp in the woods about a mile from shore, where they will first have to be dismantled and then transported over a plank road. If these buildings were located in or near the city of Vancouver where transportation was not a factor, you would be able to get much more for them than you will in their present location; but I am satisfied whoever put the valuation on these buildings has no conception of what it will cost to dismantle these buildings and transport them to a new location for re-building. I am sure when any prospective purchaser goes into the cost of dismantling, transportation, and waste, any offer you may get will only be a fraction of the price you have submitted to our Department.

I am informed that W/C Little, when he was O/C of the Port Hardy-Coal Harbour Airports, purchased similar pre-fabricated buildings for $100 a piece and moved them to Vancouver for re-building. These buildings were practically on the beach at the Airport and could be moved at very little cost and yet, I am informed, he had difficulty in breaking even. Our Department had previously been given priority on these buildings which W/C Little later purchased. Mr. Berry, then Chairman, gave the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, this undertaking on July 22nd, 1944, file #223-36R-600, serial #38, and category #600. We heard nothing further but later learned, to our astonishment, the buildings were sold to W/C Little and other private individuals for a very nominal sum.

In your letter to Mr. Hoey you state there are twenty-nine Loxtave huts, and the price set at 40¢ per square foot amounts to $21,427.20. This works out at an average of $738.87 per building. Recently I have inspected and examined every building in the Military Camp referred to. I know how they are constructed, and in dismantling them there is going to be a considerable waste. The lumber will merely be used for the construction of an ordinary building and not a pre-fabricated building. If these buildings could be sold and used in the same location without dismantling, then the price asked would be more or less in line with their value; but as there is no use for them in their present location and must be dismantled and transported to new locations and rebuilt, I feel anything you can get for them will be like found money.

p.t.o.
Our Department would not be interested in the ten wooden frame construction buildings you refer to at the price asked, as the waste would be so great in tearing down, plus the cost of labour and transportation, that they would cost more than new buildings. We could only take them over as a gift. We are, however, vitally interested in the Lextave huts, as these buildings could be dismantled and the material transported a short distance and used for the construction of an ordinary building. It is our intention, if arrangements can be made, to use this material for Indian homes and schools to educate their children.

For your information, I am again taking this matter up with the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, who, no doubt, will make you an offer in line with the value we place on them for our use.

If we could obtain even twelve or fifteen of these pre-fabricated buildings (or the whole camp at a nominal figure) it will be of great assistance to our Department; and any consideration you can show us will be very much appreciated.

Yours very truly,

(Ms. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B. C.

Just previous to you leaving for Ottawa I discussed with you the serious school situation and other matters in the Kwawkewlth Agency, and requested that you take them up while in the East. As you did not have sufficient time to go into all the detail with me, you requested me to carry on my conversations and go into the details more fully with Inspector Coleman.

Following your departure Mr. Coleman and myself went into these matters fully, and the program we have in mind entails three undertakings which must be worked out together; namely:

(1) Set aside new Indian Day School site in Industrial School Reserve, Alert Bay, B. C. Clearing of the site, graveling and burning refuse on the roads leading to the school, which requires immediate action and reply in order to take advantage of the bulldozer still on the island.

(2) Arrange to take over, purchase if necessary at a nominal figure, pre-fabricated buildings suitable for classrooms from the War Assets Corporation.

(3) Provide sufficient funds for the dismantling, transporting, and re-assembling, with additional material, of some of these buildings on the school site referred to above.

In respect to No. 1, after talking the matter over very carefully with Inspector Coleman, it was decided that the whole of Lot 24, Industrial School Reserve, Alert Bay, should be set aside for school purposes and play ground. This is an excellent level site which has been logged off leaving stumps, small second growth timber and refuse, and I estimate it will cost approximately $500.00 to clear this acre of land. The road which we have been building through the Industrial School Reserve leading to the school site requires to be gravelled, and the refuse on the roads adjacent thereto burned to remove any fire hazard, and I estimate this will cost approximately $500.00. I would guarantee to have this work done for the above figure. As this money is going to be used for school purposes it would naturally have to come from the school vote, and if funds are not available, I would recommend that as the House is still in session, it be requested as a supplementary vote.

In regard to No. 2 I enclose you, herewith, copy of a letter which I have written to Mr. Dinsmore, Director of Lands and Buildings Department, War Assets Corporation, which will be self-explanatory. For the Department's information, I have carefully perused the letter dated June 1st last written by Mr. Fraser of the War Assets Corporation to Mr. R. A. Hoey, Director, in respect to Port Hardy Military Camp, B. C., and

p.t.o.
noted the remarks contained in paragraph two, and also the valuation set on the pre-fabricated buildings. In my opinion, the price asked for these buildings is all out of proportion due to the fact that they are in an isolated place, and the heavy cost that will be involved to remove them elsewhere. It is noted they are asking 40¢ per square foot, which is roughly 35% of the original cost. If we are unable to get these buildings transferred to us without cost, I feel we could well afford to pay 10¢ a square foot or even 15¢ if necessary, and still obtain classrooms at a minimum cost.

I have gone to considerable trouble in working out what it would cost for dismantling, transportation, and re-assembling the buildings required for the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and estimate the cost would be $8,000.00. This would include any additional material we would have to purchase to complete the work. I am enclosing a rough sketch showing how the buildings would be assembled and the plan of the entire school. You will please note provision is also being made for two teacherages in connection with the building. This will give us three classrooms and two play rooms, one of which could be used for a fourth classroom if necessary. We would also have cloak and wash rooms.

I have made a survey of the permanent Indian families now resident in Alert Bay and find there are 136 children of school age and 83 of pre-school age. In addition to this there are 16 children of school age whose families are not permanent residents but live here roughly six months of the year, and their children attend school. These families have 9 children of pre-school age. In regard to the permanent residents of school age, a few of these children are now in the Residential School, but would be discharged and sent to the Day School if accommodation was provided. This would make it possible to take other children into the Residential School from outside villages where no school facilities are provided and where there are not sufficient to establish a permanent school.

As we have been informed that considerable sums of money have been provided for schools in the rehabilitation plan, and as the school situation is such a serious matter, it would seem only right and proper that these funds should be made available at once in order that we can take advantage of this splendid opportunity to provide the needed buildings to properly educate our Indian children.

If we could obtain the buildings referred to at a nominal cost and this plan worked out, we will have the needed schools and teacherage at half the present day cost, and I hope the Department will use every effort to bring this about.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

This is to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 6th last, file #6-13-2, enclosing copy of a letter received from Ottawa, file #156-0-8, dated July 3rd, in respect to my recommendation for the Department to assist Simon Beans in the purchasing of some building materials for the erection of a new home being built on the Industrial School Reserve, Alert Bay, B. C.

First let me say I appreciate the Department's ruling and understand the situation entirely, but I do not believe I have made myself as clear as I should have when recommending this assistance to Beans. When the Department gave Mr. Beans Lot No. 22 on Industrial School Reserve for the purpose of building a home thereon for his family, so that he could educate his children by sending them to the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and for other reasons, they distinctly stated this permission was granted subject to certain conditions. These conditions were explained to Mr. Beans before he was allowed to occupy the lot. He understood them thoroughly and agreed to comply with any requirement of the Department.

He has an application filed in this office to transfer to the Nimpkish Band of Indians if and when it is permissible, and the Nimpkish Band have agreed to accept him in. There is nothing further he can do.

Mr. Beans has told me he is prepared to comply with any requirement of the Department, whether it is transferring to the Nimpkish Band or vacating the property. In the case of the latter it would be at his own responsibility. The Department are not assuming any responsibility whatever in respect to his home, as he was allowed to locate thereon under certain conditions which he must comply with.

p.t.o.
Beans has his house partially completed. This house, when built, will be a credit to himself and the Department. It will cost in the neighbourhood of $4,000.00. I do not feel we are being fair with him by refusing this assistance when we have been helping others under similar conditions on the same Reserve. Our whole thought is to try and encourage Indians to complete good homes, and I do not consider we would be wise in not assisting this progressive Indian when he is willing to comply with every regulation made by the Department.

Supposing something did turn up which I do not think is possible, and he was asked to leave the Reserve - he would merely dispose of his home to another Indian, so in the long run we would be helping some Indian have a good home to live in.

In order to assist this Indian in completing his home so that he will have a place for his family to live in this winter, I am prepared to see that the Department will not have to compensate him in any way for any improvements Beans makes on his Lot should the Department find it necessary to ask him to vacate. Let us help this deserving Indian and let it not be said that we refused to assist someone deserving of help. If there was any question in my mind about the final outcome of Beans' right to locate here I would not, under any consideration, make this request to the Department.

I would, therefore, appreciate if the Department would reconsider and allow me to assist him to the amount requested.

An early reply will be appreciated as the winter is drawing near.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Memorandum.

Miss M. Walton,

Under date of December 8th, 1945, Indian Agent Todd of Alert Bay advised that steps should be taken to open up the Industrial School Reserve on Cormorant Island, Alert Bay, British Columbia. This was also recommended by Commissioner MacKay. The only funds available for the purpose were those to the credit of the "Indians of British Columbia Account" where proceeds of timber, sold on the parcel in question, had been placed and release could only be effected by Order in Council. We arranged with you, since the funds were needed immediately, to advance $1500.00 from your Appropriation for this purpose, to be repaid when the Order in Council had been passed. Various factors contributed to a delay which carried us past the end of the fiscal year.

Now it develops that it would be unwise to expend Trust Funds in the development of this parcel until the Band membership of the Indians living there has been determined and the ownership of the Reserve has been settled. We are, however, faced with the necessity of paying some $1500.00 in accounts incurred in road work and clearing the land. Since it is felt the Reserve will certainly be allotted to Indians, the expenditure could, we feel, safely be made from your Appropriation. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would make the necessary arrangements for the payment of these accounts. If you will return the file to the Trusts Division, Commissioner MacKay will be further advised as to what is now required as preliminaries to settling the entire matter.

For D.J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

Following my departure for Ottawa, Inspector Coleman had an interview with Agent Todd on June 8th with a view to assisting him in making up a report on the work accomplished on Lot 1957 Cormorant Island, Alert Bay, for the $1,500 expenditure authorized by the Department last January and what he proposed to have done for the additional $1,000 applied for. This conference was not, by any means, an agreement between them as to what should be done, as stated in the Agent's letter of June 12th enclosed here-with, but a statement of the latter's views.

The rough tracing enclosed of the subdivision of the Lot east of the Residential School will show the work already carried out from the information supplied by Agent Todd at the conference referred to, and this will be observed to consist of approximately:

1,000 ft. of beach on Broughton strait graded for a road, no clearing required.
4,000 ft. of roads cleared with a bull-dozer, stumps being pushed to sides of roads and yet to be disposed of. Require grading and graveling. This work exposed springs on Hill Street between Sub-Lots 34 and 38 making it unusable and requiring drainage as well as grading and graveling.
500 ft. of Park Street cleared, graded and gravelled, the only work completed, evidently with the intention to open up Sub-Lot 24 for a school and Sub-Lots 35 and 37 for a recreation ground for Alert Bay Indians.
Sub-Lots 35 and 37 partially cleared for recreation ground
for Alert Bay Indians.

These cleared areas will all revert to bush as time goes on unless used or travelled over.

The work yet to be done and for which the $1,000 is applied for by the Agent is set out in paragraph (1) of his enclosed letter and would apparently consist of:

(1) Burning stumps on and grading and graveling road "leading to the school", which according to the plan would be about 250 ft. between Sub-Lots 22 and 24 on Park Street.

(2) Clear Lot 24 for construction of new Indian Day School.

His letter of application for the funds dated March 2nd last, forwarded to the Department, advised that the amount was required to carry out the following:

(1) Gravel the roads now cleared with the bull-dozer.
(2) Bridge over springs opened up on Hill Street and establishing drainage as this flow will erode the street, if not controlled.
(3) Clear school and playground site.
(4) Burn all slash and debris, apparently including the bull-dozed stumps alongside the roads opened up.

It will be noted that this is quite a different programme to that originally proposed for the amount asked for. While the Dominion Water and Power Branch will not be able to send a man up to Alert Bay for several months, according to Colonel Whyte of that Branch, the need for such an examination still exists in the light of the foregoing.

Agent Todd advised that the Nimpkish Band are now quite lukewarm about taking over Lot 1957 as an addition to their holdings and having the trespass situation cleared. From Agent Todd's letters, it would appear that they expect to secure the use of the land, ready for occupation, to take care of their overflow without any corresponding obligations. In discussing the Department's problem, as set out in their letter of App.1st in which they stated that the interest of
all the Indians of the Province in the Lot would have to be liquidated before it could be transferred to the Nimpkish Band, the Inspector advised that a valuation would have to be made for this purpose and that it would probably be found to be not less than $15,000 for the whole, or about $27.50 per acre. To this he made immediate objection as being far too high which was quite interesting in view of his very much inflated values that we have had to contend with when the public and others endeavour to secure use of Reserve lands in very remote spots, asking an annual rental of $100.00 per acre for the road right-of-way on Thomas Point Reserve. An alternative solution would be to require of Indian occupants of the property, including the use of the recreation ground, an annual rental on a lease basis if the interest of the Indians of the Province as a whole is to be protected.

The greater part of the Agent's letter enclosed is taken up with the purchase of Air Force buildings at Hardy Bay and re-erecting them on Sub-Lot 24 as a five-room school with quarters for four teachers, no suggestion being made as to what use is to be made of the existing and somewhat substantial school on the Reserve. The use of the huts in this manner is expected to cost us $8,000. I can not recommend the expenditure of such a large amount on temporary structures nor do I see the necessity for such an extensive plan as that suggested. I consider that the existing Day School building should be continued as the primary room as the proposed location on Lot 24 on top of the hill is too far for the little legs of the village, being about a mile distant from the main Village and quite a climb.

I forwarded on June 18th a separate letter, regarding the purchase of the R.C.A.F. buildings for school use all over the Agency, to the Department but if it is going to cost as much as we estimated in this case to make these buildings over into temporary school buildings, then we should consider proper construction for our money.

In conclusion, I would recommend that nothing further be done in the matter until the interest of B.C. Indians as a whole in the property is extinguished (See Mr. Allan's Memorandum of April 1st, 1946), an examination of the Lot be made by an Engineer of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau in
respect to the Agent's proposals, and a valuation of the property be made by an official of this Office.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Indian residents of Alert Bay, through the Native Brotherhood of B. C., are again inquiring what progress has been made in respect to the Industrial School Reserve, Alert Bay, being transferred to the Nimpkish Band of Indians, subject to certain conditions.

The Indians point out that as the Department have ruled that no further development on this Reserve can take place until such time as the status of this Reserve is definitely settled, they feel now that they have complied with the Department's suggestions in every respect they should be receiving information from the Department when they can expect the matter to be concluded. I realize how necessary it is for the status of this Reserve to be clarified at an early date as it means so much to the Indians here, some of whom wish to build homes but are unable to under present restrictions.

MEMORANDUM:

W.M. Cory, Esq.,
Departmental Solicitor

I am enclosing herewith Branch file 27156-29 and would be pleased to have you examine the tubbed letters and documents with reference to the Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve on Cormorant Island.

Chief Surveyor Robertson's memorandum of April 4th, 1935 attached to a memorandum dated March 8th, 1929 contains an accurate report of the original minutes of decision with reference to the creation of the reserve and the history thereof is further outlined in a memorandum by George Patrick dated April 4th, 1935 and a letter from C.H. Taggart, May 10th, 1939.

Our present problem is that the Nimpkish Band, whose Reserve Alert Bay No.1 is presently overcrowded, have expressed a desire to secure part of the Industrial School Reserve for purposes of expansion. The problem is further complicated by the fact that during the years of operation of the Industrial School graduating students, who have been members of various British Columbia Bands, have been permitted to build homes on a subdivided portion of the Industrial School Reserve. As I said previously, this practice has been going on for a good many years now and so far as we can tell there are at least 30 families of various Bands residing on a subdivision on the Industrial School Reserve.

The Industrial School does not actually use or require more than a small portion of the Reserve's 412 acres and it has been suggested that the outcome to the present problem would be to create a new Band made up of the various other Band members who are residing on the Island together with any Nimpkish Band members who might wish to transfer to the new Band and set aside
for the new Band the subdivided portion and sufficient additional land to provide for reasonable expansion in the future. In short, we would like to create a new Reserve with part of the Industrial School Reserve and set it aside for the use of a new Band.

Our problem is whether this is possible. As you will note the original minute of decision, setting apart the Industrial School Reserve, stated that the land was to be for the Nimpkish Band but the original minute was amended setting apart the property as "Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve". While the minute of decision above mentioned was dated March 10th, 1891 it was not until June 21st, 1939 that title to the property was actually transferred from the Province of British Columbia to the Dominion, a copy of the Order in Council being hereunder tabbed "A". The said Order in Council conveys the property to the Dominion in trust for the use and benefit of the Indians of British Columbia, subject, however, etc., and it is the part following the words "subject, however," that we are interested in at the moment.

I would be glad if you would examine the correspondence and the Order in Council and advise us on the following points:

1. Under the conditions contained in the Order in Council from the Province have we the right to set aside a portion of the Industrial School Reserve for the use of any Band?

2. If not, have we the right to purchase a portion of the Industrial School Reserve as a reserve for a particular Band and deposit the purchase price in an account to the credit of the Indians of British Columbia?

Briefly, we can see no way out of our present difficulty unless we can create a reserve for a particular Band and while we feel that we probably have such right, there seems some question as to whether we can do so without reimbursing the Indians of British Columbia in general. I would be glad to have you consider the entire matter and let us have the benefit of your advice.

for L.J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

MEMORANDUM TO:

- Mr. Allan -

Re: Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve B.C.

You will recall that the problem regarding settlement of Indians on the above mentioned land, is of long standing and that, despite a large amount of correspondence and investigation, in so far as the Department was concerned, it was never decided (a) that settlement of Indians on this land was desirable or (b) how such settlement could be accomplished, even if desirable, in view of the peculiar status of the land.

I have now had an opportunity to discuss the entire problem, at length, with Agent Todd and with a much more complete picture of the situation at the Island (Cowichan Island), I am of the opinion that the proposal to allot the unused portion of the reserve as a new reserve for the Nimpkish Band is most desirable and almost a necessity due to developments that have taken place in recent years. It is, therefore, proposed to briefly outline herein the status of the Reserve, the situation presently existing thereon and to offer suggestions as to how it may be remedied.

STATUS - The original Minute of Decision setting this reserve apart stated that the land was set apart as Reserve No. 6 of the Nimpkish Band and that it was approved by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works. At the suggestion of the Department (and I have not been able to discover why) the said Minute was amended by Commissioner O'Heilly and again approved by the Chief Commissioner of Lands and Works as follows:

"Minute of Decision, 5th March, 1891, approved by Chief Commissioner of Lands 10th March, 1891, setting apart as reserve 410 acres."

"Minute of Decision
Alert Bay Indian Industrial School reserve.
A reserve of 410 acres situated etc. (description)"

The Royal Commission (1912-14), on being requested to declare a portion of the land to be an Indian reserve, replied that "Inasmuch as the tract of land comprised in the Industrial School Reserve at Alert Bay was alienated by the Province of British Columbia and subsequently acquired by the Government of the Dominion of Canada for a school reserve, the Commission has no authority to constitute or confirm the whole or any portion thereof as an Indian Reserve."
under the terms of the Agreement, the Dominion being the unquestionable owner of the property and unhampered by the terms of the agreement in dealing therewith in such manner as may appear to the Dominion Government to best meet the purposes of the purchase of the said land, but that from what the Commissioner learned at meetings with the Indians at Port Bay, it seems to the Dominion that it would be right and proper to secure in occupation the Indians who have, with the consent or acquiescence of the Department of Indian Affairs, made homes upon the said tract of land."

It is not understood why the Royal Commission referred to the property as having been purchased and to the Dominion Government as being the "unquestionable owner" for neither our records nor those of the Province substantiate such statements. It is difficult to understand how the Commission were misinformed on this matter, but it now appears that they were, and in view of the concluding remarks in the Commissioner's statement, above quoted, it seems safe to assume, that if the true status of the land had been known they probably would have constituted a portion of the land a reserve for the Indians living therein, that is the Nicknack Road.

It was not until 1939 that steps were taken to clarify the status of the land. At that date C. H. Taggart, acting for the Dominion on a "Commission Investigating Ordinance and Admiralty Lands in British Columbia", brought to the attention of both the Dominion and Provincial Governments that the reserve in question had not been included in the schedule of reserves conveyed to the Crown Dominion by C.C. 28th July, 1938.

Investigation by the Provincial authorities confirmed this and, as they were at a loss to know why the title had not been transferred previously, they were prepared to rectify the omission and by Order in Council No. 621 of June 1st, 1939 - Lot 1937 in Rupert District, containing 415 acres more or less, was conveyed to His Majesty the King in the right of the Dominion of Canada "in trust for the use and benefit of the Indians of the Province of British Columbia, subject however to the right of the Dominion Government to deal with the said land in such manner as they may deem best suited for the purpose of the Indians, including a right to sell the said land and fund or use the proceeds for the benefit of the Indians........"

It is the opinion of the Departmental Solicitor, in which the writer concurs, that the Provincial conveyance aforementioned does not create this land a reserve, within the meaning of the Indian Act, as the land was not set apart for the use and benefit of any particular Band of Indians. In consequence the land would fall within the category of "Public Lands of the Dominion" Chap. 114 R.S. 1937 and subject to the consent of the Governor General in Council, the Dominion could, therefore, to quote the terms of the Provincial conveyance "deal with the said land in such manner as they may deem best suited for the purpose of the Indians" without the necessity of securing the consent of the Indians given by way of a surrender of their interest. You will recall that Lots 145, 146 and 154, Group 1, New Westminster District, were not long ago sold to the City of New Westminster after ascertainment that they were not Indian reserve lands within the meaning of the Indian Act.
