Local Situation:

As evidenced by the original Minute of Decision aforementioned, there were Indians of the Nipiski Band on Cormorant Island before any thought was given to officially setting the land in question aside as a reserve and, in fact, according to Agent Todd, the existence of the residential school is due to the fact that the first missionary to these Indians took up a pre-emption adjacent to the then Indian holdings and later surrendered his rights to the pre-emption on the understanding that a school would be opened there. In short, the Indians were generally located in this part of the island before the school was built and it is not clear why it was thought necessary to set aside the entire 412 acres for school purposes, thus overlooking the interests of the Indians who had been residing in the area for some time.

In 1904 the Indian Agent requested that a portion of the 412 acre parcel be subdivided and allotted to certain ex-pupils of the school who had been permitted by the former agent to settle on the land and following approval by the Department a small surveyed subdivision was laid out. The question of issuing Location Tickets for this subdivision was considered at that date and ruled out for the reason that the land was not a reserve within the meaning of the Act. Following the statement of the Royal Commission of 1913-14, concerning the status of this land, the Department instructed the Indian Agent to "give recognition of title in writing to each individual occupant of land on this property". It was understood that the regulated form of Location Ticket was not to be issued.

In 1915 a portion of the Reserve extending across the island and extending to the eastern boundary was subdivided into lots of approximately one acre each, the new lots including, in so far as possible, the improvements and holdings laid out in the former subdivision. The new subdivision, comprising 40 lots and streets, covered the same 60.75 acres and is as shown on Plan B.C. 377.

You will recall that when the problem in question was considered some years ago, we did not view with favour the idea of creating, to all intents and purposes, a new Band made up of ex-pupils of the school and Indians of many bands. The objection was also raised that we would be establishing Indians on small lots where they had no apparent means of earning a living whereas, if they return to their own reserves, they might find ample land.

Information secured since then has clarified the picture considerably and we are now advised that the subdivision is neither entirely populated by pupils nor are they residents from a large number of other places. A fairly recent list, submitted by Agent Todd, shows that out of the 38 heads of families residing on the subdivision, the Band or Agency origins is as follows: Nipiski - 10; Hemililikulla - 5; Kenoskowith - 5; Etekakumunk - 11; Battingi - 1; Tannatamuk - 1, and New Westminster - 1. In short, close to one-half the residents are residents of the Nipiski Band who own land in the vicinity.

While it is true that certain ex-pupils have settled in the subdivision, as stated previously, all residents are not ex-pupils and while Agent Todd can at length give reasons why ex-pupils and...
others wish to settle there, the case of Simon Beams, who is not an ex-pupil, is probably illustrative of the general picture. Beams is apparently an industrious Indian who, through his fishing activities, earned a considerable income yearly while resident with other members of the Musalilikulla Band on their Reserve. However, due to the potlatch custom, as practised by the Band, his industry and substantial earnings gained him next to nothing each year. Realizing this, he publicly declared to his Band that he was giving up the custom and thereafter he and his family were persecuted to such an extent that he concluded he would either have to become enfranchised or seek shelter on other reserves. I gather that he made application to reside on the subdivision on Cormorant Island and was granted permission to do so and since then, through his fishing activities, he has within a few years been able to build a $6,000.00 home and purchase a seine boat for himself.

According to Agent Todd there are many other Indians in his Agency who desire to get away from the potlatch custom but find themselves unable to do so while remaining on their reserve and would be only too willing to move to the Island if they were given a lot. The subdivision is further desirable to the Indians generally in that the fish canneries at Alert Bay on the Southern part of the Island provide a ready market for fish or an opportunity for employment and I understand that all Indians on the Island earn their livelihood in the fishing industry. They are not, nor are likely to be, farmers and require only sufficient land for a house and a garden.

The Nisqually Indians, of whom there are ten presently living on the subdivision, have a reserve almost adjacent to the 412 acre reserve and have several other reserves on the mainland but the mainland reserves are of little or no value to them and the majority live on the Island for they are engaged in the fishing industry or employed in the canneries. Their Cormorant Island Reserve - Nisqually Reserve No. 1 - comprises only about 40 acres and is actually too small and they naturally look to the subdivided area as an escape from the over-crowded conditions on their Reserve.

In short, the Department, by subdividing the area in the first instance and permitting Indians of various Bands to take up residence thereon, has itself created the problem now before us and due to the nature of the improvements made by the Indians on the subdivision, it would be almost impossible at this date to demand that they leave. However, within the past year or so, the Department has built a new day school on the subdivision to take care of the pupils thereon. Apart from the difficulty of stopping settlement and reverting the land to its former use, there would appear to be no real reason to refuse to allow the community to grow, as it has in the past, by settlement of either ex-pupils or other responsible Indians who make application to reside there. Surely our aim is to encourage Indians to make the best possible use of their ability and education and if an Indian can make a better living on Cormorant Island than on his former reserve, why should he be refused the opportunity particularly if he is opposed to the potlatch custom and wishes to get away from it. It is considered that starting with a surveyed subdivision and populating it with a group of Indians who are probably of average intelligence and who are earning more than average wages, there is a fine opportunity to build up a model community.
Solution 7:

It has been proposed that to solve the difficulty presently existing, all that portion of the "Reserve" not required for the use of the Industrial School be set aside as a Reserve for the Nimpkish Band and that all present residents, who are not members of that Band be permitted to transfer therefor. The Nimpkish Band has already passed a resolution that they are willing to take in all present non-member residents and I understand from Agent Todd that the residents are quite willing to transfer to the Nimpkish Band.

The proposal seems fair enough in that in the first instance, if any Band has a right to the land in question, it would be the Nimpkish Band, and in the second place, the Reserves provided for the Nimpkish Band on the mainland are not as suitable for their means of livelihood as is the No. 1 Reserve on Cormorant Island which is too small to accommodate them.

It appears to the writer that there are two possible means of achieving the desired end and while one of the said methods presents many advantages over the other, it is proposed to mention both.

In the first instance, the Minute of Decision, approved on March 10th, 1891, set apart the 410 acres as "Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve" and in the normal course of events it may be assumed, I think, that the Provincial Government should have conveyed title to the Dominion for purposes of a school reserve and not in trust for .......... the Indians of the Province of British Columbia" as provided in the 1893 conveyance. The actual conveyance of title was for an entirely different purpose than that for which the land was originally set aside and while it is possible that the Provincial authorities thought that as the school served Indians generally, the designation "for the Indians of British Columbia" was quite in order, nevertheless, for administration purposes there is a world of difference and it is submitted that the Province had no right or authority to alter the original purpose for which the land was set aside and certainly not without first securing the consent of the Dominion Government.

In short, therefore, it is possible that the Provincial Conveyance, in so far as it recites "in trust for the Indians of the Province of British Columbia" was ultra vires of the Province and if that were the case it would follow, I believe, that the Dominion would take title subject to a trust to use the land for the purpose for which it was originally set aside by the 1891 Minute of Decision - that is, for purposes of an Industrial School.

If the foregoing opinion is sound in law and we can, I assume, declare that part not being used by the school as surplus which would have the effect of retrotransferring title to the Province who have the reverent interest therein. Should it be arranged with the Province that, if we were to declare the land surplus for school purposes, we would have the first opportunity to repurchase it as a reserve for the Nimpkish Band and, as you are aware, under our present arrangement with the Province, we got such land at half price. While

...........
this method might result in securing the land fairly cheaply, there are two objections to it, the first being that the Province might not view with favour our attempt to prove that their conveyance was incorrect. As you are aware, we cut the commercial timber on this property within the past few years, realizing several thousand dollars therefrom and if the true status of the property was determined to be school lands, we would have an awkward time explaining what right we had to cut and sell all the commercial timber.

It is considered that if the Department viewed the proposal of Agent Todd and the Indians with favour, the simplest method of bringing it into effect would be to accept the Provincial conveyance as sound in law, which it of course may be, and simply exercise our right therunder to sell the land or any portion thereof and deposit the proceeds to the credit of the Indians of British Columbia - that is, sell it on behalf of the Indians of British Columbia and purchase it ourselves to be set aside as a reserve for the Nimpkish Band. There would, of course, be no actual sale but merely an Order in Council setting out that the interest of the Indians of British Columbia in the said lands was being extinguished by the payment of so many dollars and that the land was hereby declared to be set apart for the use of the Nimpkish Band.

Before carrying into effect any such proposal it would, of course, be necessary to first ascertain the requirements of the school and also be certain as to whether any arrangement we may have with the school authorities is contrary to our proposal. In the second place, it would be necessary to ascertain what rate per acre should be paid for this land. While Agent Todd has suggested $5.00 an acre as being all that it is worth, now that the timber has been removed off it, I doubt very much whether this figure could be accepted as being a fair price and we shall have to be fairly certain that whatever price is paid would stand up to any criticism that might be levelled against us by some of the Indian organizations for disposing of the land too cheaply. It is possible that there may be some Provincial Crown land on the Island and that we might secure information as to general land values from the Province.

If the proposal is approved and direction is given to arrange the purchase of this land at a fair price, it will, of course, have to make provision for the money in the supplementary estimates for this year and a decision, one way or the other, should be secured at as early a date as is possible.

MEMORANDUM

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve

Your attention is directed to Mr. Brown's memorandum to the Superintendent of Reserves and Trusts hereunder.

After many controversial years, 1891 to 1939, during which the legal ownership of the portion of Cormorant Island occupied by the Alert Bay Industrial School and certain Indians resident thereon, an agreement was reached with the Province pursuant to which the actual legal title was conveyed to the Crown Dominion in trust for the Indians of British Columbia, together with a conveyance of the right to deal with the property in such manner as would best serve the Indians and with specific permission to sell it and use the proceeds for the benefit of B.C. Indians.

This settlement, achieved by long and tedious negotiation with the Province, should not, in the judgment of the writer, be disturbed for any reason, technical or otherwise. The trust imposed by the document of conveyance (B.C. Order in Council No. 821 of June 21, 1939) conferred on the Dominion Government not only the right to deal with the property but to sell it and to use the proceeds for the benefit of the Indians of B.C. This it is submitted gives us full and ample authority to carve out of the lands conveyed to us the land actually required for school purposes and continue to use it as such.

The conditions of the trust are also broad enough to enable the Federal Government to transfer a sum of money properly representing the value of the balance of the lands which are surplus to school needs to a Trust Account to be used in the discretion of the Superintendent General to promote the interests of B.C. Indians in general, leaving the said balance of the lands free from the trust to be disposed of by the Superintendent General as he sees fit.
The said balance could then be transferred to the Nimpkish Band as an additional Reserve on such terms as the Superintendent General may approve. Such terms should be that the Nimpkish Band agrees to accept into its Band membership all Indians presently resident on the said lands and should agree to allot to such resident Indians the actual land and improvements which they presently enjoy, in order that location tickets may be issued to them in accordance with the terms of the Act, any residue of the land to be retained in Band ownership, subject to its right to allot it from time to time to Band members, as provided by the Act.

This arrangement, if approved, would necessitate (a) an appraisal of the value of the lands surplus to school requirements, and (b) a vote by Parliament of the sum of money representing the cash value of the lands.

When the money had been voted and deposited in a Trust Account for the B.C. Indians generally, then by Order in Council the lands could be constituted an Indian Reserve for the Nimpkish Band and the necessary Band transfers and issue of location tickets effected.

It is suggested and recommended that an appraisal be made by Commissioner Arneil and Indian Agent Todd and that such appraisal be accepted as the value of the lands and the required sum be included in the Estimates so that the arrangement herein suggested can be carried out.

The above recommendations are respectfully submitted for approval.

DJA/MC

MEMORANDUM

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve

Further to my memorandum of February 3rd re the Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve, this matter has been discussed fully with Mr. M. S. Todd, the Indian Agent for the Kwawkewlth Agency. In addition to the representations made in the said memorandum of February 3rd, the following information is considered relevant and material.

The Nimpkish Band has a total population of 169 according to the last census. It has seven Reserves comprising in all approximately 557 acres. Only one of these Reserves is occupied by any Indians. Indian Reserve No. 1 which lies on Cormorant Island is only 45 acres in extent and all suitable land is occupied by Indians of the Band to the point where they are already greatly overcrowded, with no possibility of expansion within the limits of that Reserve.

In addition to the Indians of the Nimpkish Band there are many residents on Cormorant Island who have drifted in from other Bands and who have become firmly established for whom provision must be made somewhere. The Nimpkish Band has by resolution agreed to accept into its Band all these transients who have established permanent homes on Cormorant Island and these same people have expressed their desire and willingness to join the Nimpkish Band. The need, therefore, for further land is extremely urgent in order to preserve to the Indian owners the improvements that they have already made on lands to which they have no title.

A further point that must be considered is that the Department has built a new day school to serve the Nimpkish Band on the subdivided portion of the industrial school lands and any difficulty in connection with title to the school property would be straightened out if the arrangement recommended were carried out.
Agent Todd further reports that the Nimpkish Indians resident on Cormorant Island are a most progressive group, all of them engaged in the fishing industry and making very substantial incomes, a part of which they desire to spend in building homes and generally improving living conditions on the Island. As they are presently located it is virtually impossible for them to organize under a representative council, which it is their desire to do in order that they may provide themselves with water services, community hall and community playgrounds, and eventually with all the other services that go with an organized community. They have already electric services in their homes - many of them with hot and cold water - and naturally they want to have security of title to the lands and properties which they have so improved. The Indians themselves and Agent Todd are most anxious that this matter should proceed to a conclusion without delay, as they cannot and will not carry out their further development plans until the question of proper title to their lands can be assured to them.

The whole development programme has been carefully worked out with the full co-operation of the Indians concerned and is strongly recommended by this office. If the question of title to the lands can be worked out in accordance with the memorandum submitted for your attention, it will be necessary to have an immediate appraisal of the lands made and an item put in the Supplementary Estimates to buy out or extinguish the interest of the B.C. Indians in the property. With your approval, it is proposed to ask Commissioner Arneil and Agent Todd to make an immediate appraisal of the lands, supported by such evidence as to their findings as they can obtain locally.

Director.

RE: ALERT BAY INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL RESERVE.

As instructed in your memorandum of February 3rd, the above Reserve, comprising 412 acres, was visited and examined. This area is well known to Mr. Todd, Indian Agent, and to Mr. A. C. C. Langstroth, Forest Ranger, Provincial Department of Lands and Forests. At a meeting today, in company with Mr. Todd and Mr. Langstroth, the valuation of this property was discussed.

It is our unanimous and considered opinion that the present day value of this property is $17,000.00, made up as follows:

| Acres       | Value per acre | Total Value |
|-------------|----------------|-------------|
| 40 acres    | $200.00        | $8,000.00   |
| 60 acres    | $2.50          | $150.00     |
| 112 acres   | $26.50         | $2,968.00   |
| 200 acres   | $29.00         | $5,800.00   |
| 412 acres   | Estimated      | $16,918.00  |

p.t.o.
Mr. Langstroth considered it undesirable to sign any statement to this effect without the authority of his Department. It was not deemed necessary that such authority be obtained.

Indian Agent Todd and myself confirmed the decision reached by Archdeacon Cook and myself on February 17th, 1948, in respect to that portion of Industrial School Reserve now occupied as a farm by the Residential School, which is to be retained and used for school purposes - this portion to be surveyed by a B.C.L.S. Immediate authority is therefore requested to have this survey made.

Mr. Allan and Mr. Brown are giving this matter high priority when the preliminary work is completed, which will enable them to prepare a request for sufficient money in the Supplementary Estimates to pay off the B.C. Indians. It is, therefore, imperative that we have the survey made and submitted to Ottawa at an early date to give them an opportunity to provide the funds in the Supplementary Estimates.

The whole program of development on this Reserve is being held in abeyance until such time as this matter is concluded.

(W. S. Arneil)
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Regarding the Clear Cedar items it is very hard to tell you what kind of shipment could be made until we have a firm specification of just what you would require.

Regarding the items of Yellow Cedar and Pine, we regret very much we are unable to quote you prices until we have a specification of the sizes which you require. There is very little of these two items available at present as all the mills are very busy cutting Fir for war orders. Consequently we hesitate to quote prices on these items until we know just what sizes are required.
If you can send us a detailed list of the sizes required to make up the 4M., feet we will be very glad to quote you by return mail.

Assuring you we appreciate receiving your value enquiries and orders which will at all times merit our very prompt attention, we are,

Yours very truly,

HARRY WELLS LUMBER LTD.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 25th instant with reference to manual training supplies for the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

From reports received it would appear that this school is well supplied with equipment and consequently I presume that all they require this year is material for vocational training work.

The Department will endeavour to be as generous as possible. We feel that good work is being done at this school but it is considered that the Principal should be able to give us some idea of the value of the material that he requires. It is not necessary to obtain detailed prices but a reasonably accurate estimate is all we need to enable us to decide what amount can be allowed this school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir,-

The enclosed copy of letter received from Principal Anfield of St. Michael's School will be self-explanatory.

The past two years the school has submitted a requisition for manual training supplies to this office complete with estimates from various firms, and on forwarding these to the Department authority has been given for the expenditure of a certain amount for this work. This has necessitated revision of the requisition and the obtaining of new estimates which has meant a great deal of work.

I would approve of Mr. Anfield's suggestion that the Department advise this office of the amount to be sanctioned for manual training supplies, so that requisitions may be prepared and forwarded not to exceed the allotted amount.

We would appreciate an early reply so that requisitions may be prepared at an early date.

Ottawa, August 21, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of August 11, enclosing requisition for manual training materials required for the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

On going through this requisition, it is noted that it includes an item of over 30 gallons of paint, valued at approximately $100.00, for manual training purposes. This appears to be quite a high amount. Is this paint used for repair work around the school or is it used only for manual training purposes?

The Department approves the purchase of the other items but would like to have more information in regard to the paint. On receipt of this information the balance of the requisition will be considered.

Yours truly,

September 8th, 1941

Sir:

Answering yours of the 4th regarding Manual Training Supplies requisitioned for the use of this School, this list has been carefully scrutinized and it is necessary to advise you that the following amount of paint therein would be used for repair work and maintenance work around the School:

| Quantity | Description       | Cost   |
|----------|------------------|--------|
| 10 Gals. | Green house paint| $30.43 |
| 2 gals   | Cream            | $6.08  |
| 1 gal.   | Grey             | $3.04  |
| 4 gals   | Turpentine       | $5.72  |
| 1 gal.   | Outside flat white| $3.89  |
| 1 gal.   | " black          | $3.05  |
| 1 gal.   | " green          | $3.04  |
| Total    | 20 gals.         | $54.65 |

These quantities and amounts may be deleted from the requisition as placed, should the Department be unable to meet the cost of the full requisition. It is difficult to know just where to draw the line between strictly Manual Training projects and maintenance and repair work around the School.

As you know we place a great deal of value on practical work for our boys and our program is based on a series of projects, many of them practical and of a permanent value to the School structure and equipment. For example we plan this year on considerable ornamental fencing around the Preventorium. It is true that this is maintenance of the School property, and yet itself very strictly a Manual Training project. Last year we rebuilt all the ornamental fences of the School and a new entrance, and some of the paint requisitioned was for the completion and painting of this work during the present school year.

It has always seemed to me of more value for the boys to be making useful practical things than spending their time making little models as is done in the Provincial Schools.

With the deletion of the paint quoted herewith, the balance of the requisition will be required for definite Manual Training purposes or initial projects therein.

Very truly yours,

FEA/M
Principal

I am forwarding herewith a letter of explanation from Mr. F. E. Anfield, Principal of St. Michael's Indian Residential School, dated September 8, and of Mr. Todd's covering letter, dated September 13 last, for the information of the Department.

The last paragraph of Departmental Letter 156-0-11 of August 21st, leaves me in some doubt as to whether authority has been given to me to proceed with the purchase of the balance of the requisition, 20 gallons of paint, as itemized in Mr. Anfield's letter of the 8th instant, needed for repair and maintenance, having now been deleted from the original requisition.

I should, therefore, appreciate receiving confirmation from the Department that the purchase of the other items is approved.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of February 26, 1942, I beg to enclose purchase order 2933 A issued in favour of Gordon & Belyea Limited, Vancouver, for the manual training supplies covered by Kwawkewlth Indian Agency voucher No. 321.

Experience would indicate that the most effective way to have Indian Agents observe requirements with respect to the submission of vouchers, where covering purchase orders have been issued by the Commissioner, is for the Department to return the voucher to the Agent with instructions to submit them to this office.

Agents have been repeatedly advised in this regard and I can only conclude that carelessness in preparing the mail is largely, if not entirely, responsible for failure to strictly adhere to the instructions issued.

Yours faithfully,

Ottawa,
February 17, 1943.

AIR MAIL

Mr. M.S. Todd, Indian Agent, Alert Bay, B.C.

On July 25 last the Department forwarded purchase order No. 13791 to Marshall-Wells B.C. Limited, Vancouver, for manual training equipment for the Alert Bay Residential School. As the accounts had not been received by the 1st instant we wrote to the Principal and he states that Marshall-Wells was finally instructed to cancel some items that seemed difficult to obtain and that the invoices for the materials that had been supplied were certified and sent to you on December 11 last. It would be appreciated if you would attach the accounts to proper voucher forms and forward them to this office at once in order that payment can be made from the current year's appropriation.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
FEB. 9, 1943.

Department Mines & Resources
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa Ontario

Dear Sir:

Re your 156-0-11 of February 1st, re account Marshall-Wells B. C. Ltd. Manual Training Equipment, purchase order #13791.

These goods were ordered as stated in your letter and most of them came forward in August and September. A considerable number of items were back ordered for various priority reasons, and the material and covering invoices kept trickling in, making it difficult to complete the requisition. Marshall-Wells was finally instructed to cancel outstanding items and the invoices were certified and sent to Mr. Indian Agent Todd, together with the purchase order Dec. 11th, 1942. It is regretted that this matter could not be concluded sooner, but conditions as previously stated made this impossible.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL
Ottawa,
February 1, 1943.

Dear Sir:

On July 25 last the Department forwarded purchase order No. [1379] to Marshall-Wells B.C. Limited, Vancouver, for manual training equipment for the Alert Bay Residential School. A copy of the purchase order was sent to Indian Commissioner Mackay on July 27 last and presumably he has forwarded it to you. No doubt the goods have been received, but you have not yet forwarded the account. It would be appreciated if you would forward the account covering the cost of the goods delivered as a result of this purchase order at the earliest possible date, in order that payment can be made from our current year's appropriation.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Todd:

Re Manual Training Lumber. Bids were called for from three firms, the Alberta Lumber Co., H. J. Wells, and Telegraph Cove Mills Ltd.

The Alberta Lumber Co. stated that they were unable to bid; H. J. Wells refused to bid on specified quantities, but were willing if we were able to get a priority order to try and round up 2 M. feet random lengths and sizes of lumber suitable for manual training, though could not give a price.

Telegraph Cove Mills has in stock a small amount of lumber mostly kiln dried, which was taken over by the Airforce. They are not particularly anxious to sell this lumber, but in view of our extreme difficulty in securing supplies they have consented to release it, and attached please find their tender for the amount $274.36

The amount specified would take care of two years normal manual training requirements, and in view of the fact it will undoubtedly be more difficult next year to obtain lumber than this, I would ask consideration of the Department to purchase the entire amount, which we will conserve to the limit. We will guarantee not to request any lumber for manual training purposes next year. We would be willing to buy half of this from School funds, but our operating costs are so tremendously high that it is impossible to consider this under present conditions.

If the Department is absolutely unable to purchase the full amount as two years' supplies, it is requested that they purchase 50% of the amount quoted upon for half the quoted price.

Thanking you,

Yours sincerely,

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Todd's letter of the 8th instant forwarding application from the Principal of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School for manual training material amounting to $274.36 of which Mr. Indian Agent Todd is prepared to recommend only half of the amount as the quantity applied for is intended to cover two years' requirements of the school.

I am inclined to agree with the Principal that in view of the considerable and increasing difficulty in securing manual training lumber that it would be advisable to purchase the supply available on the understanding that no request will be made for same next year. Whether this could be done would, of course, depend on funds being available and the matter is submitted to you on that basis.

I do not consider that manual training is being carried out on too large a scale at this school considering the pupilage. There is no doubt that Mr. Anfield's work at this institution has been highly successful and I do not agree with Mr. Todd's opinion that there should be any suspension of manual training but feel that the work should be extended rather than curtailed.

Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines & Resources,
Vancouver, B.C.

The enclosed requisition covering lumber for manual training requirements at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School as per the attached quotations submitted by Principal Anfield, is being forwarded for your attention. This requisition is in addition to that forwarded on June 11th last for hardware supplies for the manual training.

It is noted Principal Anfield is recommending the purchase of two years' supply on the chance that it may be impossible to purchase material next year, and the list covered by the quotation from Telegraph Cove Mills Limited is for that period. In this connection, I cannot agree, and can only recommend that fifty percent of the material quoted be supplied, which would serve the requirements for one year. In fact I feel when money is so difficult to obtain and needed so urgently for the war effort, that the Department could well dispense with manual training on a large scale for the duration.

Attached please find correspondence received from Rev. S. J. Wickens, Principal of St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, in which he is requesting the Department to increase the grant to the Manual Training Instructor.

It is also noted that Mr. Wickens suggests his salary be increased to $75.00 per month, plus his room and board.

Personally, I do not think this is enough. As this is one very important phase of our training I feel the Department should assume the full responsibility of the salary and I do not think that it is possible to obtain the services of a satisfactory Manual Training Instructor unless he receives a salary sufficient to attract him to the position.

In my opinion he should receive $100.00 a month, plus his room and board. We should have a highly trained instructor to fill this position, and unless we are prepared to pay a fair wage we will not be able to obtain a satisfactory instructor. I also believe the appointment of this Manual Training Instructor should be the responsibility of our School Inspector. In view of the above I wish to make the following recommendations:

(1) The Indian Affairs Branch establish a salary of $100.00 a month plus room and board for the Manual Training Instructor.

Dear Mr. Todd:

Inspector Davey in his report on our School was not satisfied with the work being done by our Manual Training Instructor and recommended that a change should be made. I, too, had previously decided that more efficient instruction of our boys in woodwork was highly desirable. The present occupant of this position was appointed during the war years when competent instructors were not available. He has done his best, but I grant that now it is not good enough.

However, if we are to attract a more competent man as Instructor, I think we should offer more than $60.00 per month. I am now looking for a man that will produce work more satisfactory to ourselves and the Inspector. I would strongly recommend that the grant be increased so that I may offer $75.00 per month to a qualified Instructor. We are all aware of the emphasis that the Department is rightfully placing on the training of our boys in carpentry, and, I think it is generally agreed that the salary should be more commensurate to the efficiency demanded.

I feel that when the adverse report on our Manual Training Department is studied by Ottawa, they will insist on a change being made, and I believe they will favourably consider an increase such as I have suggested.

Thanking you for past favours,

I am, Yours very truly,

S.J. Wickens,

MEMORANDUM

TO: Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C., June 30, 1947.

FROM: School Inspector.

re: Alert Bay Indian Residential School

Enclosed is correspondence from Mr. Indian Agent Todd and myself concerning the institution of a mechanical training course at the above-mentioned Residential School, along with an outline of proposed course of studies.

When I inspected the Alert Bay School I suggested to the Principal that a course of this nature would be most useful for the pupils of his School.

It is noted that the cost of the tools which would be required for this purpose would amount to approximately $325.00 and, in addition to this, a building will be necessary. The Principal of the School estimates that the cost of this building would be in the neighbourhood of $1200.00. The total cost then for instituting this program would be approximately $1600.00.

As the majority of the pupils at this School will enter either the fishing or lumbering industry, in which the operation of engines occupies an important place, I consider that this type of vocational work would be of great value to the pupils. I feel that the type of work as indicated in the course is what is required but there are no doubt some changes which should be made. In this connection I believe the Correspondence Branch of the Department of Education for the Province of British Columbia has courses along these lines and it might be possible to use them as a guide in developing this work.

The Alert Bay School already has gasoline engines in operating order which will be available for this work when the School connects up with the Power Commission electric lighting plant at Alert Bay so there would be no expenditure
for this. In addition to this the School also has an old Diesel engine which is not in use and upon which the boys could work.

In view of the anticipated visit to the Coast by Mr. Doucet in the fall, the Department might feel it advisable to leave this matter until he had had an opportunity to discuss this with me.

MARSHALL-WELLS CATALOGUE
1. Care and operation of tools

No excuse for the misuse of tools, which cause the majority of replacements. Use the right tool for the job.

(a) Bench Vice: Body is cast, joints are of hardened steel and replaceable. When not desiring to mark work soft joints are used. The size of the vice is the width of the joints. Top of the vice should be set at shoulder level for correct working level.

(b) Hammers: Proper grip, better balance, greater striking force, select proper weight, keep handles tight. Do not allow face to become chipped.

(c) Cold Chisels: Made of tool steel, cutting edges hardened. Keep edges sharp and ground to proper form, never let head become mushroomed as it may throw off steel chips dangerous to the eyes.

(d) Punches: Select proper punch for the job, keep centre punches properly sharpened to a point. Drift punch should be square across.

(e) Pliers: Kinds - Uses. They should never be hammered on, or used as a hammer. Should not be used on bolt heads, or as wrenches.

(f) Tin Snip: Should not be used for cutting wire, should receive special attention regarding care, and not allowed to rest on other tools.

(g) Screw Drivers: Use correct size and width for the job. Do not use as pry, hammer, or scraper. Keep properly sharpened, square across tip, faces parallel.

(h) Wrenches: Keep wrenches clean, make sure you have the proper size to fit, never increase leverage by using an extension or handle, do not use wrench for a hammer. Keep wrenches in tool kit or on board, do not leave on the bench where they may become damaged, keep free from grease, wipe after using. Do not use crescent wrenches if you have a box or open end to fit the nut. They are liable to slip and damage yourself as nut comes.

(i) Files: High carbon steel. Always use handle for safety and accuracy. Different types and cuts and their uses: Do not hammer or pry with files as they are brittle hard. Drawfiling.

(j) Hacksaws: Good frame, tighter blade, teeth facing front, correct number of teeth. Apply pressure on forward cut only. Be sure of pressure. Do not run fast. Sixty strokes per minute.

(k) Drills: Pressure, how to sharpen and cone for same, cooling oil etc.
2. Operation of tools (cont.)

(a) Soldering: Correct weight of copper. Copper should be hammered out not filed. Correct angle of iron is important, cleaning iron, tinning, correct heat to procure proper copulation of solder and work, cleaning work, use of acid and flux. Soldering heavy work with blow torch.

(b) Rivetting: such as used on patch repairs, spacing, heading, bucking, size of hole, cleaning hole, size of patch, length of rivet.

(c) Smithing: materials, bending, flanging, cutting, handmade stove pipes, oil drip trays, annealing copper pipe, flaring same, tool boxes, etc.

(d) How to file: correct method to hold file, what type of file to use, draw filing, cleaning file, precision fitting of two pieces by filing.

(e) Tempering: How to temper (harden) punches, drifts, etc. Correct hardening colours. How to soften tempered pieces for drilling and re-temper. Tempering fluids.

3. Principles of Internal Combustion Engine

(a) Naming parts of engine, work done by each part, i.e. piston travel, inlet, compression, combustion, exhaust, meaning of two cycle and four cycle engine, work of valves, cam. shaft, crankshaft, gear wheels, fit of parts. Spark plugs, magneto, fuel pumps, oil pumps, Diesel Engine nozzles and pumps. Water cooling, water pumps, lubrication. Firing order on multi-cylinder engines. Carburettor.

(b) Ignition, Timing, Carburation: The principle of the magneto, magnets, spark plugs, wiring, coils, brushes, impulse starter, correct timing and setting of engine (Diesel nozzles, fuel pump, injection timing, air intake.

(c) The principle of combustion: Types of carburettor, floats, jets, gas level, feed lines, correct amount of fuel, feed control, fuel oil and gasoline, flash points.

(d) Cooling methods and trouble shooting: water cooled, circulation, air cooled, fan, water scale, removal of same, chemicals for removal, importance of free circulation. Trouble shooting - locating fault, checking ignition, combustion, fuel, checking diesel fuel pump, nozzles, timing.

4. Repairing Methods - Fitting Bearings

(a) Fuel lines, shut off cocks, setting valves, grinding valves, replacing valve springs, piston rings, checking alignment. Fitting keys, testing bearings for play. Correct clearance.

(b) Pouring bearings: Heat of babbitt for pouring. Pre-heating parts, fitting bearings, stems, grinding and polishing same, detection of high spots, importance of accuracy. Set-up for running bearing, cutting oil grooves, tightening bearings.
4. Care and Maintenance:

(a) over haul, Gas and Diesel engines.

(b) dismantling, breakdown, observation, checking parts as dismantled, cleaning, fitting new parts, where to look for wear, scored cylinder walls, fitting piston rings, valves, taking up slack, reassembly by stages and checking while progressing.

(c) How to look after an engine: Advance warning of trouble. Setting up engine.

(d) Alignment: Scoring and wear - its causes and corrective measures.

(e) Importance of correct lubrication: Pressure and splash.

(f) Testing engine: Running in, etc.

MEMORANDUM

May 10, 1947
Vancouver, B.C.

to The Indian Commissioner for B.C.
from The Inspector of Indian Schools

Re: Application for Increased Grant,
Manual Training Instructor's Salary.

I refer to the application of Reverend S.J. Wickens for an increase in the grant toward the Manual Training Instructor's salary at the St. Michael's Residential School and the letter from Mr. Indian Agent loud in support of this application.

In my report on the Vocational training at the St. Michaels Residential School I indicated that the Vocational Training at this school is extremely weak. I also discussed this with the Principal and pointed out to him that there should be considerable improvement in this work. In order to do this the school will certainly have to pay more for a suitable Manual Training Instructor than the present amount of $60.00 per month. At the time of my inspection at the beginning of March there were 114 boys in residence which indicates that a full time instructor could be used for vocational training. I recommend that the grant be made on the basis of $55.00 per month for a part time instructor with some qualifications, or $100.00 per month for a full time Manual Training Instructor.

It is very doubtful if the school will be able to obtain an instructor who has both the practical and professional training, but if Mr. Wickens is fortunate enough to secure such a man an additional amount of $25.00 per month should be made if his professional standing warrants it.

Regarding the recommendation of Mr. Todd that the Manual Training Instructor be appointed by the departmental School Inspector, I should like to point out that
it is impossible for me to do my regular work of inspection and at the same time make contacts in view of filling vacancies in the Residential Schools, and I do not consider that the Department's policy with regard to this should be changed, at least until another inspector is appointed for this district. At present the Department reviews appointments to such positions and bases the salary grant on the qualifications of the instructor. It is my opinion that this is the only practical manner of handling the problem at the present time.

The Department is at the present time reviewing the grants for Manual Training Instructors' salaries in B.C. and is considering basing them along the lines recommended here.

R.F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools

May 26, 1948.

Dear Miss Kent:

I have for answer your letter of April 23 which was held awaiting my return from an inspection trip.

At the present time we have not gone into the Vocational Guidance field to any extent because of the widely varying conditions existing among our Canadian Indians.

We have been using freely the literature available from the various Provincial Departments of Education, in accordance with varying local conditions. Therefore it will be in order for you to advise, by requisition, if there are any pamphlets which you wish ordered from the Provincial Department of Education in Victoria.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Miss Marion G. Kent,
St. Michael's Preventorium,
Alert Bay, British Columbia.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,

When forwarding accounts accompanied by purchase orders, you should enter on the account "Pay from B.C. Special".

As we keep a list of the tools supplied to all manual training classes you might let me have a list for our records showing the tools that have recently been supplied to Alert Bay.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

PP/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

The Principal, Alert Bay Indian Residential School, has requested, and District School Inspector Davey has recommended the supply of various manual training tools and a quantity of manual training materials and in view of the difficulty in securing such items and the close proximity of the end of the current fiscal year I have placed orders as follows:

Reliance Lumber Co. - lumber for manual training class - $242.90.

Gordon & Belyea Co. Ltd. - manual training hand tools, one ½ H.P. electric motor and various small items and material - $366.96.

It is thought that there are ample funds available from the Vocational Training Division of the B.C. Special Vote and I trust that my action in placing these orders is approved.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Manual Training Instructor
Alert Bay Day School

I refer to Mr. Phelan's letter of January 4th concerning the appointment of Mr. H. Scanlon as Manual Training teacher at the Alert Bay Day and Residential Schools. In view of the Department's wish that the manual training departments at these two schools be combined it is recommended that an appointment be deferred until the beginning of the new academic year. The residential school is at present employing a manual training instructor and the appointment of a new man would lead to complications.

W.J. McEwen

Dear Colonel Neary:

In reviewing our revenue for 1948 we discovered that we had no record of receipt of payment from you for a Manual Training Instructor at Alert Bay, B.C. We therefore wrote the Principal asking him to look into the matter and have now received the following reply:

"I have today brought this matter to the attention of Mr. M. F. Todd, Indian Agent, who informs me that all vouchers have been sent forward covering the school year 1948. For your information, herewith particulars of vouchers:

Re: Manual Training Instructor
St. Michael's Residential School

The Reverend Principal of the above-mentioned School has requested an increase in his grant towards the Manual Training Instructor's salary. He has had his instructor complete the attached application form.

Re: Home Economics Supplies
Alert Bay Residential School

Attached is a requisition for Home Economics supplies from the above mentioned school. It will be noted that the principal has requested two sewing machines. In this connection Inspector Davey, who recently visited the school reports that the school has three machines, two of which are in very poor condition and the number is insufficient for the number of pupils taking sewing classes. The two machines in poor condition can be overhauled and will be suitable for rough work but an additional two should be supplied.

Also included in the requisition is a request for an electric iron. Many of the reservations along the Coast from which the pupils are admitted have electricity and it is considered that this item should be supplied to this school.

It will be noted that the other items are for instructional purposes and not school clothing.

It is considered that the expenditure required for all of these items is a legitimate charge against the B.C. Special Vote and it is recommended that authorization be given for their purchase.

W.S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Scott:

In answer to your letter of June 8th, regarding the purchase of a good working horse for the Alert Bay Industrial School, I have just had a consultation with Mr. Lord, the Principal of the school, and he is writing to a reputable firm in Vancouver to find out what a suitable horse would cost. I have made requisition to be allowed to take the launch to Vancouver for repairs and expect to be there about the 7th or 8th of July and will be able to select a suitable horse for the work. Judging from prices advertised in the papers a horse of the weight and quality suitable for their work would cost in the neighborhood of $250, to which would be added freight possibly $10 or $12. I would recommend that I be given authority to make this purchase while in Vancouver but there would not be time for an answer to be received at this office by mail and I would respectfully suggest that this authority be sent by wire.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I am enclosing a letter from the Principal of the Alert Bay Industrial School making application for a grant to purchase a horse to do the work on the farm attached to the school.

I would beg to report favorably on this application. Heretofore there has not been nearly enough attention given to clearing land and keeping it under proper cultivation. Mr. Todd, the Trade Instructor of the School, is a practical farmer and has been doing good work in this capacity since he has been taking care of the work at the Industrial School. Strictly speaking the school should have 20 or 40 acres of land under cultivation but the land is heavy to clear and with so many other things to attend to in the way of work progress in this line has been very slow. When the committee of the Missionary Society of the Church in Canada were at Alert Bay I took the matter up with them and recommended that they should have more land cleared so as to enable the school to be more self-supporting besides giving better instruction to the boys and they intended to take this up with the parent committee at Toronto. Venerable Arch Deacon Snowden of Ottawa was one of the committee who visited at Alert Bay.

I think if a good big sensible horse was provided for the use of the school it would be a matter of great assistance to them.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

I have the honour to request that you will give your best consideration to this, my application for a grant to purchase a horse, to do the work on the farm attached to this school.

We have found it necessary to put away the only horse we had, on account of old age, and he has been really unfit for work for some time. He has been used continually by the school for twelve years, and was about 25 years old.

Owing to the development of the farm in late years, we need a good animal, weighing about 1500 lbs to handle the work, or I would suggest the purchase of a mare in foal, with a view to raising the colt for work in the future.

The service of a horse is absolutely necessary to work the farm, and we should be severely handicapped without one in cultivating and harvesting our crop this year.

With further reference to your letter of June 8th, and to my letter of June 24th with regard to the purchase of a horse for the Alert Bay Industrial School, I beg to advise you that I have not yet received any answer to my communication of the 24th.

While I was in Vancouver, during the second week in July, I made a special point of visiting the sales stables of J. Hanbury & Co., to look over their horses and have an idea as to prices, etc., but as I had not received any authority to make the purchase I did not do so. I found that I could obtain horses from $250 to $300 each. I picked one out at $200, which I considered to be the best buy of any horses he had for sale. The horse was rising seven and was a splendid animal in every particular but was too slow for their work at teaming in the city which would be a valuable asset to the horse for the purpose for which he is intended. I was shown another good horse about 100 lbs. lighter at $250, guaranteed perfectly sound but had a blemish on each leg in the shape of a wind gall. From my own experience while farming in British Columbia the wind gall does not interfere at any time with the working qualities of the horse but seriously interferes with him from a sales point of view. The great difficulty in getting a horse for the work here is in getting one that will stand working without wearing shoes as most horses of that weight are used to wearing coiled shoes. In order that the horse may go bare footed he requires to have good hoofs and the first horse mentioned had exceptionally good feet. I am awaiting your instructions with regard to purchasing a horse and Mr. Lord, the principal, is anxious that the purchase should be made as soon as possible, as they have their hay stacked outside waiting for the horse to draw it to the barn.

In each of the above instances the price of the horse included a well fitting collar.

Your Obedient Servant,

OTTAWA, August 2nd, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo with reference to the purchase of a horse for the Alert Bay Industrial School.

In reply, I beg to say that your letter of the 24th of June was received, and a reply was sent you by telegram on the 5th ultimo, as follows:

"May purchase suitable horse at reasonable cost for Alert Bay Industrial School. Animal should be examined by veterinary surgeon and certificate obtained. Forward vouchers for payment."

This message was sent you as you stated in your letter of the above date that you were leaving for Vancouver, and it was hoped that it would reach you before you left Alert Bay.

You may, therefore, make the necessary arrangements to carry out the instructions contained in the above quoted telegram, and arrange for the purchase of a suitable horse for this school. While a serviceable horse for the purposes required should be secured, it is expected that such will be obtained as cheaply as possible. You should forward properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, for payment after you have arranged for the purchase of a horse which has been approved by a veterinary, as sound, and you should attach his certificate to that effect to the vouchers which you forward for payment.

I may say that it is regretted that the telegram above referred to did not reach you before you left Alert Bay on your recent visit to Vancouver.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

I talked with the Principal about his milch cows. They are a poor bunch. They do not come of a milking strain. I advised him to gradually get rid of what he has and put in their place two good cows. OTTAWA, March 8th, 1922.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in a report on his inspection of the Alert Bay Industrial and Girls' boarding school in February, last, states that the milch cows kept give a very small supply of milk, and that he has advised the Principal to get rid of them and obtain a better grade of cows.

He also draws attention to the quantity of milk used at the girls' school. He states that in January, last, only 45 gallons of milk were produced, 7 of which were sold, also that 10 pounds of butter were made, 5 of which were sold.

This is quite an inadequate supply of milk for the use of the pupils. Milk should form one of the main items of diet, especially for the younger children, and you should take up with the Principal the matter of obtaining a sufficient number of good milch cows to supply the pupils with an adequate supply of milk each day.

Owing to the small quantity of milk at present produced, it should be used for the benefit of the pupils, and none should be sold. This also applies to the butter made.

I will be pleased if you will consult the Principal regarding the obtaining of more milch cows, and inform the Department as to what he proposes to do in this matter, as milk should be served to the pupils, especially the younger ones, at each meal.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of July 25th dealing with recommendations from Rev. Dr. Westgate, Field Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, I beg to advise you that within a radius of some 70 or 80 miles from Alert Bay there is only one farmer who has a herd of grade Holstein cattle and that is my brother, Mr. E. A. Halliday of Kingcome Inlet. Mr. Lawrence Landsdowne of Kingcome Inlet has a few grade Holsteins but none for sale. After receipt of your letter I had an opportunity to go to Kingcome Inlet before making any decision about the purchase of these cows and as it happens to be my brother with whom I was dealing, I wish to bring the matter to the attention of the Department before making any final arrangements as there might be a suggestion that I was using my position as Indian Agent to negotiate sales for a member of my family.

He has a herd of 26 milch cows and is in a dairy business in fact he makes his living entirely from the sale of butter and beef. There is no veterinary nearer than Vancouver but in order to ensure that his herd is free from disease every other year he applies to the Provincial Government Veterinary Surgeon and has him examine the whole herd. The last examination was made on August 4, 1931 by W. W. Alton, Veterinary Inspector for the Province of British Columbia and during this inspection he administered the tuberculosis test to all the cattle and found them free from disease. I have in my possession this report which deals with the two cows which I have selected for purchase subject to the approval of the Department.

My brother has now purchased his 5th pedigree Holstein bull, the last three having been bought from the Provincial Government Colony Farm and their cows have made a record for milk and butter test for the whole of Canada. The difficulty in the way is the transportation and I have told him that the Department should not consider any other terms than that they be delivered at the school at Alert Bay. It will cost him $100.00 to deliver the two animals as he will have to charter a gasoline tug and now to bring them over but he will guarantee delivery for $100.00 for each animal. I may say that Mr. Landsdowne his near neighbor has just bought a grade Holstein cow in Vancouver and it cost him landed at Kingcome Inlet $125.00 and in my estimation it is not as good an animal as either of the two I selected. One of these gives a butter test of 4.1 and the other 4.3 % butter fat and while not particularly heavy milkers are long seasoned cows. One of them is 4 years old and the other one 6 and both are due to calve early in the year, the calves being from his latest imported Holstein bull from the Government farm.

If this is not suitable to the Department it may be necessary for me to take a trip to Vancouver and see what can be done in the way of purchasing as there are no good milch cows of any kind to be obtained in the near vicinity.
With regard to the second paragraph of your recommendation regarding beds I took the matter up with Mr. Lord, principal of the school, and personally went through the dormitory and examined every bed and I would recommend that 25 complete beds with springs size 2 ft. 6 X 6 purchased and four springs 7 ft. X 6 and 5 springs 6 ft. 6 X 6 be purchased to complete some of the other beds of the Dominion link fabric type as are in use at the present time and I would further recommend that 40 mattresses be obtained size 3 ft. 6 X 6. In looking over the beds I found that the best service had been given by the mattress known as the "people's favorite" made in Waterville, Quebec, by George Galt. These have been in use for a number of years and it is possible that the firm is no longer in operation but they have stood the test well and after all these years many of them are in a fair state of preservation.

With regard to a request that the school cottage for which a grant of $150.00 was recently made for repairs and which is being used as a residence for the principal, I had to advise you that Mr. Lord has already had the cottage moved and paid $150.00 on a contract for having it moved and set up in its new place. With regard to this cottage I may say that Mr. Lord approached me on the matter of a grant towards the moving of it but I explained to him that the department had just completed repairing and refitting the house at an expense of $250.00 and that I was making the application for these repairs that there had been no thought or suggestion that the building be moved. I pointed out to him that to a certain extent it meant a waste of a portion of the funds as all the under pinnings would have to be taken away and replaced and repainted and I thought if he did not know what he wanted any better than that that there was no particular reason for moving the house.

With regard to the paragraph in your letter stating that the house was situated right in the seepage of the bog in which lies behind the ridge on which the schools are built I beg to say that this is not correct. The cottage as it was was in a very good situation and is just as healthy a place as it is at the present time. I was rather opposed to the moving of the building on the ground that I intended to ask for an entirely new school for the Industrial School and that consequently quarters for the principal would be arranged for at that time. Under the circumstances however as the cottage has already been moved at a contract price of $150.00 I would recommend that this amount be repaid to Dr. Westgate who made the necessary advance to Mr. Lord to have the work done.

Your Obedient Servant,

OTTAWA, January 22nd, 1923.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in a report on his inspection of the Alert Bay Industrial School, dated the 11th of December last, has again drawn the attention of the Department to the inadequate supply of milk furnished for the use of the pupils. He states that during the week of his visit butter was being made at the expense of the supply of milk furnished for the pupils. He states that he discussed the food value of whole milk, and urged the Principal not to make any butter while there was such a small quantity of milk.

Last summer authority was given for the purchase of two Holstein grade cows for the use of this school, in order to provide an ample supply of milk for the daily requirements of the pupils. The Principal should realize the value of whole milk as an item of diet especially for the younger children.

I have to request that you will draw this matter to the attention of the Principal, and inform him that the Department requires that the pupils, especially the growing children, will receive an ample supply of milk at their meals, daily.

I shall be pleased to hear from you after you have had an opportunity of discussing the matter with the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.
DAIRY:

2½ lbs. of butter were made this week, but this was done at the expense of the pupils, who received no whole milk during the week. I discussed very thoroughly the food value of the whole milk and urged the principal of this school not to make any butter while he had such a small quantity of milk. Most of the Principals of our residential schools do not realize the value of whole milk for growing children and I am placing great emphasis on this subject, in my conference with these men.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of May 15th regarding a report and recommendation in connection with the purchase of a new bull for the Alert Bay Indian Residential Schools I am sorry that the report has been so long in being forwarded but it was difficult for some time to get in touch with anyone who had animals of this nature for sale.

I wrote to the Colony Farm at Esquimalt, to the Agricultural Branch of the University of British Columbia and to the Dominion Experimental Farm and also looked at one or two bulls in this vicinity. I also wrote to Mr. brother, Mr. R. M. Macdonald who is one of the leading dairyman in Comox Valley. In reply to these letters the Provincial Master Breeder is willing to provide a young bull "Colonel Arctic Champion" born February 3rd, 1926. They state that he is an excellent calf, big and bright and from good producing and high buttering stock. His two nearest dams average 2,487 pounds of butter per year. Price subject to prior sale $150.00 F.O.B. Vancouver.

The Dominion Experimental Farm at Agassiz has a very fine young bull calf born January 10th, 1926, which they are planning to show at the Vancouver Exhibition and also at the New Westminster Exhibition. His sire is the son of Agassiz's Begle Bay Echo, the world's champion cow that produced 20,366 pounds of milk and 1,061 pounds of butter in a year. The dam of the calf produced 19,960 pounds of milk and 760 pounds of butter in a year. The price on this calf is $200.00 subject to being unheld when they hear again from this office.

They also refer me to Mr. C. A. Milliner, 2900 Marine Drive, Vancouver, who has a young bull of the same breeding as the one above mentioned. He is by the same sire and his dam as a two year old produced 16,522 pounds of milk and 708 pounds of butter and her dam in turn produced 19,925 pounds of milk and 974 pounds of butter in a year. She has three registered sisters that produced over 20,000 pounds of milk in a year. The Superintendent writes that while he has never seen this bull he thinks it could be purchased from $150.00 to $200.00. These animals are all three Holsteins.

My brother took up the matter in the Comox Valley with Mr. R. H. Harford who handles Jerseys. He says that he has a fine yearling pure bred Jersey to be two years old this Fall. This bull is from Brampton Mariposa, of Grinnell Bros., Tender Island, whose record is 666 pounds of butter fat as a four year
is very creditable. Brampton Mariposa is a regular producer and Grinnell Bros. figure her the best cow they ever owned. The bull is very nice to handle and was shown at the Fair in Vancouver, and Courtenay was the Junior Champion Bull. He says that he is of good size and that his hide is exceptionally good and hardier than near perfection as one would wish. He is guaranteed free from disease and also as a sure breeder. Price registered in either my name or the principal of the School f.o.s., Campbell River $125.00. Mr. Hurford states that the bull is worth easily twice the money but he has three which is too many for his stock but wishes to be allowed the right to purchase the animal back again at the same price at the end of three years. He states that he may not be obliged to do this but wishes to have the option if he wishes. My brother writes me that he was local examiner of the live stock at the Courtenay Fair and says that this is a very fine animal and that Mr. Hurford is a man absolutely to be relied on.

In summing up and taking all things into consideration I would recommend the purchase of the Jersey on account of the better grade of milk produced by Jerseys over Ayrshires or Holsteins. The bulls are inclined to be a little savage at times but that might said of a bull of any kind. The females at the school do not run very high in butter fat and I think that a Jersey bull would be the best means of improving the stock and getting a better grade of milk. Any of these animals are subject to prior sale so would you kindly advise me as soon as possible what to do and if in the meantime the Ayrshire bull which I went personally to see at Malcolm Island becomes available I will take this up before making the final purchase.

Your Obedient Servant,

W. H. Halliday
Indian Agent.

Sir:-

Dairy & Farm Stock - Proposed New School,
Alert Bay, B.C.

I have the honour to place before you for your consideration the necessity of providing the proposed new school at Alert Bay with sufficient dairy and farm stock to make possible reasonably economical operation of this plant.

At present we have the following stock:

(a) Five milk cows; two of which I believe are suffering from contagious abortion and which I think will be slaughtered at the next visit of the veterinary inspector.

(b) Six calves of scrub variety, ranging from a few months to heifer age.

(c) Two hogs, both of which will be butchered inside of a month.

(d) A very nondescript and ancient flock of hens.

Dr. Frank, the veterinary inspector for the Federal Department of Agriculture, strongly recommended on his last visit that the new school adopt the policy of having a pure bred herd, Jersey type by preference. He chose this particular breed on account of the availability of animals in the Comox district and also on account of the fact that the Jersey is a reasonably small eater, which factor would be of great importance at Alert Bay where practically all feed and hay is shipped in.

I estimate that we will require at least ten milking cows to handle the pupilage at the new school and it will also be necessary that accommodation should be provided for this herd. The inspector's report forwarded to you some time ago by our Dr. Westgate will give you information regarding the present barns and dairy equipment.
It will be necessary also to provide both stock and accommodation for hogs and chickens, both for meat and egg-laying purposes, as well as to provide instruction for the pupils in these subjects.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Dr. Scott,

Mr. Pidcock of Alert Bay has a small herd of dairy cows, all T.B. tested but has trouble getting a suitable bull. The Indian school there has a good one but it is said they are under some "supervised herd" scheme which forbids using the bull outside their own herd. If Mr. Pidcock's herd is really all T.B. tested it would seem quite safe to let him use the school bull.

It would of course be with the consent of the school principal but while Mr. Pidcock did not say so in so many words, I gathered from his letter that the objection did not come from the principal but from the "supervised herd" regulations. Subject to the principal's approval and to the cows being T.B. tested, could the regulations not be relaxed enough to let this man be encouraged in starting a dairy herd in this remote place?

Yours faithfully,

A.W. Neill

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant in which you state that Dr. Westgate, of the Missionary Society of Canada, urges the Department to provide a caterpillar tractor for the use of the Alert Bay Indian School.

In reply I beg to say that this subject was discussed between Principal Anfield and myself, when I visited Alert Bay on the 17th of July, and as a result of our conference on this subject, I am perfectly in accord with the suggestion. This is in view of the fact that the area on which feed can be grown for stock on the Alert Bay Industrial School Reserve is very limited, and what can be grown will be needed for the cattle. Even at that it is estimated that a certain amount of hay will have to be purchased from the Fraser Valley during certain seasons of the year. The tractor can do everything that a team of horses would be needed for, and it would cost less for gasoline for the tractor than for hay for the horses.

Dear Sir:

I have received from Mr. Anfield, the Acting-Principal of our Society's School at Alert Bay, a very strong recommendation that the new school be supplied with a "Caterpillar" tractor to assist the school management in doing the following work:
(1) For hauling out logs which have been felled during the process of clearing the land, to be cut up into firewood. These logs are so large that horses could not handle them, and it will be practically impossible to cut them up into wood where they lie.
(2) To complete the clearing of the land already under cultivation.
(3) To help in the levelling up of the ground, a work which will involve an immense amount of grading.
(4) The hauling of supplies, etc., which will be used in the new building.

The need of this tractor appears to me to be fully as great and even greater than the need which existed at our Sioux Lookout School, and I am quite convinced that at neither institution would it be possible to bring such heavily timbered land into a satisfactory state of cultivation without it. At the same time I am also very strongly of the opinion that the items of work mentioned under sections (1), (2), and (3) should not be left entirely to the school management, but should be undertaken by your Department and without expense to our Society. The "Caterpillar" tractor recommended by Mr. Anfield would be of incalculable service in this connection, and might be used by the men engaged by your Department to do this work, and then handed over to the School as part of their equipment.
A still further reason why a tractor should be supplied to this institution is to be found in the necessity which exists for giving the Indian boys a working knowledge of an instrument of this kind. Comparatively little use will ever be made of horses along the B.C. coast and instruction in the handling of instruments of this kind should be a great help to the Indian boys in earning a livelihood after they have left the School.

Mr. Anfield took this matter up with Mr. Indian Commissioner Ditchburn during his recent visit to Alert Bay, and he states that the Commissioner was firmly of the opinion that a tractor should be secured, and the horses disposed of by sale.

He also secured information about tractors from the Morrison Tractor and Equipment Co., Ltd., Vancouver, and I enclose herewith the original of their letter addressed to him on March 27th last, and with it an illustration of the two ton "Caterpillar" tractor, equipped with Stationary Drive Pulley which he recommends should be supplied.

I commend this important matter to your prompt and sympathetic consideration, and have the honour to remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to advise you that Dr. Westgate of the Missionary Society of the Church of Canada has been visiting at Alert Bay, and with him I have gone carefully over the source of supplies, etc., for St. Michael's Residential School. The school has, as you are aware, almost doubled in the number of pupils who are attending, and this will be augmented by another thirty or forty. There is a great shortage of milk at the school, and up to the present time there has been a shortage of pasture. The shortage of pasture will continue, I may say, for another year, until the new clearing gets into a condition to produce, but in the meantime the shortage of milk is acute.

I understand that Dr. Frank, the Dominion Government Veterinarian, has recommended Red-polled cattle, and if communication was got through him, I would recommend that two milk cows be obtained by the Department to get the school well started. I don't know what the price would be, but that could be obtained from him.

Regarding the horses which they have, I understand from Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn that the idea of getting the tractor was to do away with the horses, as pasture is very limited and feed very dear, but at the present time no purchaser has been available. I will be using one horse for some little time in the land clearing operations which I am carrying on for the benefit of this school, but this will be completed, weather permitting, by about the first of March, and I think that steps should be taken to sell these horses. If they do, it will be necessary to purchase some kind of a cultivator that will work by power. I believe there is one on the market the cost of which is about $160.00, run by a two-horse motor, and which is equipped and sent out from Vancouver by Easthope Bros.. I recommend these things to your serious consideration.

Your obedient servant,
