Sir:

At the Alert Bay Residential School there are a number of small trees which are too small to use with the "Wee McGregor" power saw, and in the additional clearing of land for the School a lot of it will want to be cut up for firewood. The tractor which was supplied by the Department has a driving pulley, and I would recommend that the Department purchase for the school a frame and a circular saw for cutting up this small stuff for use in the kitchen range and also in the boiler department.

I have got prices and I find that a 30" saw, suitable for the work can be got for $10.60, and a frame which would be useful for either long or short stuff can be supplied for $64.00 F.O.B. warehouse Vancouver, and I would recommend that this be granted, the school to supply its own belts and anything else that would be needed excepting the machine and saw.

I also beg to direct your attention to the urgent need of a motor truck. As the school has no private wharf and all supplies, coal, etc., have to be transported from the cannery wharf about ¼ of a mile distant, the need of this item of equipment is obvious. When the main school building was under construction your Department kindly provided a grant of $200.00 to buy a second hand truck. This truck rendered sufficient service to justify its purchase. When it became useless another used truck was purchased by the Principal, but this is now practically worn out, and must soon be replaced. At one time the Principal felt that a boat would be necessary, but if the road to the cannery wharf is completed, or the saw-mill wharf is repaired and made available for the school's use, the cost of the boat may be saved. A good Ford truck can be delivered at Alert Bay for $900.00 and I beg to strongly recommend that this expenditure be authorized at the earliest date possible.

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Residential School, asking that the School be allowed a separator, so that during the vacation time they would be able to make butter from the milk given by the cows. The intention of the School is only to keep enough cows to supply the school while it is in session, but as during the holidays a large number of the pupils would be away, it would leave them with an overplus.

I do not happen to have any catalogue of prices, and it is some considerable time since I personally had anything to do with these machines, but I submit it to the Department for their consideration.

Alert Bay, B.C.,
April 24, 1931.

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Indian Residential School asking that the Department give a further grant towards getting two Guernsey cows for that institution.

I may say that the Principal has just completed the purchase of four new cows from Kingcome Inlet, but Inspector Barry during his recent visit to Alert Bay considered that even these would not provide sufficient milk for the needs of the School. I understand that you will hear from the Inspector himself on this matter.

Regarding the bull, the one that they have I am sorry to say, was badly neglected after it was first bought, and does not show itself to be as well bred an animal as the pedigree shows, but they have had it now for six years and it is time they had a change, and I would recommend that authority be given me to dispose of the present one and purchase a new one for the use of the School. They would prefer, however, a Guernsey this time instead of a Jersey.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)

Ottawa, May 5, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, relative to the request of the Principal of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School to be supplied with two Guernsey cows and to dispose of the bull and purchase a new one.

In reply I have to say it is expected that all replacements of stock will be made by the school management from per capita earnings or other receipts. Further, it is expected that the herd strength will be kept up to a standard to supply sufficient milk for the use of the school. As milk is an important item in the diet of the pupils, provision should be made for an ample supply.

I have also your letter of the same date regarding the request of the Principal to be supplied with a separator. As our funds this year are extremely limited, the school authorities will have to provide this equipment from per capita earnings or other receipts.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. H. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF SCHOOL INSPECTOR BARRY, DATED APRIL 13 & 14, 1931, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE ALERT BAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL. - Original on File 156-0-6.

Live Stock:

There are 2 horses, 2 fairly good Guernsey cows (6 and 5 years). The remainder of the cows are in my opinion scrubs and quite useless. They are 3 Holstein cows (8, 8 and 6 years old), 3 poor grade cows not milking. There is a Guernsey calf (4 months). The school has a Jersey bull, 5 years old. This bull ought to be exchanged. Two cows have died suddenly in the last three months. There are 30 old hens and 3 ducks.

When I was at the school only four cows were milking. This gave about 16 gallons per day, which was not enough to supply the kitchen. Milk by the case is bought from Vancouver as required. The children, except in the few cases mentioned above, were not having any milk to drink.

I explained to the Principal that I did not like this state of things, as the children of the coast were, as he knew, subject to T.B. The result of this little talk was that the Principal immediately went to Kingcome Inlet and bought four new cows. This will increase the milk yield by 10 gallons per day, and will allow for a cup of milk daily for Junior and Intermediate children.
Ottawa, July 4, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, relative to the request of the Principal of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School to be supplied with a cream separator.

In this connection I have to say it is considered that the milk supplied for the pupils' use at this school is really not adequate, and the Department believes that all the milk obtained should be served whole to the children. I would point out that milk is a most important item of the children's diet and they should be given an adequate supply. The Department does not consider it necessary at the present time to supply a separator.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. W. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.
Sir:

The Principal of the School has again written me on the matter of the purchase of a cream separator which was refused by the Department in a previous communication.

He states that the Commission wish attention to be drawn to the fact that they have, from the per capita grant, purchased four cows recently for the School, and are meeting all the expense in the necessary alterations and repairs to the present building and the old Girls' Home during the present summer months, and they stress the fact that they cannot afford to purchase the separator from the per capita funds.

I leave this matter for the consideration of the Department, but I wish to draw attention to the fact that when the School is in session and all the children are present, there is not very much chance to separate very much milk, as it would all be used, and the separator would be used principally during the vacation times as the cows are milking then and without a separator, it is difficult to do much with it.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Residential School at Alert Bay asking that the Department supply the school with a leveller. For an Eversman Junior Automatic Leveller, weight 950 pounds, the price F.O.B. at Alert Bay would be $255.00. This machine is very highly recommended, and as the school is in need of considerable assistance in preparing a proper playground for the children, I would recommend that the Department make this purchase.

It can be obtained from the Morrison Tractor & Equipment Company, 940 Station Street, Vancouver, and as we have had dealings with this firm I know that they are absolutely reliable.

There is considerable work being done all the time in grading and levelling the grounds, but without a proper leveller it entails a great deal of unnecessary labor, and it is the aim of the Principal to make the school grounds a beauty spot, not only for the benefit of the children but also as a sign that the Indian Department is wide-awake to their opportunities as guardians of the Indian children.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)

15th June, 1938

The Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.

Dear Mr. Todd:

Will you please lay before the Department the need of another bull for the School farm.

The present animal has been in use for over six years, and we are having considerable trouble with our breeding. A new animal should be provided for this fall for sure, and should not be less than a year old. We would like to continue with a pure bred Guernsey, and would suggest that the Inspector of the Health of Animals Branch, Federal Block, Vancouver, be asked to make the purchase as the animal would have to be tested for T.B. by them before shipment in any case.

It is important that an animal from a good milk strain be secured. The farm manager is of the opinion that the present animal is not worth transferring to another school.

Thanking you for your interest in this matter.

Sincerely yours,

"F.E. Anfield"
Principal.

Dear Sir:

The Principal of St. Michael's Residential School has drawn attention to the need of a new bull for the School farm at Alert Bay.

An item of $100.00 was included in the 1938-39 estimates submitted by Mr. Indian Agent Todd for this purpose. It will be recalled however, that Mr. Todd's estimates were late in reaching the Department, and it is just possible that provision was not made for this expenditure.

Inquiries have been made as to the Guernsey stock available in the Fraser Valley, and as a result of replies received, Mr. Indian Agricultural Agent Caldwell visited two farms to look over the animals for sale. There are only two Guernsey bulls available at present, and of these the eleven months old bull at Mr. Ross Peers' farm, Sardis, B.C. is considered the most suitable, and should funds be available I would recommend the purchase of this animal. The price of this bull is $120.00 f.o.b. farm, and the approximate cost of transportation from Sardis to Alert Bay is $25.00. Should the Department approve of the application, no doubt examination by the Inspector of the Health of Animals Branch will be arranged for, before purchase is made.

A copy of Principal Anfield's letter together with copy of a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Todd is forwarded herewith.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith an application received from Principal Anfield, of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, through the office of the Indian Agent, for a Holstein bull to replace the purebred Guernsey bull purchased by the Department in 1938. This animal died a few weeks ago from an undetermined cause.

Although this office recommended the purchase of the Guernsey bull supplied in 1938, I was not aware at the time that it was not the policy to extend such assistance to Indian Residential School farms. In this particular case, the stock is raised at Alert Bay to provide milk, beef and milk products for the children and staff. Instruction in stock raising and agricultural pursuits is not given to any extent at the School, as the Indian children are mostly from Reserves where the Indians are engaged in the fishing and lumbering industries.

Unless it is the established policy of the Department to assist in the maintenance of cattle at Residential Schools where stock is raised to provide food for the School, it is considered the school should be required to provide a suitable animal from school funds.

The cost of a well-bred Holstein bull calf would be approximately $150.00.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir,

The enclosed copy of correspondence has been received from Principal Anfield in respect to three ex-pupils of St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, and will be self-explanatory.

For the Department's information, I am well acquainted with the three pupils referred to, and in my opinion they are deserving of assistance from the Department. The girls are outstanding pupils, have nice personalities, and I believe will make good and be a credit to themselves and to the Department. I have interviewed both these girls, and they inform me they are determined to go through with their studies if given this assistance.

As the arrangement made by Principal Anfield is acceptable to the Provincial School Inspector and the Board of School Trustees of the Alert Bay Superior School, and according to Mr. Anfield's letter will receive the endorsement of Inspector Barry, I would strongly recommend that a grant of $150.00 be made to cover the fees necessary for these three pupils to attend the Superior School at Alert Bay during the next academic year.

As it is necessary to have an answer to this letter by September 1st, I would appreciate if you would kindly give the matter your early attention, and if necessary, communicate with the Department by Air Mail. I am forwarding copy of this letter direct to the Department so that they may take the matter under consideration in advance of your recommendation.

Your obedient servant,

(M.S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Todd;—

At the close of last term, five pupils from this School were promoted by the Provincial and Federal School Inspectors to Grade IX. Three of these pupils, Flora Eleanor Hamner, #336, age 16 years; Beatrice Rose Edwards, #271, age 15 years; and Charlie Jefferson Brown, #400, age 16 years, have applied to continue their studies in Grade IX. All three have proved admirable pupils, of good character, and have a definite purpose in wishing to take further studies. The two girls both wish to train as nurses eventually and Charlie will be taking charge of a large general store when he gets older.

In conversation with Inspector Barry and also with the Provincial Inspector, Mr. J.Z. Manning, I suggested the advisability of allowing these pupils to attend the Alert Bay Superior School, in order to give them contact with white children in their Grade IX course. I am convinced that if Indian children taking advanced courses are to succeed, they must take these courses in the environment of white schools. In this both Inspectors heartily agreed; Inspector Manning being quite agreeable to the pupils attending the local Superior School, and Inspector Barry stating that he was prepared to endorse a recommendation that the Dept. make a grant to meet the necessary fees. I am now in receipt of a letter from the local School Board approving the admission of these three pupils on a fee paying basis! The three pupils are ready to go ahead with the course, and I now have the honour to ask that you will place before the Department a request for a grant of $150.00 to meet the fees for these three pupils for the academic year starting next Sept. 5th. The children would of course be in residence at this school, and would take their domestic science and man. training courses with us.

Thanking you for your favourable consideration of this request, Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal.
Alert Bay, B.C.

Dear Sir:

Application is made herewith for permission to return the following pupils to the School for a further period of one year, and for a grant of $250.00 to enable them to take Grades IX and X in the local Superior School:

Pupil # 0271 Beatrice Rose Edwards, Massett Band, born 11/4/24
# 0356 Flora Eleanor Hanuse Masmalilikwa, born 8/1/23
# 050 Charles Jefferson Brown, Bella Bella, born 4/3/23
# 257 William McKay, Greenville Band, born 21/9/21
# 093 Leonard D. Leighton, McIlkathla Band, born 4/3/22

The first three of the pupils listed above were passed with the approval of the Provincial Inspector to Grade X, and the latter two were passed by Inspector Barry of the Indian Affairs Department Branch and also by the Provincial Inspector, Mr. J. Z. Manning, into Grade IX.

From the attached papers, you will see that practically all these young people are anxious and willing to pay some part of their tuition costs, should the present season enable them so to do. I would therefore ask them to first of all pay for their text books, which last year cost the School over $30.00, and if they were able to do more, they might be able to pay back part of the grant requested to cover their tuition fees.

All five applicants have good health records, and have a clear T.B. record from the Travelling Clinic that surveyed the School twice last year. Their record of conduct has also been good, and I believe that they are all seriously interested in making a success of their educational opportunities.

Should the special grant be made, it would be understood that they would continue to reside at the School as grant earning pupils in the regular way.

As time is short, it will be appreciated greatly if you would give this application prompt despatch, so that the northern children may be notified of the Department's decision in time to permit them to return with the others at the end of the holiday. It is hoped that you will see your way clear to endorse the applications in toto.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to the attached correspondence in which Mr. F. Anfield requests, and Mr. Indian Agent Todd recommends a grant of some $250.00 for the further education of five pupils of the St. Michael's Indian Residential School at the Alert Bay Superior School, I wish to report as follows.

Beatrice R. Edwards (Masset)
Flora E. Hanuse (Mamalilikulla)
Charles J. Brown (Bella Bella)

These pupils were promoted to Grade 9 last year, were reported on by me to you in a special report dated August 7th 1939, and have since done very well indeed in Grade 9 at the Provincial Superior School, Alert Bay. They have now been promoted to Grade 10 with the approval of the Provincial Inspector of Schools, Major Manning, with whom I have been in close touch all through the year.

There is no doubt whatever that the above mentioned three pupils are well able to cover the Grade 10 work if given a chance during the next academic year. I would recommend that they be permitted to continue their higher education.

Pupil #567 William McKay (Greenville) and Pupil #693 Leonard D. Leighton (Metlakatla) have done very well in Grade 8 at St Michael's this last year. William McKay has a Binet I.Q. of 103 and Leonard Leighton one of 104. I measured these I.Q.'s myself with Otis Group Test Form "B" and most investigators would have increased each by about 5 points.

The promotion of William and Leonard was made on the joint authority of Major V.Z. Manning and myself, and there is no doubt that the boys would gain greatly from the proposed High School course for which they were recommended.

I wish to recommend that the whole of the five pupils mentioned above be permitted to remain as per capita drawing pupils of St. Michael's Indian residential school during the next year at least.

I wish further to recommend that a grant of some $250.00 be made out of any funds available for the higher education of Indian children to cover the fees of the above five children while pupils of the Provincial Superior School at Alert Bay. I know the whole of these children quite well and have no hesitation whatever in supporting the request of Mr. Anfield and the recommendation of the Indian Agent, Mr. Todd. I am certainly of the opinion that these Indian pupils are well above the average and that they will gain greatly from their High School studies.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry

I, Beatrice Rose Edwards, pupil of St. Michael's Residential School, Alert Bay, make oath and say:

"My father and mother are both dead. My mother's sister married a man by the name of Albert Edwards, and when my mother died I lived with my father for a little while and then my auntie and her husband took me. Then I came to school, and have been in school ever since, but went home for holidays last summer.

Albert Edwards is a lighthouse keeper at Massett. The lighthouse is quite a distance from where they live, and as he has not been very well my auntie told me to go with him to the lighthouse to see that he would be alright. When we were going to and from the lighthouse he tried all the time to make love to me, but I didn't like it and he didn't do anything more. I used to try to get someone else to go with me because I didn't like to be alone with him. He never liked me to play with other boys and girls all summer, and I didn't have a happy time on my holiday because I was always a little bit afraid of him.

I don't want to go back to Massett this summer because I feel that he will want me to do things which I do not want to do and I am afraid of him."

Dear Sir,

On July 7th last Principal Anfield of St. Michael's School came to me accompanied by Beatrice Rose Edwards, pupil of the school, and asked for the Department's assistance in respect to the future of this girl. After Mr. Anfield had discussed the whole matter privately with me, I then discussed her problem with the girl herself, and in view of the disclosures made to me I took the attached statement from her and am forwarding it to you seeking your advice.

For your information, this pupil has now passed her Grade X in the Superior Public School at Alert Bay, the Department having paid her tuition fees during the past two years, and she has been living at the Residential School. This year we had a very excellent report from the school on her work and conduct, and it is her ambition to continue her studies and eventually train for the nursing profession. The Principal of the Superior School reports on her as follows: "Her English is fair to good; in all other subjects she is good. She has the intelligence to carry her along to University entrance." I therefore feel the Department should give every assistance to this child in her efforts to make something out of herself.

You will please note that both her father and mother are dead, and that she lived with an aunt for a short time before being put into the Residential School at an early age, and she has been in the school ever since. The Principal informs me the living conditions in her aunt's home where she has been going for holiday periods are not of the best, and it was for this reason that Beatrice did not wish to return there this year, and was permitted to remain in the school.

Beatrice informs me that she has had a letter from Albert Edwards, stating that unless she comes home immediately he will come to Alert Bay and forcibly take her out of the school, and as the Statement discloses that the girl is afraid of this man, who is not a blood relation, I feel the Department should definitely appoint someone as her legal guardian until she is twenty-one years of age, so that she will not have to return to Massett and her aunt and husband and will be nothing further to do with her. At present of course Mr. Anfield is representing the Department as her legal guardian. Beatrice informs me Mr. Gillatt baptized her about 1925 when he was Indian Agent at Massett, and that in all probability he would know whether Albert Edwards and her aunt ever took out legal adoption papers for her. This case is a pathetic one and I feel requires the sympathetic attention of the Department.

The reason I am taking this up direct with you rather than with her own Indian Agent, Mr. Phillips, is to get quick action in view of the fact that this man Albert Edwards stated he was coming to Alert Bay and forcibly take out of the school if she did not return home.

Dear Sir:

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of 
REGGIE ALLAN, Pupil No. 830, 
of the ST. MICHAEL'S Indian Residential School at ALERT BAY, B.C., 
who died at ST. GEORGE'S HOSPITAL, ALERT BAY, on MAY 20, 1948.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

FORM No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? May 18.

2. At what time of day? 7:30 p.m.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? Rosies' playmates immediately ran to the school to report to me.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Reggie was carried to the school on a stretcher to await arrival of the doctor.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? None.

6. When was the doctor called? 7:35 p.m.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? 7:40 p.m., in the taxi which brought the doctor.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?

9. Add any other useful information here.

The boys decided to cut off branches beyond the treeline, and found a safe place among the trees overlooking the old logging road. Two of the boys made a successful jump but Reggie lost his nerve when at the full height of the pole-barn and he fell about fifty feet.

C. STATEMENT OF INDIAN AGENT

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of Reggie Allan have been recorded? Yes. If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

(1) Remove all means of amusement within school property which are dangerous.

(2) The Department to insist that all children enrolled in this school be properly supervised at all times.

Supervision in this school is lacking and has been for the past four years or more. Children are allowed to roam around at will when they are out of the classrooms. The staff are not aware of where they are or what they are doing. I have complained about this before but no improvement is noticeable.

The school lacks organization of the right type and this must originate with the principal.
